workes lvcius annaevs seneca morrall naturall containing bookes benefites epistle booke prouidence three bookes anger two bookes clemencie booke blessed life booke tranquilitie minde booke constancie wiseman booke shortnesse life two bookes consolation martia three bookes consolation helvia booke consolation polibivs seuen bookes naturall question translated tho lodge physicke london printed william stansby illvstrissimo heroi ac domino svo observandissimo thomae egertono domino de ellismere svmmo angliae cancellario maiestatis regiae secretioribus concilijs omni virtutum genere ac doctrina clarissimo almae academiae oxoniensis cancellario bonorum que studiorum omnium moe enati praestantissimo thomas lodge doctor medicus salutem cvi potius liber iste dicari velit vel ego debeam dedicare quam honori tuo vir omnibus nominibus honorande deliberanti diu multum cogitanti plane non occurrebat etenim cum philosophia ipsa inculta prorsus sit ab omnibus neglecta fere tum si pleris que vt horrida conspuatur non est sane mirandum quo magi veteri quidem debet ne temere cuivis sese offerat ne forte eos incidisse videatur qui cuticulam curantes ipsi nihil admirantur vltra cutem quorum oculis nihil placet nisi quod externa specie lineamentorum harmonia se commendet quorum aures omnia respuunt nisi quae cum voluptate quadam influunt quod si contingat quomodo non contemptui apud omnes esset liber qui apud eum ipsum quem patronum sibi delegit potissimum sordescat quod si ioculare quiddam molliusculum publicum proferendum statuerem quod voluptate nescio qua mentes hominum titillaret tantum introrsum turpe speciosum pelle decora vt inquit poeta non deesset hercle qui fautor vtro que meum laudaret pollice ludum nec certe nauibus que quadrig peterem mihi patronum aliquem quoi donem lepidum nouum libellum opprimerer eorum multitudine credo qui occurrerent mihi naenijs hisce patrocinaturi cum autem re serias tantum tractet author hic noster id que serio quae tantum ijs arrident quibus leuiora illa arrident minus tum eos qui subtiliori quodam oculo mentis acie venustatem philosophiae illam intueri possunt quae si corporeis oculis cerneretur mirabiles amores excitaret sui nescio quod fatum contraxit compendium et certe quamuis eorum numerus tantus esset que talis quorum sinum hic noster posset tuto conuolare vt delectus ipse delectum fere tolleret nescio tamen cuiquam ex omnibus deberi se magi agnosceret quam honorituo qui cum eam opinionem iam diu veneris vt inter prudentissimos virtute quam maxime excultos principatum quendam tenere videaris tum etiam ita ad certam authoris huius normam vitam direxisse momentum officiorum ea perpendisse videris omnia quae ab ipso apiente requiruntur vt si eadem tempora incidisses ille ne praecepta ad exemplum tuum tu vitam ad ipsius praecepta conforma esset vehementer dubitandum qua de causa quidem spem maximam venit aditum ipsi apud te patere quod ea afferat potissimum quae si tibi placeant quod non desperat nemini quidem tuae vitae ratione non alienissimo poterint displicere quid quod eum sibi patronum deligendum censet qui ipsa authoritate possit eam ab aliorum iniurijs vindicare quod cum ita sit nullius quidem iniurijs eo locus erit quamdiu totus ipsi apud te suerit cuius potentia authoritas cum sit maximum talem tamen intuemur vt maiorem indie auctiorem fieri velimus omnes qui videmus inter ajacem vlyssem litem nonnullam apud poetas legimus interiectam de achillis armatura quondam vter indueretur ipsa de facto non disputo poetarum men ea fuit vt cum prudentia polleret alter concilio lacertis alter que robore apud quem tandem armorum eorum ius resideret eumne qui prudentissime ijs vti posset qui robus issime eluceret quod si ex iure manu consertum vocaret authoritas sapientiam sapientia authoritatem ad quem tandem senecae nostri patrocinium aequius pertineret haud esset difficile quidem ad iudicandum tu vero vir honorande cum tanta si sapientia vt ab authoritate quantumuis maximum vinci non possit authoritatem tantam nactus e vt ne sapientiae tuae quamuis eximiae illustri velit loco cedere facile controuersiam anc omnem dirimes quo cum vtrae que summae de paritate contendant ad quem patronum potius accurret quam ad te qui propter sapientiam singularem optime consultum vole libro non insipientissimo propter egregiam authoritatem effectum dabis libro male ne consulatur dico confidenter egregio ad vero quod attinet illustrissime moecen cum multa alia perpulerint vt te potissimum seligerem sub cuius nomine prodeat hic labor seneca transfere meus tumista inprimis quae dicturus sum nempe vt ad senem ille de senectute senex amicissimus scripsit ad amicum de amicitia ita ego illud sileo quod quam vellem vt possem attexere philosophiae libros ho quam sapientiam dixere veteres ad te sapientissimum philosophorum oxonij studentium omnium patronum primarium inprimis statui dedicandum quo quidem loco non possum illius non meminisse quod praetermitti sine scelere nefario non potest quod que grauissimi est instar argumenti cur tibi vel solo vel certe potissimum omnium nostrum qui oxonienses audimus gratae mentis testimonium labores studia inseruiant qu per te effectum est fere vt studijs nostris ibi locus sit vbi cum floruere maxime tum maxime eiecta inde voluissent ij qui minime debuissent per te vero iam effectum id videmus vt qui fontes illos limpidissimos conturbarunt quo minus haustus inde puriores essent iam tandem aduersum musarum alumnos vtcumque coaxant fortasse tantum tamen coaxare possint de hoc autem ni grati simus omnes omnium erimus ingratissimi quin quod magi ipsum spectat illud cardinale quiddam est quod cum beneuolentiae erga tuae vestigia semper vidi non leuiter impressa mihi nun quam satisfacio ipsi priusquam tibi non dicam satisfaciam de animo erga tuo agnoscam certe quantis nominibus obstrictum obaeratum sentiam quin attexo ideo tibi lubens dico quod cum mihi beneuolus semper extiteris tunc etiam ab ijs qui ex emanarunt vtcumque animo esse non poteris alieno hac spe fretus honorande maecenas hosce meos labores quales quales tibi trado manus quos aequi si consulas conditione haudquaquam iniqua susceptos existimauero deumque rogabo opt max vt tamdiu nobis te conseruatum volet quamdiu te virtutum tuarum minime poenitebit dignitatis tuae obseruantiss tho lodg dmp reverendissimis doctoribvs caeterisqve stadio literario optime excercitatis lectoribvs tho lodge medicus phisicus salutem cvm nulli magi opprobrijs alios conscindunt lacerant maledictis quam ij qui opprobrium ipsi facillime incurrunt tum plerum que id euenit vt exilis cuiusdam ingenij ipsi sibi conscij nihil sapere videri se credant aliis nisi plane desipere se probent dum ea carpunt omnino quae non capiunt ex quo euenit vt nihil egregium ita excellens publicum emanarit vnquam quod dentes isti mordaces non impegerint quo hominum genere cum ego facile vindicare nesciam apud vos viri doctores doctores que p estantissimi politioris literaturae alumnos qui quales erga vos ipsi velitis alios esse tale estis erga omnes praefatione vti nonnulla haud absonum fore existimaui vt rationem consilij de seneca nostrum sermonem transmittendo mei vobis explicem video autem multis id displicere quidem id que vehementer quod authores ita latini transferantur sermonem nostrum migrent anglicum cum multa alia tum illud inculcantes iniuriam lite insignem inuehi quod ea quae literatorum deberent esse propria nunc denuo prostituantur omnibus contrectanda prouulgentur qui cum id agunt quid aliud agunt quam vt nostri ad vnum omnes virtutum scientia vt profani quidam arceantur veluta dianae sacris de quibus illud est calimachi nonlatin alphabet hi dum se scientias omnes velut chaldaeis dy postulari volunt quid aliud agunt quam quae ipsi vident vt caeteris omnibus inuideant quae simens eorum fuisset qui ista primo literis mandauerunt quomodo tandem egregia illa ingenij eorum monumenta ad nostra haec tempora permanare potuissent nec vero nios ille priscis inoleuit vt cogitata illa sua praeclara caeteris inuiderent qui per se minus acie valerent ingenio ex omnibus certe vix paucos reperias qui vel graeci latine vel romani graece scripserint quo minus suis innotescerent ea quae libri sui praeclara continerent ex quo effectum id est vt quantum bruta intellectu caeteri tantum ipsi ingenio caeteros antecesserint ne que vero non laudare possum sapientissimum illum apud laertium qui cum de tribus diis ageret gratias quod homo esset natus non brutum quod vir non foemina tertium id erat quod athemensis esset non barbarus non quod solus inter eos sapere visus est sed quod ex infinitis vnus esset qui non nihil sapere didicisset et recte ad amicum scribens tullius monet vt vbiuis esse malit quam vbi sit propterea quod multo rectius illic viuendum sit vbi aliquo numero siet quam illic vbi solus sapere videatur et sane si aequi rerum aestimatores velimus esse facile quidem inueniemus excultiores multo nostros limatiores quam antea extitisse ex quo doctrina illa veterum historia romanorum vernacula ipsos alloquente lingua perpoliri caeperunt quo curriculo labores mei cum non nihil desudarint tum facti mei tamdiu non paenitebit quamdiu publicae vtilitati honori patriae inseruire intellexero quanquam omnes reclamantes videro comici tamen illo facile consolabor recreabo quod nihil animo magi habeam quam vt pluribus prosim quin illud fortasse non recte quod nonlatin alphabet occurrunt senecae nonnulla quae celari multo possunt honestius quam apricum protrudi lucem non ferentia male locata operam eam omnem clamabunt omnes quae non bona habet etiam nonlatin alphabet qua plurima quae si recte ediscantur nihil illa nocebunt quanquam quid egi aut quo euigilauere curae cogitationes meae nisi vt lectorem pro virili praemonerem ad scopulos eos digitum intenderem ad quos si adhaeserit fortasse naufragium illico facturus sit nec vero defuerint ij qui id vitio mihi vertendum senserint quod omnibus non verbum verbo respondeat quin infidus interpres sit ille necesse est vbi fide est opus vel maxime fideliam adhibebit qui ita interpretem agere edidiscit quin ille rectissime non verbum verbo curabitred dere fidus interpres ne poterit quidem quod tum eo re deducetur vt dum verbis se torquebit nimis sensus interim elabatur omnis quis autemita inscius erit vt illud non intelligat omni sermone idiomata loquendi quaedam apparere flores elegantiarum quae si verbis alienis efferantur illico pro ridiculis habeantur longum esset huc omni conuertere quae salsissime latinis dictum nostris enuntiata verbis ijsdem appareant insul quo facilius adducor vt eius omnia sic interpreter vt quae proprijs verbis enuntiari non possunt enuntientur quibus possunt aptissimis hic ego si reprehensionem incurro iustam exemplo consolabor eorum qui cum hoc genere palmam ferant crimen commune mecum sustine bunt nec nostroru solum sed eorum etiam omnium qui hispania gallia italia communem mecum eo genere nauarunt operam agnosco vero libentissime erratum huc irrepsisse nonnulla quae vt homini cuiuis summo otio non vigilantissimo facile possunt obrepere quaedam ita si mihi hoc opere frequentiora visum est qua erat aequum facile ignoscet qui rem ipsam vt acciderit cognoscet prius cum enim primo statuerem ita hoc opere meam operam posuisse vt nequid per incuriam elapsum mihi videri possit medio operis suscepti nescio quomodo medium rerum omnium certamen incidi praeterqua enimillud quod fratre charissimo pientissimo que essem orbatus ita vt studijs nullus locus esset relictus quem dolor vniuersum occuparat accidebat id etiam vt turbis ijs forensibus molestijs vndi que circumfrementibus opprimerer ita vt dum illius omnia iam cum beatis illis incolis agente aeuum co ponere studeo ne subcisiuas horas certe mihi relinquo vllas quibus huic operi iam inchoato supremam manu imponam interim ista dum aguntur annus fere integer elapsus est adhuc tamen pendent opera interrupta mina que murorumingentes vt poetae verbis vtar interea fremere typographus de praelo tantum non praelia mouere quae nactus est typis excudenda curare sed citra cura hoc modo ad imprimendum solum licentia fortasse nactus qui premit semper nec pensi quid habet quid imprimat quin tande vt molestijs hisce euoluo colligo vt possum ex magna iactatione dimidiu senecae alterum quod imperfectum reliquera quantum possum absoluo celeritate nec typographo satisfacio tamen inhianti suo semper luero quin quae manus prima coniecit chartulas subinde arripit ipsa impressione peiora facta emissurus quae prius acceperat omnino non optimum quippe quibus ipsius festinatio praepropera ad ornanda se melius ne minimum quidem indulsit temporis ita fit vt quod mensium nonnullorum opus esse debuerit diebus haud ita multis absolutum prodierit que vtinam absolutu quod si minus conceditur non despero tamen quin per meum dehinc otium quae rudia iam excidere limentur accuratius quae obscuritate nonnulla videbuntur laborare fiant etiam illustriora cum proxime emanabunt obijcient alij qui reprehensionis ansam vndi que arripiet quod versus eius quosdam vna cum apocolocynthesi epistolis quibusda ad diuum paulum exaratis vt non nemo retulit e patribus omnino praetermiserim sed parcent mihi facile spero qui prius norint quibus rationibus adductus huic ego labori pepercerim primo quidem de apocolocynthesi cum liber totus dicterijs mortem claudii c sari sit refertus ne alienus se noster seneca videretur qui vbi que seuerus grauis ab hoc genere qua maxime videtur abhorrens inutili labore potius supersedendum statui qua ea attexenda quae labe nonnullam operi toti possent f fricare de reliquis autem id tantum dico quod cum authoris huius sint multis dubium vocari video tum sint interpretanda vehementer dubito habetis iam tandem doctores lectores beneuoli quae ego dicenda habeo quae si vobis candidioribus arridere perspicero tum vt ii placeant quibus omnia displicent vehementer non contendo valete courteous reader well donne nature gentle reader giue time ill donne men apprehend much thou hast lost life begetting vanity nourishing applauding folly intending read nouem nisi quae docuere sorores castalis vnda tuae nil docet iste liber vera sed hic rectae promit dictamina vitae et sapiens narrat quae bene dixit anus si malus ista leges pote int non ista placere greeke signifieth good patrimonie propertie great ample patrimonie know well employ bestow benefit matter custome giue name mother shee child poet assigned true name thinges whereof intreated rome confesse thou gauest mee life remember mee thy often reproches conceiue thou hast giuen mee death owe thee nothing thou hast saued end make ostentation thy vanitie long wilt thou lead spectacle men torture selfe long thou suffer forget hard fortune beene led triumph enemy beene one day miserable spectacle secrecie must accompany benefites neuer ought wee disclose wee haue giuen hee vpbraideth curtesie redemaundeth wee must importune ought neuer refresh memorie former pleasure seconding another neither ought disclose vnto others let hath done good office conceale let hath receiued disclose otherwise may said vnto one publiquely vaunted boasted pleasure hee done happily said hee r ceiued gift thou wilt ny thou hast receiued againe thou gauest mee asked hee answered many time many place ee say oftentimes many place thou hast vaunted thereof vain ly neede hadst thou speake vsurpe vpon man office man might haue done honestly reckoning vp good hee hath receiued thy hand might praise thee diuers thing thou canst doest discouer leastwise thou wilt say mee vngratefull f concealing thine owne bountie desert make knowne haue receiued ought rather relate thee good thou hast done euill commit confessing thy goodnes thou oughtest pesently make answer truly worthy farre greater benefites know haue better power performe speech wee ought vtter flattering dissimulation fained pretence men doe make shew reiect would faine draw vnto briefly ought vse kinde sweetnesse curtesie much v lieth husbandman loose labour hee hath cast corne ground make reckoning hee hath sowed corne cannot come maturitie without much manuring regard nothing bring forth fruit beginning end labored handled due industrie condition benefites greater care circumspect diligence world parent haue ouer child pedigree cause deceiue thee reckon vp ancestor wheresoeuer noble name faileth presently faine god despise man though pedigree worne remembrance hee smally furthered vnfriendly fortune whether predecessor freeman bond forrainers ouragiously aduance ye mindes whatsoeuer basenesse lieth way leape ye ouer great nobilitie attendeth last pride lifted vp vnto great vanitie seruants disdaine receiue benefit looke vpon sort forgetting desert doest thou call one seruant thou seruant lust gluttonie adulteresse yea common slaue adultere s callest thou one seruant whither art thou dragged groomes beare thy litter whether liuerycloaks counterfeit souldierlike vulgar attire indeed whither say doe carrie thee abroad doore doorekeeper garden doth indeed beare office ordinarie yet deniest whether man according stoicks doctrine may called vngratefull hee affirmeth teacheth fourth question whether vngratefull saith although confesse many depending said question farre whither bound one sonne father like answereth distinction rather denyeth fift question whether vnpleasing benefit may bee giuen man vnwilling receiue may last question whether benefit may bee redemanded former bookes thought consummated accomplished principall intent intreated discouered manner good turne bee done sort receiued two point pole sphere discourse moued whatsoeuer intreat linger necessitie matter correspondent vnto giue men leaue thankelesse list shall bee thy default intended debt gui haue receiued benefit thy hand may freely redemand neither wilt thou refuse former either suppressed dissembled thee intent generous man one hath noble minde long forbeare winke vngratefull person vntill hath made thankefull neither manner dealing deceiue thee euer naturally vice submit themselues ground thinke farre different thou imaginest neuer neede thou feare affront dishonour suffering thy selfe ouercome noble competencie vertuous action thou forsake thine armes ouercome hast ouercome diligence thing appearance subtill deceitfull exile securitie dulnesse sloth men mindes sometimes easie passage laid open may wander sometimes somewhat difficult dangerous set way may hardly creepe without trauell may walke without difficultie said man vngratefull thus concluded benefit profiteth man profit euill man stoicks say therefore euill man receiueth benefit consequently also cannot v honestie cannot euill man apprehend ceaseth euill vertue enter long euill man giue benefit good euill thing oddes cannot reconciled therefore man profiteth whatsoeuer befalleth corrupteth euill vse furthermore men ambitious men wicked thou must bee displeased agrieued hereat mad recall thee vncertainties say vnto thee see vngratefull youth neuer innocent wisheth father breathed last modest dieth vnwillingly departeth mournefully part vngratefull man content himselfe time lent time alwaies seeme short vnto thee thou reckon thinke chiefest good time little soeuer take good part addeth nothing thy felicitie day thy death prolonged delay life made blessed long much better giue thankes vnto goddes honest pleasure wee haue receiued busie selues numbring men yeares esteeme owne thankefully put accompt gaines hath god thought worthy sufficeth mee might hee haue giuen mee also benefit let v bee thankefull god let v thankefull men let v thankefull vnto haue done v curtesie thankefull likewise haue done kindnesse chap xviii thou obligest mee infinitely saiest thou thou saiest prefixe therefore end bestoweth benefit sonne thou saiest bestoweth likewise father first aske whither afterwards desire thee likewise informe whether pleasure done vnto father likewise done vnto brother father vnckle grandfather wife sonne law tell end long wilt thou follow order petigree many person haue tilled thy land thee haue done thee pleasure haue quenched fire would haue burned thy house haue repaired feare fall vpon thee shall giue thee benefit saue thy slaues life shall impute vnto thee preserue thy sonne hast thou receiued benefit hand chap xix thou settest downe vnlike different example tilleth land giueth benefit land hee vnderproppeth house least fall doth pleasure house selfe without sense must need debt none else manureth land doth deserue wel soile selfe say seruant iustly appertayneth profit preserued therefore indebted sonne capable himselfe benefit therefore hee receiued glad fauour done concerneth mee somewhat yet obliged yet would haue thee answere mee thinkest thou art indebted whether thy sonnes good health felicitie patrimonie appertaineth father hee shall bee happy sonne bee whole safe vnhappie los made happier deliuered perrill mightie infelicitie misfortune hath receiued benefit saith certaine thing bestowed vpon others extend also vnto v euery thing ought required hand bestowed money required hand borrowed although came sort hand marke glimps charity euen pagan benefit profit thereof toucheth extendeth neighbour sometimes also farthest v question whether benefite transferred giuen first placed thou must alwaies redemaund principall debter ought first pray thee saiest thou thou hast giuen sonne hee perished haue liued gauest thou benefite life whose safetie thou preferrest thine owne time saued thy sonne thou diddest fall downe feete thou diddest pay thy vowes vnto god thou thy selfe hadst beene pr serued diddest thou cry manner hast thou done succouring sonne ni sauing mine owne person make accompt thou hast saued two especially saiest thou thou receiuest benefite although sonne hath borrowed money repay vnto creditor yet shall bee indebted sonne hath beene taken adulterie may happily ashamed yet shall therefore adulterer say bound vnto thee sonne offer selfe vnto thee voluntarie debter great pleasure hath befallen safetie inestimable profit conceiue thereby haue escaped grieuous wound corrasiue childlesse question whether thou hast profited whether thou hast giuen mee benefit liuing creature herb stone profit yet giue benefite neuer giuen one willing thou wilt giue vnto father sonne meane thou knowest father therefore thou saiest haue therefore giuen benefit father haue saued son argue thou contrariwise particular part publike benefit sayest thou neuer thought time much good vnto men particular intent giue mee citie neither addressed purpose profit wherefore obliged thing wayes thought mee time act intended first bethought himselfe good vnto gaules though also gaule comprehended although proper name yet vnder publique name nation againe shall tyed vnto good properly particularly mine one partaked fauour amongst comminaltie satisfie mine owne behalfe contribute common good countrey chap xx man l nd summe money countrey say indebted neyther acknowledge debt although sued publique office neyther also sued debtor yet contribute part payment debt like sort deni debtor fauour done vnto nation becaus gaue yet manner gaue giuing ame knew whether gaue yea yet know must pay portion thereof good one meanes appertaineth tyeth requite must done shall oblige sort saith neyther owest thou thing moone sunne moued thy sake whereas moued end may preserue thing moue also part vniuerse moreouer condition different e profiteth intent meanes may himselfe gaue benefit hee made instrument profit sunne moone although v good yet end profit v mean profit themselues befriend chap xxi shall know saith hee sunne moone haue profite v power bee willing cannot surcease stay motion n yther abridge intermit accustomed trauell see manie wayes may refelled man therefore lesse willing cannot vnwilling nay rather great argument firm able time change good man cannot choose doe doth shall good man except therefore good man bestoweth b nefit becau e doth ought cannot otherwise ought besides much di ference whether thou sayest cannot chuse compelled cannot vnwilling mu edes doe tyed vnto benefit compell b necessity willingnesse proceed hee hath nothing better himselfe compelleth himselfe looke thing haue beene beholding compelled others shall beholding compeller make cease saith pray think little matter man voyde vnderstanding denie willingnesse acteth thing accompanied danger impediment performance altering selfe contrary seeing side man may right seeme willing whose assuredly certaine remaineth eternall immutable willing may anon vnwilling shall thought willing nature cannot
