intollerable passion comming high hath made v beleeue god report fable haue forged hath planted opinion v measure owne vice equall dreadlesse neuerloathing pleasure doth man enioy heere fashion describe may say skilfull diuine humane lawes contenteth himselfe thing present dependeth future neuer liueth man assurance doateth vncertainties exempted therefore mightie care distract minde hopeth nothing coueteth nothing hang expectation contenteth himselfe owne neyther suppose man contented small rich thing yet sort alexander although conquered much shore red sea yet wanted left behinde whence came country eyther possessed conquered hee sent onesicritus generall gallies discouer ocean search fur warre vnknowne sea sufficiently appeare poore extended warres beyond limit nature thrust himselfe headlong blinde couetousnesse vast vnattempted boundlesse sea skils many kingdomes hee hath violently taken manie hee hath giuen many country hee hath loaden tribute want much desireth chap iii neyther alexander errour onely happy temerity inforced beyond tract bacchus hercules fortune hath made greedy ouerglutting run ouer reckon vp cyrus cambyses progenie king persia wilt thou finde contented satisfied empire ended life thinking proiect neyther wondred falleth couetous hand forthwith exhausted hidden neither skilleth much much thou throngest neuer satisfied wiseman onely master thing neyther costeth much keepe hath embassador send beyond sea campes pitch enemy country garrison dispose conuenient fortress needes legion troups horseman like immortall god without assistance armes gouern kingdom entertain greatnes assurance without disturbance forsaking place high eminent wherin repose euen wiseman executeth gouerneth office although haue large extent without tumult beholdeth mankind himselfe powerfullest best vnder mock thou li test yet matter worthy generous spirit thou hast mind diligently considered east west whereby also thou mayest penetrate remote retired solitude thou hast beheld many liuing creature affluence thing beautifull nature blessedly lauisheth break discourse beseeming god thing mine commeth passe desireth nothing nothing chap iiii sayest thou expresly willed haue ouertaken thee intend see thou wilt rid thy selfe incombrances whereinto thou art wilfully fallen tell mee may man giue ought wiseman thing also giueth owne benefite therefore cannot bestowed vpon vnder name wiseman intends signifie thorow whole body discourse signifieth booke pro er e ecclesiastes wisedome word wisdom signifieth vertue ius ice name wise man sense vertuous iust wiseman haue nothing giuen owne yet say man may giue somewhat vnto wiseman know demand like respect friend say thing common amongst therefore man giue thing friend giueth common cause somewhat may wisemans possesseth giuen assigned ciuill lawe thing king yet thing whose intire possession appertaineth king distributed amongst seuerall lord thing hath possessor therefore may giue king house bondslaue money neyther said giue owne king appertaineth power ouer seueral men property cal bound athenian campanians otherwise neighbour priuate termination distinguish amongst themselues land belonging man commonweal yet part hath determinate owner therefore may giue land commonweale although said commonweales one sort another sort mine bee doubted slaue whatsoeuer substance hath master yet may giue present manner man may giue vnto w se man man cannot therefore say seruant hath nothing could haue lord said neither therefore faileth present gaue willingly might taken although hee would euen haue approued thing appertaine vnto wise man alreadie agreed point must present expresse haue matter need giue liberally vnto w e confesse master haue thing father possession child yet knoweth sonne also may giue father somewhat thing appertaine vnto god yet haue sacrificed altar offered many time temple therefore haue faileth mine thine one thing may thine mine sayest thou baud owner common harlot wise man owner thing amongst thing prostitute comprehended therefore wise man baud like manner forbid buy say man buyeth owne thing appertaine vnto wise man wise man therefore buyeth nothing like manner restraine borrowing thing man payeth interest owne money innumerable thing contend cauill whereas notwithstanding fully conceiue spoken v chap v vndoubtedly sort conclude thing wise man one notwithstanding remaine master lord hee hath euen vnder gouernment good prince king posseseth thing regall authoritie euery priuate man particular tenure title time come shall proue meane let suffice question may giue wise man one kinde another mine neither strange matter somewhat may bee giuen lord haue hired house thee house something thine something mine house selfe thine vse house mine thou therefore shalt neither touch fruit farmer forbid thee although grow thine owne soile scarcitie corne famine ala vaine shalt thou behold anothers mightie mow grew thine owne ground stacked thine owne barne must stored thine owne garner thou shalt enter hired tenement although thou lord thereof neither shalt thou carrie away thy slaue hireling hire wagon thee thou shalt take kindnesse giue thee leaue sit thine owne wagon thou seest therefore may man receiuing owne may receiue courtesie chap vi thing lately recited one master one thing one lord thing selfe vse say bookes ciceroes dorus bookeseller saith book true one challengeth author therof buyer rightly said appertaine right yet manner may titus liuius receiue gift buy money owne book dorus hand answereth former obiections giue wise man particularly appertaineth vnto although thing since kingly manner possesseth thing freely proprietie euery thing distributed euery particular person receiue present owe buy hire thing caesar yet nothing owne patrimonie particular demeanes returned exchequer thing subiect soueraigne power peculiar heritage properly owne question without diminution empire euen adiudged none another sort owne wise man mind possesseth thing law right onely owne chap vii bion somewhiles argument concludeth men sacrilegious sometimes man would cast men tarpeian rocke whence hainous fender headlong cast downe rocke saith whosoeuer hath taken away lauished appertaineth god conuerted vse sacrilegious thing god whatsoeuer euery one taketh away hee taketh god thing appertaine therefore whosoeuer taketh away thing sacrilegious againe would haue temple broken open commandeth capitol pillaged without feare vengeance god capitol place rome dedicated iupiter time past called tarpe saith man sacrilegious whatsoeuer taken place appertaineth god transferred another place appertaineth likewise vnto god answered true thing god thing dedicated god nd sacriledge obserued committed onely thing religion deuotion hath consecrated god say wee likewise whole world temple immortall god onely worthie contain maiestie magnificence yet prophane thing different distant sacred lawfull act thing corner earth hath called temple may lawfully doe sight heauen view starres vndoubtedly crilegious cannot iniurie god whose diuinitie hath planted without shot yet punished hath done god owne opinion obligeth maketh subiect penaltie euen therefore seemeth sacrilegious taketh away sacred thing althoug whithersoeuer transferreth hath taken away within limit world like manner man may rob wise man taken master thing world whereunto peculiar title reputeth vseth owne seuerall possession acknowledgeth would haue though might discourse breake roman emperour vttered vertue good gouernment much land decreed allotted one day could enuiron plow haue need saith citizen hath need one citizen liuing much worthie thinkest thou man refusing gift deseruing many great captaines haue broken defaced men bound neuer one hath limited owne chap viii therefore behold wise man mind powerfull ouerall thing spreading empire ouer whole world wee say thing referre right daily custome shall taxed powle cause require great difference whether possession estimated greatnesse minde reuenues would hate lord ouer thing whereof thou speakest reckon vp socrates chrysippus zeno great personage greater enuie obscureth praise haue liued time past little made mention demetrius nature iudgement seemeth purposely haue bred time shew neither could corrupt correct v man though himselfe deny exact wisdom firme constancie thing determined yea eloquence best sitted matter greatest strength polished painted word proof cutting cause great courage according heat carried doubt diuin prouidence gaue man life abilitie discourse end age might want good example reproch chap ix one god would deliuer good demetrius possession vpon condition might lawfull giue away dare auerre would refuse would say entangle selfe inextricable waight plunge man cleane free auarice deepe bog sincke thing bringest thou mischiefes infelicity men would receiue although could giue away presently see many thing might honestly giue contemplate thing dazle eye king nation behold thing spend blouds hazard soules set mine eye chiefest spoiles superfluitie whether thou wilt vnfold order better deliuer grosse see vaulted roofe cunningly carued curious varietie shels diuers loathsome sluggish creature bought excessiue price wherein varietie pleaseth made counterfeit colour according similitude thing themselues see place table wood estimated lesse senator substance much precious much infelicitie tree writhed wrested infi knot see place vessel chry whose brittlenesse enhanseth price amongst ignorant men p asure thing augmented euen dange use v hate see pot vessel murrhine superfluity rio e penny beene sufficiently prized vomited great v sels pretious stone excessiue wine drunke one others health see pearles seuerally fitted euery one eares accu tomed beare burthen diuers tyed together two third hanged vnder madnesse woman ufficiently brought husband subiection except hanged eyther care worth two three men patrimony see silken garment may called garment wherein nothing may couer eyther body leastwise shame woman hath put vpon may scarcely swea e naked great sum way commerce fetched forraine nation matron may shew themselues adulterer chamber publique chap x doest thou auarice many thing value surpasse thy gold thing haue reckoned vp honour better price recognize thy rich plate mettals couetousnesse dazeled earth produced whatsoeuer pro itable vse hath drowned mettals yea whole waight hath cast selfe vpon vpon hurtfull hatef thing could come light common hurt nation e iron taken darkenesse whence gold siluer end neyther instrument mutuall slaughter n yther price murtherers wanting yet haue thing som matter esteem somewhat wherein mind may follow errour eye see patent indenture obligat ons emptie image couetousnesse certaine shadow sicke auarice deceiue mind delighteth opinion transitori thing interest daybookes vsurie c rtaine name humane couetousnesse nature neuer heard complaine nature shee hath hidden gold siluer deeper hath cast heauier bu might remoued register computation sailable time called centesima kind vsury amongst roman creditor wont giue debtor crown vse therof paid euery moneth crowne interest till hundreth month past end whereof returned principall crediter bloudie vsuries twelue hundreth voluntarie euils depending constitution nothing may subiected eye held hand dreames vaine couetousnesse wretched taketh delight reade ouer great rentall patrimonie large demeanes tilled bondman infinite heards cattell need whole country kingdomes feed family greater warlike nation priuate building bignesse exceede great city hath well examined thing whereby hath disposed spread rich made himselfe proude compare hath desireth poore man let go restore rich minde know kingdome wisedome great secure enioy thing men may enioy particular chap xi whereas therefore caius caesar gaue demetrius two hundreth talent smiled refused deeming value might iustly glorie refused god goddess small thing would either haue honoured corrupted minde must testifie worthy man haue heard great matter reported wondred caesar indiscretion thought could changed sleight matter said thus said intended tempt haue tempted whole empire chap xii something therefore may giuen wiseman although thing likewise nothing letteth something may giuen friend though say thing common amongst friend sort thing common betwixt friend partner part one child common father mother hauing two betwixt haue one two peice first make know whatsoeuer hee copartner nothing common betwixt association cannot amongst wisemen onely vnderstand practise vse true friendship friend copartner againe good common diuers kindes siege theater ordained knight appertaine knight rome yet place sate mine owne haue yeelded vp place although giue place thing c mmon yet seemeth haue giuen somewhat thing appertaine men vnder certaine condition haue place amongst knight sell hire possesse continually onely end behold publik sport shal therfore lie say haue place amongst knight come theater place taken vp yet right haue place lawfull sit haue occupied haue much title place selfe suppose care amongst friend whatsoeuer friend ath common v yet propertie possesseth cannot vse thou mockest sayest thou appertaineth friend mine haue libertie sell haue libertie thou canst sell knight place yet common thee order argument therefore thing thine thou canst sell thou mayest consume thou mayest change worse better thine although thine vpon condition haue taken place yet hast thou neuerthelesse chap xiii dallie delay thee longer one benefite cannot greater another thing whereby benefit may giuen may greater beneuolenc may extend selfe please selfe louers wont whose many kiss closer embracement increase exercise loues question also ensueth fully debated former therefore shall shortly handled argument haue vsed question may employed question whether hee hath done best restore benefite hath giuen satisfaction thou mayest know sayest thou hath satisfied hath done recompence appeareth therefore thing done meanes hath paide siluer ought vnto creditor performe sought euery could finde thing condition must needes effected thing much haue attempted man cou haue effected deed physitian hath done vttermost heale patient hath performed part orator although cly nt condemned haue shewed vttermost art hath lost honour eloquence generall captaine although conquered commended much lay proceeded prudence industrie fortitude hath attempted meanes recompence thy courtesie thy felicity letted calamitie hath falne vpon thee whereby thou mightest make tryall true friendship could giue vnto rich man sit healthfull man succour happie man thankefull vnto thee although thou receiuedst benefit besides intending matter alwayes expecting time opportunitie hath spent manie care e imployed much diligence finde occasion requitall ath endeuoured whose fortune make satisfaction suddenly chap xiiii example debitor farre different hath done little gathering mon exc pt hath paide importunate creditor standeth ouer head sussereth day passe without interest thou art matched bountifull creditor shall see thee ro ting vp downe carefull pensiue satisfie saith vnto thee dislodge care thy breast cease vrgent thine owne trouble wholly satisfied thou dost iniurie thou thinkest desire thing thy hand fully possessed thy good mind tell saith wouldst thou say restored benefite onely beene thankefull reckoning hath requited hath satisfied like reckoning contrariwise put case hath forgotten benefite hath receiued hath wayes endeuoured himselfe requite wouldest thou say requited man speake hath wearied himselfe day night renouncing office thinke vpon hath wholly intended satisfaction laboured occasion ouerslip shall therefore like respect hath cast away care returning gratuitie neuer thought ought else thou dealest vniustly thou exactest recompence hand thou seest minde euer addicted content thee short put case thou wert captiuitie ransom thee hauing engaged good vnto creditor taken assurance mony borrowed thee put forth sea sore stormie winter coast promontory beleag ed pyrats furthermore suffered peril may chance euen peaceable sea hauing trauersed desert men liuing fled sought finde thee comming last pyrats whose hand alreadie another discharged thee wilt thou denie haue requited thy goodnesse vndertaking iourney haue shipwrack lost money borrowed thy ransome fall selfe captiuitie whence would deliuer thee wilt thou confesse haue beene thankefull vnto thee yet vndoubtedly athenian called armodius aristogiton tyrant quellers mutius hand left vpon enemy altar much slaine porsenna vertue likewise wrestling fortune although intended action effected alwayes honoured hath performed hath followed flying occasion euer hunted new might thankefull hee first occasion made gratefull without paine trauell chap xv hee hath saith hee employed two thing thee good thou likewise owest two worthily mightest thou say vnto onely yeelded thee idle thou canst speake willeth endeauoreth leaueth nothing vnattempted performeth much lieth power againe number alwayes equalled number sometimes one thing ouervalueth two therefore forward desirous make restitution standeth stead benefite minde without act bee sufficient requite benefit man thankfull god nothing bestowed wee saith giue nothing god haue thing giue obliged bee reputed gratefull toward men yeelding herein cannot giue vnto god chap xvi yet thou aske thinke wilt subscribe vnto mine answere let man iudge hee hath receiued benefit man know hath requited let one release confesse debt let man say haue man owe controuersies let v respect common good let vngratefull men exempted excusations may flie vnder may colour refusall haue done could doe likewise thinkest thou ancestor imprudent vnderstood vniust act set difference betweene spent money borrowed creditor royot sport either fire theeues misfortune lost owne men truely admitted excuse end men know faith obserued euery way better iust excuse amongst accepted men attempt thou hast done thou canst satisfie let suffice thee little euen vnworthie receiue requitall suffereth thy serious sedulous endeuour slip away vnregarded likewise art thou vngratefull thou thinke thy selfe freely obliged taketh thy good payment meanes acquiteth thee thou owe lay hold neither contest yet seeke thou occasion restitution requite one asketh releaseth thee repay man wicked euill therefore thou hast cause thinke question may stand thee stead whether hee hath receiued benefit wise man wise bound restore afterwards hee become foolish shall good man thou wouldest restore thing committed thy trust thou haddest receiued wise man yea euill man wouldest thou satisfie lent thee likewise wouldest thou restore benefit hee changed shall change thee thou hadst receiued thing man health wouldest thou restore sick whereas alwaies obliged friend hee weakest truely man sicke minde let bee helped let borne withall folly sicknesse minde intent may bee better vnderstood mee thinketh good vse distinction herein chap xvii two kind benefit one wise man cannot giue wise man absolute true benefit vulgar little value whereof vse ordinarie amongst v ignorant men doubt ought restore owe whatsoeuer hee bee whether become homicide theefe adul rer lawes punish crime bad action iudge better chast seth vngratefull man let man make thee b bad himselfe fling away benefit wicked man restore good man one owe lest debt chap xviii kinde benefit question capable receiue except wise ought likewise restore wise man put case tender yet cannot receiue capable hath lost science vse command bandie backe ball maimed man hand folly giue hath power receiue may begin answere thee thy last speech giue hee cannot receiue yet recompence good hath done although cannot receiue cannot oblige man receiueth yet may discharged giue satisfaction cannot make vse thereof let looke fault shall bee chap xix restore saith thing deliuer hand ought receiue thou owest wine vnto man willeth thee powre net si ue wouldest thou say thou addest repaid wouldest thou returne whilest restored spilt betweene restore giue thou owest appertaineth hath receiue onely thing ought performe may receiue receiued hand charge owe custodie thereof acquitall faith farre better haue restore presently satisfie creditour although know hee suddenly send owe vnto stewes although assigne ouer satisfied adulteresse pay would powre money receiue bosome vntied yet giue must repay yet bound either keepe defend ought carefully keepe good haue receiued haue restored long remaineth see shall lost called must satisfied although slip ou hand receiued restore good man shal profitable euil man shal demand thou canst saith redeliuer benefit vnto sort thou receiuedst thou receiuedst fro wise man thou repaydst foole neither embased render haue receiued recouer wisdome redeliuer intirely receiued long euill render one may receiue saith hee made euil cruell enraged apollodor phalaris wilt thou restore benefit thou hast receiued hand nature suffereth great change wise man falling best worst must need follow also impression goodnesse remaineth euen wickednesse vertue much extinguished men impresseth markes cannot defaced change wilde beast haue beene brought vp amongst v breake wood retaine part former tamenesse looke much wilder amest beast much tamer wildest beast neuer many tractable man hand man hath euer fallen extreame wickednesse hath euer stucke vnto wisdome hee tainted deepely may wholly washed changed colour furthermore aske thee whether speake bee onely sauage cruell minde take pleasure procure ruine publike misfortune whole world thou hast proposed vnto apolidorus phalaris tyrant whose nature euill man haue himselfe restore benefit back againe end may wholly acquit euer delighteth taketh pleasure humane bloud exerciseth vnsatiable crueltie age rageth anger certaine thirst desire hath shed bloud hee killeth child father presence contented simple death tortureth onely burneth die scorcheth altar alwayes soyled new murthers massacre small matter keepe backe benefit one whatsoeuer whereby lincked vnited together hath beene dissolued reason crueltie tyrannie hee hath broken right lawes humane societie done thing receiued good hand afterwards taken armes made warre country whatsoeuer deserued lost thankfull would reputed haynous crime assaile country tedious owne iniurie nation e persecuteth owne notwithstanding great impiety minde dissolueth bond whereby vnited sufficient make mine enemie leastwise shall haue occasion loath hate respect duetie ought beare common good men deserueth haue power ouer mee obligation owe one particular person chap xx bvt although may freely act whatsoeuer listeth towards time since whereby violating lawes hath brought passe nothing may vnlawfully attempted yet beleeue action must bee limited good intend benefit shall neither augment force destruction men neither confirme power hath alreadie say may doe without ruine commonwealth restore benefit saue childe infant doth benefit wrong crueltie dism mbreth furnish money pay souldiers guard shall want ither marble rich raymen shall wayes preiudi iall man shall supply excesse superfluitie souldiers furniture helpe request way great kindnesse send cunning comedi n gourtezans delight may mper cruelty wil willingly offer though would send armed gallies shippes warre yet would send whirries couered barge like thing wherein king take pastime intend sport themselues vpon sea hope amendment vtterly lost yet hand giue benefit men returne best remedie euill disposition best dead whose life neither reclaimed rectus ied seldome great wickednesse seene rare reputed alwayes strange wonderfull feared gaping opening earth great fire burst forth deepest caues sea let v therefore leaue speake detest without horror euill man may find euery marketplace priuate men eare returne benefit haue receiued must make profit wickednesse looke belongs let returne oweth hee good bee bad diligently examine thing restore giue place craueth merrie fable chap xxi certaine pythagorist vpon credit bought paire clownish shooes cobl r great matter warrant dayes came vnto shop make satisfaction long time knocked doore one answered lose labour cobler seeke carried burned may griefe v lose friend euer know shall borne anew thus iested pythagorist philosopher carried home three foure penny merily shaking diuers time hand went homeward afterwards accusing himselfe pleasure conceiued nonpayment perceiuing much little gaine pleasing returned shoppe said vnto himselfe hee liueth thee pay thou thou owest word hee thrust foure penny shop crany wall closing panell shrunke chastising himselfe cursed auarice lest accustome himselfe detaine another man good chap xxii seeke thou thou mayest returne thou owest man require payment thy hand call thou thy selfe account appertaines thee whether good euill restore accuse thy selfe forgetting office diuided betweene haue commanded forget thee haue enioyned remember notwithstanding deceiueth himselfe thinketh say hath giuen benefit neuer thinke pleasure hath done wee would haue entirely lose remembrance honestest thing may done world wee command thing strictly ought cause th returne true particular proportion say must remember meaning must publish abroad hee ought vaunt reproach som make courtesy haue done tabletalke amongst companion talke sober talke drunke discouer stranger commit friend inordinat reproachfull memorie might repressed commanded done courtesie friend neuer remember commanding could performe perswaded silence chap xxiii oft thou distrusteth ouer thou hast command thou mayest exact farre thou needest end may performed sufficient euery hyperbole aimeth issue lie man may attaine vnto truth therefore said exceed snow whitenesse surpasse windes lightnesse could said end could beleeued said fixed rockes headlong torrent thinke perswade one immoueable rocke excessiue superlatiue kinde speech neuer hopeth much dareth affirmeth incredible thing end may attaine vnto credible say let hath giuen benefite forget meaning one forgotten let man perceiue hath remembrance thereof memorie awakened say ought redemand bene againe wholly take away meanes redemanding ofttimes euill men haue neede exacter good men also admonisher shall shew ignorant man opportunity requitall shall discouer necessity vnto eyther hee belie himselfe sorie hee knew let admonition intermixed yet modest neyther sauoreth importunity matter plea chap xxiiii socrates hearing friend said ought cloake money required man admonished contention supply ow small matter socrates receiued great matter worthy one socrates would receiue could mildely chastise said bought cloake money whosoeuer forwardest gaue late socrates already necessitie intemperate exactors sake forbid redemand benefit neuer put vse might done modestly sparingly chap xxv aristippvs hauing sometimes taken pleasure good sauors perfume said beshrow effeminate fellowes haue defamed worthy thing must said euill betide wicked importunate exactors benefit haue extinguished worthy admonition amongst friend yet wil vse loue friendship redemand benefit would haue requested need receiue stead another benefite haue meanes requite haue done neuer say way complaint tooke thee vp cast vp vpon shore forlorne poore mads made thee partner princely state admonition rather reproch lesse bring benefit hatred direct meanes make eyther lawfull delightfull thankelesse enough much refresh memorie submisse familar word haue ought demerited thee ought well liking hath appeard let likewise say otherwise thou hast deserued thou hast entertained thy house tempest cast shore denied supply shipwrackt poore chap xxvi bvt saith haue done good dissembles forgetful doe thou proposest necessary question becommeth v conclude discourse ingratefull men borne withall truely peaceable milde great minde let neuer inhumane forgetfull vngratefull man offend thee delight thy bountie extinguished thee neuer let iniurie inforce speech thee would done let infelicitie thy benefite content thee likewise shall repent euer thou hitherto repent thee thou must grieued new casualtie befalne thee thou oughtest rather wonder happened one affrighted labour another charge another danger another vnseemly bashfulnesse lest requitall acknowledge hath receiued forget duetie another idle affaire another ouerbusie marke immeasurable desire men doo alwayes gape graspe mony thou wilt wonder see man addressed requite man receiueth enough one firm solid mind thou mayest safely trust thy benefit man mad lust man serueth bellie another wholly addicted lucre whose substance thou hardly mayest equall man sicke enuy another blinded ambition readie runne vpon sword point adde hereunto dulnesse minde olde age contrariwise agitation perpetuall tumult vnquiet breast annex hereunto much esteeme insolent pride man selfe contemned speake contumacie incline worst inconstancie leuitie setled nothing adde vnto headlong temerity feare neuer giueth faithfull counsell thousand errours wherewith intangled boldnesse coward discord familiar common mischiefe trust vncertainties loath thing possession wish thing may wayes hope attaine chap xxvii seekest thou faith thing peaceable amidst passion mind restlesse true image life presented thine eye thou wouldest suppose thou sawest pillage great citie taken assault wherein without respect shame iustice enemie stead counsaile vseth force violence publique proclamation permitted exercise pleasure kinde outrage neyther fire sword spared murthers mischiefes punished religion selfe hath oftentimes amongst armed enemy saued liues humbled themselues feete cannot containe men set vpon pillage one forcibly defaceth good priuate house another publique man stealeth prophane thing man sacred one breakes vp passeth ouer man discontented straightnesse passage ouerthroweth stoppeth way make profite ruine man spoyleth without slaughter man beareth bootie bloudie hand man catcheth something another amidst greedinesse mankind feare thou art much forgetful common fortune seekest finde gratefull man amongst many robber thou art agrieued vngratefull men sorie luxurious men vexed couetous men displeased impudent men angrie deformed sicke pale olde men vice confesse grieuous intollerable breaketh society men deuideth destroyeth concord whereby weakenesse supported yet common himselfe complaineth cannot auoyd chap xxviii bethinke thy selfe whether thou hast beene thankfull euery one thou art obliged whether pleasure haue beene done thee lost whether thou hast alwayes remembred benefites thou hast receiued others thou shalt see thing giuen thee thou wert childe forgotten thee ere thou wert stripling thing bestowed thee thy youth continued thy memorie vntill olde age thing haue lost thing haue reiected thing haue vanished sight little little thing selues haue turned eye excuse thy weakenesse first memorie fraile cannot long time apprehend great number faires must needes lose much entertaineth ouerwhelme elder later commeth pas authority thy nurse pr uaileth little thee succeeding yeares haue layed benefit hath done thee farre thy thought hence groweth thou yeeldest reuerence thy master commeth passe whilest thou art busied labouring consulship pretendest priesthood thou forgettest gaue thee voyce questor happely thou diligently examine thy selfe thou shalt finde vice whereof thou complainest thine bosome thou doest amisse angrie publique crime foolishly angrie thy selfe absolue thy selfe forgiue others thy su ferance thou mayest make better worse thy reproches thou must harden heart let shame left retaine still ofttimes publique notorious reproach exile doubtfull mod stie man would retaine man feareth seene shame discouered lost chap xxix haue lost benefit shall say haue lost thing consecrate good v benefite ought numbred amongst thing consecrated prouided man hath well employed although badly requited haue shewed himselfe hoped would let v wee haue beene let v vnlike vnto wrong done appeareth vnthankfull man accused v owne disgrace complaint losse benefit signe badly giuen neere let v pleade cause selues say happely hee could peraduenture knew perhaps doe hereafter wise patient creditor sometimes recouereth debt reputeth lost forbearing debtor giuing time like must let v nourish languishing faith forget themselues chap xxx h ue lost ben fite thou foole thou knowest time thy detriment thou hast lost thou gau st matter discouered euen thing se lost moderation hath profited much infirmity bodie minde handled gently ttim thing pati nce delay hath discouered vnfolded broken pertinacie stubbornnesse haleth ne reproach need plaint needes pursuit doest thou acquit dismissest thou vngratefull oweth thee nothing reason prouoke incense thou hast many wayes pleasured end doubtfull friend may becom assured enemie giue mean defend cause better procuring thine owne shame bee say sure great matter know hee could abide much indebted man sort complained superior stained though could face greatnesse honor neyther man content fain trifle seek credite greatnesse lie chap xxxi farre better way whereby hope friendship reserued opinion friendship likewise thankefull entertaine better thought incessant goodness conquereth euill men neyther man hard hat full minde thing beloued loueth euen greatest wrong continue good men beginneth owe also sustaineth displeasure hand requiting reflect thy thought therefore vpon correspondencie h ld shall doe euen god best author thing begin bestow benefites know whence come perseuer also good vngratefull one chargeth little regard v another haue iniustly dispensed grace another thrusteth world leaueth alone sloth heauiness without light thing another saith sun owe haue distinguished time betweene labour rest deliuered darken sse wee haue escaped confusion perpetuall night course tempereth yeare nourisheth body hasteneth haruest ripeneth fruit som stone globe casuall fire call thing rather god notwithstanding god like good parent smile iniuries little child cease heape benefites vpon suspect author benefites equall hand distribute blessing amongst al nation reseruing themselues power good water earth timely shower moue sea fitting windes distinguish time course starres weaken winter sommers gratious intercourse gentler wind pardon mildely winke suffer errours sinnes sinfull soules let v imitate let v giue although many thing haue beene giuen vaine yet let v giue vnto others let v giue uen vnto haue sustained losse man forbeareth build house feare ruinated fire hath consumed place aboad suddenly lay new foundation againe ere floore halfe colde ofttimes build city place destoyed sunke constant confirmed mind good hope men labor would cease land sea reedifie reattempt ruines past chap xxxii hee thankelesse man hath iniured himselfe vse benefit gaue neyther therefore giue slowely diligently haue lost recouer others yea man also giue benefit like good husbandman care labour conquer barrenn sse soyle haue lost benefit man credite men action generous minde giue lose marke mightie minde lose giue end seuenth last booke benefit epistle lvcius annaevs seneca philosopher written vnto lvcilivs together argument vnto euery epistle ivstvs lipsivs london printed william stansby lvcivs annaevs seneca epistle lvcilivs argument iustus lipsius epistle commendeth lvcilivs estimation vse time ought deferred let slippe neither ill employed doe lucilius recouer thy selfe thy selfe time hitherto hath beene either taken thee stollen thee otherwise hath escaped thee recollect reserue thy selfe perswade thy selfe write time taken away fro v stolne v slip away v shamefullest losse may proceedeth negligence thou wilt seriou ly neerely obserue thou shalt perceiue great part life flitteth doe euill greater doe nothing whole doe doe man wilt thou shew hath put price vpon time esteemeth day vnderstandeth daily dieth herein deceiued wee suppose death bee farre v yet notwithstanding greater part thereof alreadie ouerpassed year behind death holdeth possession therefore lucilius thou writest vnto thou doest embrace lay hold houre come passe thou shalt lesse suspence morrow thou lay hold fasten thy hand day whilest life deferred fleeteth thing lucilius forren v time onely owne nature hath put v possession fraile fleeting thing may expelled man great folly mortall men suffer thing yea euen least vilest truly recouerable imputed vnto haue obtained let man thinke oweth thing hath receiued time meane thing indeed gratefull man cannot restore happily thou wilt aske doe command thee thing ingeniously confesse vnto thee doe befalleth luxurious man diligent take strict account expence cannot say lose nothing yet know well lose readie yeeld reason pouertie befalleth many others brought pouertie owne fault men pardon man succoureth think poore supposeth little remainder hath sufficient yet rather thou shouldest keepe thine owne begin vse good time thou mayest elder opinion sparing beginneth bottome late least also worst remaineth lee epist ii approueth quiet bodie mind also one thing studie condemneth ercurious runne ouer reade diuers author writing perswadeth rather reade ew good dwell vpon counsel eth alwayes cu one thing commit memorie example made vse saying epicvrvs touching pouertie conceiue good hope thee reason thing thou writest vnto mee heare spoken thee thou art wanderer neither disquieted desire transporting thy selfe one place vnto another tossing sicke minde iudgement chiefest testimonie well composed minde able consist dwell selfe beware lest desire reade many author sort bookes containe giddinesse inconstancie mind thou must stayed maner nourished certain spirit thou wilt apprehend thing shall con antly remaine thy memory euery tha passe life trauel take vp many innes entertaine friendship must need befall acquaint themselues familiarly one spirit lightly trauers slightly ouerrunne many thing meat neuer nourisheth bodie sooner taken deliuered nothing much hindereth man health often change remedy wound hardly cured couered diuers sort medicine tree prospereth transported one place another short nothing profitable profiteth passing ouer multitude bookes distracteth distempereth vnderstanding therfore vnable read much thou hast sufficeth haue much thou canst reade sayest thou ouerrunne booke stomacke distempered longeth diuers sort meat beeing different diuers doe rather choake com ort nour sh reade therefore thou wilt credit bookes alwaies approued though variety sake thou sometimes change let others vnto thee thy harbour thine ordinarie retreat house purchas vnto thy sel e euery day new force pouertie couns l death fortifie thy self preseruations th plunge life thou hast tasted diuers thing lay hold one day thou mayest digest likewise doe diuers thing reade apprehend somewhat see heere haue learned day epicur wont sometime passe mine enemy campe fugitiue spie contented pouertie saith honest thing pouertie contented contenteth himselfe pouertie rich man hath little desireth poore man skilleth much man hath chest much lieth barn much feedeth much profiteth vsurie still gape men gaines make reckoning thing hath gotten remaineth gotten thou requirest measure proportion rich first haue necessarie next sufficeth epist iii oftentimes badly rashly called friend deserueth name friend thing reposed trusted faith communicated vnto another selues fearefull base minded reprehended likewise ouercredulous open meane best thou hast deliuered thy letter conueyed hand thou sayest friend thine thou aduertisest communicate thy pertinent affaire thou sayest thou art accustomed doe like one letter thou allowest disauowest thy friend beleeue first thou hast giuen name friend aduenture common name sort cal euery man passeth v name sir ignorant name called let tell thee thou thinkest haue friend thou wilt put much confidence thy selfe thou deceiuest thy selfe much vnderstandest sufficiently force true amitie deliberate thing thy friend first resolue thy selfe thy friend friendship contracted ought wee trust bee formed ought iudge preposterously confound office contrarie precept theophrastus loue iudge haue iudged loue thinke therefore long time thy selfe whether man bee entertained thy friendship thou shalt resolued accept loue discouer vnto readily thy whole hart boldly communicate thy secret thy selfe yet liue thou thy thought action may thou mayest commit serious obseruation thine enemie sometimes diuers thing fall custome hath made secret impart freely vnto thy friend thy designes cogitation thou supposest faithfull thou wilt doe lesse many haue taught deceiue fearing lest themselues deceiued haue ministred men priuiledge offence vaine suspicion cause therefore conceale thing friend thinke selfe alone commit thing onely communicable friend euery one meete disburthen euery whatsoeuer distastefull vnto againe likewise distrustfull faith esteeme dearest yea could would scarcely trust themselues inwardly oppresse themselues owne secret neither thing done sauour infirmitie credit men credit one opinion laudable vice secure reprehend alwayes disquiet alwayes idle manner liuing first industrie rather course recourse tempest agitateth soules touching thinke motion trouble vexation rather dissolution languor moderation commit therefore memorie haue read possidonius saith sort retired hidden thinke thing garboile open light behoueth thee temper thing together chuse certaine intermission proper action repast deliberate nature tell thee made day night epist iiii exhorteth perseuer philosophie wherby may esteemed serious graue perfect man rest hee concludeth child feare thing feared especially death concludeth end euils eyther sudden motion desperation many haue contemned reason concludeth therefore life loued ought daily thinke vpon di er light cause death approacheth v finally proposeth embleme epicvrvs true rich continue thou hast begun indeuour thy selfe much thee lieth end thou mayest plentifully enioy reformed gouerned minde reforming moderating thou shalt enioy contentment man receiueth contemplation conformed minde replenished perfect innocencie farre pleasant agreeable thou doest remember pleasure thou diddest feele hauing left thy childish liuerie thou tookest vpon thee abilements man brought pretor marketplace expect far greater beyond comparison thou shalt cast thy childish mind philosophie hath inrouled thee amongst number men childehood ouerslippeth v easily grieuous childishnesse remaineth v worst see haue alreadie authoritie old men neuerthelesse possesse yet vice child onely child infant affraid thing small value thing false feare one thou wilt well bethinke thy selfe thou shalt vnderstand certaine thing cause bring v much feare ought lesse feared euill great commeth last might feare death could abide alwayes v necessarie eyther befall v ouerpasseth incontinently thou tell difficult thing perswade mind contempt life doe consider vpon light occasion haue attempted one hath strangled himselfe halter mistris doores another hath cast himselfe top house bottom auoyde master displeasure another hath stabbed himselfe breast rather would brought back place whence fled thinkest thou vertue cannot inforce much excessiue feare could trust man enioy peaceable secure life laboureth ouer much prolong esteemeth great benefite see obserue reuolution many yeares meditate euery day haue power leaue thy life freely willingly diuers men entertaine another maner embrace bryers thorn haue beene driuen athwart violence furious streame float betwixt feare death torment life liue know die fashion therefore vnto thy selfe pleasant life forsaking sollicitude may befall thee loue good plausible possessor losse whereof minde alreadie prepared nothing losse whereof easie supported lost cannot redesired take thee courage assurance thing subiect necessitie thou art euen mightie king egypt pupill pothinus eunuchus eunuch gaue sentence great pompey head crassus cruell insolent parthian caligula caius caesar commanded lepidus present necke tribune decimus hee himselfe gaue owne chaereas fortune hath neuer much fauoured man hath affronted many menace trust ouermuch vnto calme instant sea turned ship swallowed day wantonly played water thinke eyther thiefe enemie may ayme sword thy throat although greater power wanting basest slaue liueth hath power thy life death assure thee whosoeuer contemneth life lord thine take account dead complots seruants open outrage treason thou shalt see lesse made away indignation slaues displeasure king importeth mightie thou fearest euery man may thou fearest chance thou fallest hand thine enemy conqueror command thou ledde kept place may haue thee alwayes mercy deceiuest thou thy selfe beginnest thou vnderstand thou hast suffered thy birth tell thee houre thou wert borne thou art led die like thing ought continually liue remembrance mind moderately expect last houre feare whereof replenisheth others disquiet heere make end letter making thee partaker fruit day haue gathered another man garden pouertie measured according rule nature great rich knowest thou well limit rule nature giueth v neyther haue hunger thirst cold end driue away hunger thirst thou hast need wait attend proude great g te suffer disdainfull imperious contemners expose thy selfe baites contumelious courtesy thou needest attempt fortune sea armes nature deserueth found euery take paine obtaine superfluous thing weare gownes peace make v watch tent cast v forraine shoares sufficeth v already hand epist v hee keepeth backe friend ostentation philosophie counselleth make himselfe noted habit diet perswadeth contemne thing vulgar make moderate vse without abuse hee detesteth vncleanlinesse calleth v lawe nature vrgeth clause hecaton coniunction hope feare auowing free one hath cast obnoxious whosoeuer one whereas thou trauellest continually thing set apart endeuourest make thy selfe daily vertuous praise thee glad heare onely counsell thee perseuer therein likewise intreat thee thereof admonish thee according maner seeke much profit seene thou applie thy selfe doe certaine thing ouersingular remarqueable strangenesse eyther manner thy life thy habit flie sluttish behauiours weare thy haire ouerlong knotted filthie thy beard vncombed lie ground make profession haue sworne hatred golde siluer whatsoeuer followeth ambition wrong course sole name philosophie modest soeuer selfe sufficiently subiect enuie separate selues companie men well may inwardly thing vnlike vnto look behauiours must agreeable good liking people let garment eyther gay slouenly let siluer enchased gold yet let v assured token frugalitie destitute eyther gold siluer let v doe leade better life common sort wont yet altogether contrarie otherwise stead correcting shall driue banish v cause disliking action imitate one philosophie promiseth first common sense humanitie entercourse societie shall become separated dissimilitude profession let v rather take heede lest fashion would held admiration proue ridiculous odious vnto others intent liue according direction nature thing altogether contrarie vnto afflict bodie hate ordinarie cleanlinesse loathsome sordid vse onely grosse meates also harmefull distastefull euen affect seeke delicacie riot also kinde madnesse flie thing vsuall may recouered without great expence philosophie requireth frugalitie miserie since honest well seeming frugalitie may bad thinke good man keep measure behoueth v life balanced betwixt good publike maners well content men admire life yet let within knowledge shall doe rest shall difference betwixt v yes great deale onely shall reknowledge obserueth v neerely shall enter house let rather looke v moueables man great generous vseth earthen platter like siluer vessell lesse hee vseth siluer vessell earthen platter able endure rich part weake mind impart vnto thee profit haue made day haue found hecaton end coueting sufficeth remedie feare thou wilt giue ouer saith feare thou ceasest hope thou wilt say thing diuers together lucilius although thing seeme contrarie yet ioyned vnited one euen one chaine bindeth officer prisoner likewise thing although seeme different conioyned martch together feare flyeth hope wonder thereat passion proc ed inconstant moueable minde thought care come greatest cause one moderate selues content selues thing present send thought farre v prouidence greatest benefit betideth mortall men becommeth hurtfull harmeful vnto v brute beast flie danger see eye hauing escaped present securitie extinguisheth memory fear affrighted onely danger past also come many good harme v memorie reuiueth representeth vnto v torment feare past prouidence anticipateth man miserable alone present euils epist vi declareth argument profiteth philosophie acknowledgeth vice expresseth affection communicate thing true friend especially profitable counsaile wisemen seemeth verie effectuall aboue precept teacheth example philosopher know lucilius onely amended transfigured reformed eyther vaunt selfe suppose remaineth thing may amended know many thing ought corrected extenuated wholly lifted vp euen testimonie mind beginneth changed better knoweth selfe vice time ignorant hope seazed certaine sickness feele themselues diseased would therefore communicate thee sudden change made begin haue certaine confidence friendship true friendship meane neyther hope feare neyther consideration particular profit distroyne men die die reckon vp vnto thee diuers men haue want friend want friendship thing cannot happen two soules coupled together strict alliance vniformitie desiring honest thing knowe thing common vnto chiefly aduersitie thou canst coniecture thy minde much profit perceiue euery day bringeth send sayeth thou thing whose efficacie haue tried truely could wish might sort poure thee glad learne end may teach thing rare commodious soeuer yeeld content might know partcular profit wisedome selfe giuen vpon condition conceale publish would refuse possession benefit contenting without companion send thee therefore bookes themselues lest thou shouldest take much paine following thing profite publikely put certaine markes finde thing quickly proue admire yet speaking liuing together profit thee onely reading therefore behooueth thee transport thy selfe hither first men giue better credit eye eares againe way precept long example short far fruitful cleanthes neuer expressed zeno onely heard alwaies conuersant eye secret studie warily obserued whether liued according taught plato aristotle sage afterwards spread themselues diuers family haue receiued instruction manner word socrates metrodorus hermacus poliaemus great men frequented schoole epicurus conuersed call thee onely vnto intent thou shouldest receiue profit end thou shouldest profit others continually assist one another mean acquit selfe rent owe thee tell thee pleased day hecaton askest thou saith wherein haue profited haue begun friend selfe hath gotten much neuer alone know friend himselfe friend men epist vii proficient much company anoyded vice contracted thereby playes showes also chiefely bloodie neyther beseeming publikely recite dispute amongst vnequals let saith hee one two ditors iudgement esteemed none wilt thou know iudgement thou oughtest especially flie multitude yet thou canst safely commit thy selfe vnto mine owne part confesse weakenesse neuer returne backe againe manner carried somewhat composed troubled somewhat thing chased away returne h backe againe vnawares befalleth sicke sort attainted long debility neuer remoued except grow worse fareth v whose spirit begin recouer long sicknesse conuersation people contrarie vnto v euery one lendeth v staine imprinteth v leaueth impression v ore beware greater companie wherewith conuerse greater danger nothing hurtfull good manner sit theatre pleasure conceiue vice steale v easily thinkest thou say tell thee onely returne couetous ambitious luxurious cruell inhumane haue beene amongst men casualtie fell vpon showes noone exspecting sport wittie jest recreation whereby men eye might reposed awhile morning beene fedde shedding men bloud finde contrarie whatsoeuer fought mercie letting passe trifle nothing detested murther combatant haue wherewith couer expose naked body stroake neuer strike without wounding spectacle doe many preferre ordinarie couple extraordinarie asked people preferre weapon kept neyther helmet target whereto serue fencing gladiatorie art delayes death morning men exposed lion bear noone spectator killer commanded set kill reserue conqueror another slaughter end ayme fight death fire sword matter managed done intermission spectacle man hath committed theft therefore deserueth hanged slew man slew deserned suffer lesse hast thou deserued behold spectacle kill burn whip runnes fearfully weapon killes couragiously dy willingly stroakes compelled wound naked exposed body receiue stroakes one another spectacle intermitted meane time men slaine lest nothing done go vnderstand euill example reflecteth doe giue thankes vnto immortall god teach cruell cannot learn tender mind little apprehensiue truth withdrawn common people easie find many frequentation different multitude might peraduenture haue shaken great mindes socrates cato laelius farre v though height composed iudgement able sustaine force charge vice comming great troupe one onely example lust auarice causeth much mischiefe companie delicate man little little effeminateth conuerse rich neighbour kindleth couetousnesse mischieuous corrupt man rubbeth rust infirmity soileth simple vprightest man thinkest thou befall world flocketh approacheth publikely force must thou eyther imitate hate one ought auoyded feare lest thou eyther like vnto wicked reason manie enemie diuers vnlike thee retire thy selfe therefore thy selfe haunt make thee better admit thou canst better thing reciprocally done men teaching others learne themselues aboue thing beware lest thou expose thy selfe great assembly affectest dispute teach way ostentation desire shew thy selfe could well thou shouldest doe thou couldest sort profitable people one amongst vnderstand thee happ ly thou finde one two yet must thou instruct may vnderstand thee wilt thou aske haue learned thing feare thou hast lost thy labour thou hast learned thing thy selfe lest reserue vnto selfe profit haue gotten day communicate thee three worthy sentence one sense one shal acquit epistle oweth thee two shall giuen thee aforehand democritus saith co nt one onely whole multitude whole multitude one whosoeuer doubted author demaunded tooke great paine preferre arte profit answered wisely saith suffice one enough none enough third excellent epicurus writing one consort study thing saith write manie thy selfe selues theatre great enough one another su h thing friend lucilius thou must commit memorie end contemne pleasure proceedeth reputation consent diuers praysed manie cause findest thou reioyce thou diuers esteme thee let see thy good within thee epist viii present dependeth former epistle obiection wilt thou auoyde multitude people thy stoicks teach follow businesse die affaire answereth perswadeth idlenesse retirement example dismissing office intendeth wisedome propagateth precept thereof writing saith action greatest excellent conclusion inserteth epicvrvs philosophie giueth true libertie thou commaundest thy aduice flie people retire selfe apart contented conscience shall becom precept thine commanded end life action seeme interim intertaine idlenesse end haue withdrawne selfe intent haue shut vp doores might profit many men spend day idlenesse yea part night spend udie maintayning forcing mine eye sleepe retired selfe onely affaire principally mine owne particular wholly traffique posteritie writi g may profitable vnto set eye writing many good wholsome counsailes receipt profitable medicine haue found fruitfull mine owne vlcers although altogether healed haue desisted fester shew others right way haue learned late haue beene long wearied wandring tracing heere cease crie flie thing eyther please common sort casualtie attributeth runne casuall benefites rather suspiciously fearfully apprehend intertaine vncertaine pleasure wilde beast fish bewitched baite laid thinke giftes fortune trust mee lying waite one soeuer v would liue sweet life let flie much may lim benefit wherein miserably deceiued think enjoy enjoy v course carrieth v fall issue life eminent fall worse impossible v stand elicitie hath begunne transport v carrie v hither thither least wise eyther content thy selfe thing good certaine thou possessor lord thy selfe doe fortune doth ouerturne casteth headlong crusheth remember therefore obserue wholsom fruitfull forme life affoording thy body nourishment may suffice continue thee good health chastise seuerely lest rebell soule let thy meat appease thy hunger thy drinke asswage thy thirst thy coat couer thee cold thy house defence thing may offend thy bodie skilleth whether builded turfe rich marble know man well couered thatch golde contemne thing superfluous labour preferreth eyther shew ornament thinke nothing admi able thy selfe thy minde nothing great euen selfe great discourse selfe conferre posteritie thinkest thou profit vpon demaund passe bond friend set hand seale testimonie testament giue hand suffrage candidate senate house beleeue seeme least doe greatest thing intreat diuine humane matter high time make end pay impost owe epistle shall mine owne expence epicurus charge day read sentence thou must necessitie serue philosophie end thou mayest obtaine true libertie hee submitteth subiecteth himselfe instant made freeman serue libertie thou wilt thinke strange peraduenture vsurpe often epicure word rather men wherefore thinkest thou saying common publique manie thing poet haue written haue beene ought spoken philosopher mention tragedian poem called togatae haue also seuerity mean betwixt comedy tragedy many eloquent verse vse euen amongst cynicks many thing publius exceed commodies worthy inserted tragedy repeat one verse appertaineth philosophie part last debated wherein denieth ought account casuall thing owne thing forraine befals wishing remember verse likewise thine much better succinct thine fortune made thine neyther let slip likewise farre better set downe thee good might giuen may bereft require acquittance pay thee thine owne epist ix part explication also former wiseman seeketh men contented himselfe friend also yea likewise without lose hauing lost repaire againe himselfe fruit pleasure whilst prouideth owne cause epicure thinke rather another may profit may vndergo danger may die reward vertue selfe length copiously subtilly farre content himselfe farre word stoicall distinction thou desirest know whether vpon iust ground epicure certaine epistle reprehendeth say hee perfectly wise content himselfe cause hath neede friend obiected epicure lpho think impassibilitie mind chiefest good shall fall ambiguitie shall striue significantly expresse greeke word nonlatin alphabet one word call impatience contrarie would expresse may vnderstood intend despiseth sense euill let conceiued endure euill see therefore whether better eyther say inuulnerable mind minde setled beyond patience difference betwixt v wiseman ouercommeth incommoditie whatsoeuer feele h hath much sense thereof accord say wiseman contented himselfe yet notwithstanding haue friend neighbour companion although himselfe sufficeth sort sufficeth sometimes contented part himselfe eyther sickenesse enemie hath taken hand accident hath bereft eye remaineth shall su fice ioyfull shall maimed mangled bodie hee could whole rather wanted nothing neuerthelesse desireth wanteth thus wiseman farre content himselfe without friend much say beareth patiently losse friend without friend shall neuer lyeth power repaire soone listeth phidias hauing lost one statue suddenly fashion another good artesan amitie suddenly substituteth another friend place lost thou demandest suddenly make repaire many friendship tell thee first agreed betweene v remain acquit debt letter shew thee saith hecaton mean increase loue without medicine hearb inchantment thou wilt beloued loue pleasure fruition old ancient amitie likewise creation new difference hath friend alreadie gotten getting laborer oweth reapeth attalus philosopher wont say farre pleasant thing make friend haue friend agreeable painter paint haue finished picture attention applyeth worke hath selfe sweetnesse cannot partaker hath set last hand labour hee hath painted possesseth fruit art tooke pleasure arte selfe painted youth child fruitfull vnto v infancie sweet returne purpose wiseman although content himselfe notwithstanding haue friend end exercise amitie endure great vertue remaine without vse epicurus said epistle haue one assist sicke succour prison necessitie contrariwise end may haue one may assist succour sicke relieue ransome need captiuitie hath euill intention onely respecteth himselfe maketh friendship shal end friendship euen began hath purchased himselfe friend intent may succoured prison take flight soone feeleth himselfe deliuered bond kindes friendship common sort call temporarie made friend profit sake shall please long may profitable felicitie see themselues inuironed multitude friend distressed make abode nothing solitude manner friend flie place shall bee proued thence see many wicked example som forsaking feare betraying feare necessarie beginning end haue correspondence hath begun friend expedient hath thought gaine friendship beside selfe may well induced suborned offer greater gaine cause doe entertaine friend end haue one may die may accompanie banishment whose life preseruation may expose selfe danger death onely regardest profit makest account may yeelde thee commoditie rather traffique friendship certaine friendship hath sort similitude likenesse affection louers vnfitly may man call passion foolish amitie scope loue neyther gaine ambition neyther glorie despising consideration himselfe hee kindleth soules desire beloued forme vnder hope mutuall reciprocall amitie dare say vicious habitude produced cause honest thou wilt say vnto friendship desired thing selfe behoueth wiseman contented himselfe follow consideration honest soeuer beautie remaineth abatement maiestie dignitie thereof obtaine respect answere thee friend lucilius say wiseman contented himselfe badly interpreted diuers men exclude euery way wiseman euery place inclose within himselfe must distinguish farre word extendeth wiseman contented himselfe liue happely liue diuers thing requsit needeth intire erected minde despiseth fortune shew thee chrysippus distinguisheth saith wiseman wanteth nothing yet hath neede many thing foole hath neede nothing make vse nothing wanteth thing wiseman hath neede hand eies diuers part ordinarie v life yet neuerthelesse wanteth nothing haue neede importeth necessitie wise nothing necessarie thus although content himselfe yet desisteth make vse friend desireth haue regard hath need liue happily liue happily without friend soueraigne good seeketh externall instrument wholly accomplished selfe beginneth bee subiect vnto fortune f haue neede seeke part selfe selfe yet shall wisemans life left prison without friend strange country abandoned world retained som long nauigation cast desert vnknowne shoare euen iupiter dissolution world confused mixture god one nature thing beginning cease little little reposeth himselfe retireth himselfe himselfe giuen ouer owne thought like doth wiseman hidden himselfe himselfe whilst lawfull order affaire contented himselfe marrieth wife contented himselfe bringeth vp child hee content himselfe yet would liue liue without mankinde pro naturall instinct inciteth entertain friendship thing haue certaine bred sweetnesse haue friendship euen solitude odious companie agreeable euen nature associateth man man likewise certaine instinct maketh v desirous friendship notwithstanding although affectionate friend although equall oftentimes preferre himselfe yet shall good inclosed bounded within himselfe shall speake stilpon meane epicurus disputed epistle hauing vpon surprisall taking cittie wherein liued lost wife child himselfe left desolate yet neuertheles happie content deliuered publique ruine desolation demetrius surnamed poliorcetes say destroyer citties demanded lost nothing said haue lost nothing good behold great generous personage victorious ouer victorie owne proper enemie haue saith lost thing compelled doubt whether conqueror good saith say iustice vertue temperance prudence especially thinke nothing good may taken away wonder creature trauerse fire without harme much admirable man without losse harme escaped fire sword ruine doest thou see farre easie conquer whole nation one man voyce common stoicke owne person beareth away good without hurt thorow middest citties burned downe content himselfe himselfe scope owne felicitie thinke alone vtter great generous word epicurus himselfe reprehendeth stilphon hath spoken like effect take good part although haue payed thee day rent alreadie whosoeuer saith supposeth owne sufficient content though lord whole world yet miserable thou thinke better spoken sort must relie sense word hee miserable thinketh himselfe happie although command whole world end thou mayest know sens common nature infuseth generall thou shalt finde cynique poet blest thinkes himselfe preuayleth thee reckoning estate thou art thine owne iudgement seeme abiect mayest thou say vnworthily rich lord ouer diuers men slaue vnto farre calleth himselfe happie shall tell thee thou oughtest regard saith thinketh onely thinketh one day ordinarily doe feare lest vnworthy man enioy great good one wiseman good yeeld pleasure follie laboureth loathing selfe epist x solitude good good haue profited goodnesse others otherwise wicked foolish men commit sinne therein remoued reformer left themselues way precept vowes ought conceiue thing except durst make knowne euerie man change mine opinion counsaile thee flie great assembly yea least least onely frequentation one alone finde man would haue thee converse consider little iudgement haue thee dare well trust thy selfe thy selfe cra e auditor stilpon made mention former epistle perceiued young man walking apart himselfe asked alone speake said young man vnto selfe take heed pray thee replyed crate thou speake wicked man accustomed obserue mourne feare retire themselues apart feare lest abuse solitude imprudent man ought left alone time complot deuise euill designes studie effect euill intent themselues others dispose vnlawfull desire time minde discouereth publisheth time feare shame enforced conceale animate boldnesse quicken lust awaken choler conclude onely good solitude hath selfe commit nothing man feare reuealer lost foole discouereth betrayeth himselfe consider thou hope rather promise selfe thee hope word vncertaine good finde man could better finde hart thou shouldst conuersant thy selfe called remembrance high generous discourse haue heard thee vtter congratulate selfe said word onely wordes haue foundation man vulgar tendeth safetie continue friend lucilius speake alwayes manner liue continually thus one thing abase thee neyther master thy courage giue thankes vnto god auncient vowes thou hast made vnto recommend vnto new thou hast conceiued aske hand good mind first pray vnto health thy spirit next thy bodie shouldest thou oftentimes make vowes vnto boldly beseech god since thou intendest aske nothing another man end according custome may accompany letter mine present receiue haue found day athenodorus know thou art disburdened euill desire thou hast attained farre thou demand nothing god hand may required openly great day madnesse men mumble betwixt teeth vileinous prayer suddenly silent man yeeld eare vnto supposing hide men ashamed discouer vnto god iudge precept profitable liue men god saw thee speake god men heare thee epist xi hoped well lvcilivs friend appeared much shamefastnesse blushing sometimes naturall cannot shaken precept followeth wiseman also somtimes appeareth euill men signe euill citeth wholsome admonition epicvrvs ought alwayes represent vnto selues good man might restraine v tutor doe speake thing present honest natured man thy friend hath spoken first word vttered incontinently testified vnto great hurt good spirit much profited study enterprised left taste whereunto assure selfe answer haue taken vpon sudden hath spoken vnto without preparation recollected himselfe easily blushed good signe young man yea blushed could moderate doubt shall best retired despoyled vice complexion accompanie yea euen perfect wisedome hath possessed vice connaturall eyther minde bodie cannot wholly defaced industrie borne v may sweetned corrected arte neyther mastered rooted hath bin noted assured men world time presented themselues great assembly discourse thing lesse troubled cold sweat wearie pant trauell knee tremble others teeth chatter tongue varies lip simper neyther discipline vse wholly take imperfection nature exerciseth force herein admonisheth one defect weakenesse know blushing bee numbred amongst thing ofttimes wee obserue spreadeth selfe flusheth euen face grauest men yet apparent young men haue heate soft nature notwithstanding eldest exempt ame neuer much feared blush instant lauished shamefastnesse sylla violent face redde nothing soft pompeis countenance neuer spake solemne companie without blushing remember fabianus much summoned senate depose certain matter herein blushing marueilously become happeneth thorow feeblenesse mind rather noueltie accident although shake yet moueth accustomed exercised na urall facilitie tendernesse bodie subiect blushing th haue bloud good well rempered othersome haue moueable readie flush vp face wisedome haue said take away infirmitie otherwise nature selfe subiect therunto wisedome power raze vice imprinted v attendeth v thorow condition birth temperature body mind hath much long time composed self remain continually cannot eschue thing pleasure command come commedians imitate affection expresse feare trembling represent sorrow accustomed counterfeit shamefastnesse manner cast downe countenance speak softly fix eye ground blush cannot blushing may n yther prohibited commanded wisedome promiseth nothing thing profiteth nothing thing receiue law themselues come wils depart without asking leaue epistle requireth clausuall receiue precept necessarie behouefull thee wish thee cause greatest part sinnes taken away witnesse alwayes present would offend let minde therfore propose vnto selfe personage respecteth whose authoritie shee may make secret holy religious happie onely reformeth action thought happie respect one sort onely remembrance reforme minde respect sort shall suddenly made worthie respected himselfe choose therefore cato seeme vnto thee ouersharp seuere choose l lius facile sweet choose whose life wordes shall agreeable vnto thee fixing alwayes thine eye minde countenance take eyther thy guide thine example behoueth v haue one according whose maners may conforme thing depraued corrected rule epist xii pleasantly discourseth olde age sheweth admonished thereof countreyhouse admonished without griefe olde age must tedious pleasant lesse subiect vice life short whatsoeuer made vse hand laide thereon let v daily say thinke haue liued side soeuer turne selfe perceiue proofes mine olde age repaired lately countreyfarme adioyneth cittie complayned daily expence reparation bayliffe keeping thereof answered fault alleaging done best could building ouerolde ruinous yet notwithstanding selfe builded leaue thee iudge mee since stone mine age decay much antiquitie touched herewith tooke occasion displeased vpon euery first thing encountreth walke well appeareth said hese plane tree well laboured altogether leauelesse boughes knottie withered stockes couered mosse filthinesse would happen man digged watred ought sweareth genius doth vttermost indeuour hath neglected manner tree olde remembred selfe planted mine owne hand seene beare first leafe turning selfe doore decrepit fellow said age left gate dead body wont looketh outward whence came pleasure hast thou carrie forth carkasse strange man knowest thou saith felicio thou wert wont bring childish gift sonne philo itus thy bayliffe thy playfellow vndoubtedly said man doateth darling become infant vndoubtedly may almost toothlesse owe farme olde age appeareth vnto way soeuer turne selfe let v embrace loue wholly replenished agreeable delight man know make vse apple neuer good begin wither ripen infancie must agreeable end thereof delight carrowsing last draught pleasant drowneth wine consummateth drunkennesse whatsoeuer contenting pleasure hath contained selfe deferred till end age declineth also agreeable yet wholly decr pit spent neyther iudge age without particular pleasure whose foote almost graue thus succeedeth place pleasure needeth none sweet pleasant thing see man selfe discharged couetousnesse thou mayest say tedious thing haue death alwayes man eye first ought well presented yong olde man eye called censor according estate none old hopeth liue least one day longer one day degree life age consist th manie part spheare hath diu r circle one inclosed within one incloseth comprehendeth rest natiuity vntill death another excludeth yeares youth another containeth childhood succeedeth yeare incloseth time multiplication whereof life composed circle yeare moneth moneth day least yet notwithstanding hath beginning end rise set cause heraclitus called scotinus reason obscuritie speech said one day like another hath interpreted another manner wit one day like number houres said true day time foure twentie houres necessarie alike night hath day hath lost another said one day like reason conformitie resemblance nothing space long time thou shalt finde one day light night turnes returnes heauens shortnesse length night make thing plainely appeare therefore ought dispose euery day sort leade vp rereward time consummate liues pa uius vsurped ouer syria buried euening buried wine meates hee caused richly sumptuously prepared himselefe solemnized owne obsequies caused himselfe transported banquet bedde manner amidst dance clapping hand curtezans sung musique hath liued hath liued day ouerpassed head wherein buried himselfe manner euill conscience let v performe good addressing selues rest let v ioyfully contentedly say haue liued ended course fortune gaue god vouchsafe v next morrow let v receiue thanksgiuing thricehappie assuredly possessed himselfe expecteth next day without care whosoeuer hath said haue liued doth daily rise profite must close letter sayest thou shall come without present doe feare shall bring somwhat said somewhat great deale excellent sentence bringeth vnto thee euill thou wilt say word epicurus hast thou another man true mine perseuer vrge epicurus vnto thee sweare consent word consider spoken let know thing best common epist xiii excellently informeth casualty rageth especially aduiseth v tormented eare thing come weth vncertaine may fall concludeth therefore feare tempered hope addeth full farre confidency doe teach thing come god good know thou hast much courage instructed thee wholsom precept subdue aduersitie thou wert contented enough exercise thy selfe fortune hast assured thy selfe also farre since thou hast made tryall thy force grapled hand hand neuer giue assured proofe themselues many difficulty shall appeare euery side yea sometimes neerely assault like manner true mind subiect selfe men wils approueth selfe touch stone wrestler cannot enter list vndaunted courage hath neuer beene sharpely encountred beaten hath oftentimes seene bloud shed whose teeth haue ne shattered fist h hauing beene ouerthrowne hath made enemie lose footing cast downe hath lost courage oftentimes hath oyled recouered new footing became fell furious say entreth fielde greatest assurance persist similitude fortune hath oftentimes aboue thee yet hast thou neuer time yeelded thy selfe prisoner hast alwayes restored thy selfe made head courage alacritie truth also generous mind getteth ordinarily aduantage prouoked notwithstanding thou thinkest good accept force strengthen defence thy selfe diuers thing lucilius feare th n hurt v oftentimes troubled opinion eff ct reason th e time stoicall language somewhat submisly vulgarly say thing cause v feares gronings light contemptible let v omit great word yet notwithstanding true onely admonish thee make thy selfe miserable thy time fearing thing wholly neere vnto thee happily neuer befall thee leastwise yet happened somethings therefore doe afflict v ought ought othersome torment v eyther augment euill presuppose imagine selues vpon ground first matter controuersie plea alreadie recorded let v deferre present terme light thou contendest grieuous know doe laugh torture others groane little stroake afterwards shall see whether thing valued owne force weakenesse first graunt oftentimes thou shalt amongst men shall endeuour perswade thee thou art miserable thou wilt grow consideration thy selfe thou hearest thou feelest consult first al thy patience ask thou thy selfe better know tha toucheth thee thy sel speake vnto thy selfe thus men lament fortune tremble feared gion misfortune attaint torment infamous dan erous enquire thy selfe ner perplexed sorrow without cause make euill sayest thou hall vnderstand whether thing feare yther v ne true take rule discerne eyther present future terrifie v iudgement present facile bodie free healthfull without griefe caused iniurie done vnto thee shall see shall happen hereafter day thou hast neede complain come first consider whether certaine argum nt thy future misfortune part troubled suspicion affrighted illusion common report accustomed end whole warres much particular men vndoubtedly friend lucilius quickly conceited ouerruled common opinion checke thing cause feares neyther shake tremble thereat turne back like cloude dust raised triumphing troupe beast putteth flight dismayed report runneth abroad hath neyther ground author mishap know commeth passe false fained thing doe trouble v farre true true haue certain measure others deliuered v wandring coniecture license fearefull minde alreadie affrighted whence happeneth dismayes pernicious irremediable mad distracted rest without reason without minde let v diligently inquire vpon businesse likely mischance happen straightwayes true many vnexpected thing haue chanced manie expected neuer came passe put case happen helpeth meet man sorrow shal partake pain ouertimely commeth meane let v promise selues better successe leastwise shall much good time gotten againe many thing may fall meanes whereof danger shall yea almost borne v eyther shall subsist wholly passe away happily shall diuerted another man head ofttimes flame haue broken giuen passage thorow middest furie auoyde themselues one hath falne top house softly layde hee light ground sometimes exposed last punishment hath beene saued euen verie attempt execution haue suruiued burie haue beene hangman euill fortune selfe neuer without inconstancie leuitie may mischance shall come may shall come meane come least propose vnto thy selfe better fortune may befall thee contrariwise happeneth sometimes euen appearance euill presage minde faineth selfe false imagination interpreteth word doubtfull signification worst proposeth selfe indignation displeasure som one greater dreameth much hee incensed much may prouoked occasion liuing end miserie man feare much may feare behoueth contrariwise reiect contemne feare self attended euerie way apparant occasion herein prudence force ou vn anding ought principally serue wise sitteth v one vice another temp hope certaine man may hat also cer ine thing feared may vanish hoped deceiue balance therefor th thy hope doubt side beleeue keth thee thou co ldest desire fall although thou lt haue probable appearance feare notwithstanding
