tender affection beare vnto disquieteth v fear chargeth v diuers thought exposeth subiecteth v disgrace honestie base maketh much account bodie reason kept carefully yet reason honour faith requireth man ready cast middest fire let v flie notwithstanding much v lieth onely danger incommodities let v secure selues retire v place securitie thinking hourely mean may separate v thing feared deceiue selfe three sort feare pouertie feare sickenesse feare thing may befall v thorow violence mightie three one thing shaketh v hangeth ouer v another man greatnesse commeth great noyce tumult naturall hast thine enemy wiseman therefore n uer prouoke displeasure mightie rather decline sort sayling marrin r shunneth storm thou shippedst sicily thou diddest cut ouer sea vnaduised master thy ship contemned threatning south rnly windes winde exasperateth sicilian sea driueth shoales whirlpooles shapeth course left shoare sayleth shoare neerer charibdis skilfull would haue enquired countrey embarqued himsel e nature sea signes cloudes imported held course farre aloofe dangerous place whirlepools like sort doth wiseman flyeth may hurt hauing especiall regard seeme flie greatest part securitie consisteth make show appeareance search thing man flieth condemneth must therefore looke v may secure common sort wee shal bring passe first couet thing set competitor together eares haue thing appearance profit may make v subiect treachery also counsaile thee thou haue thing thy bodie thou mayest spoyled man thirsteth man bloud onely leastwise greater sort rather hunt prize life naked man walketh freely thief dangerous passage poore man findeth man bid stand afterwards behooueth thee according auncient precept endeuour thy selfe auoyde three thing hated enuied despised wisedome onely shew v may affected otherwise hard thing much feared lest distrust enuie bring v contempt lest whilst trod vpon seeme able trod hath beene cause much feare mani hauing power feared let v euery way retire selues lesse harmefull contemned admired let v therefore haue recourse vnto philosophie instruction wherof shall markes dignitie vnto v onely good men also indifferently euill eloquence profession tend moue common sort haue aduersarie peaceable retired intermixeth selfe nothing selfe neyther contemned respected artes yea consent wicked neuer shall vice obtaine great force neuer shall conspire much vertue name philosophie shall alwaies remaine holy venerable yet must philosophie selfe moderately peaceably handled true happily thou wilt obiect vnto marcus cato hath handled modestie perswaded himselfe might represse onely counsailes heate ciuill warres thrust himselfe amidst army two displeased inraged prince whereas displeased pompey som caesar feared offend answer thee may debated whether time wisely done busie himselfe publique affaire pretendest thou doe cato title libertie question long time troden vnder foot question onely whether two eyther caesar pompey shall bee master commonweale haddest thou doe quarrell thou haddest part herein question choose soueraigne could auaile thee conquered better cannot conquer hee may worst shall subdued cannot better getteth masterie haue touched last part catoes life neyther former yeares euer conuenient wiseman intermeddle commonweale already exposed pray thing exclaime cast vnprofitable speech whilst people taking vp playde like football spit face drew perforce place senatehouse ledde vnto prison shall see hereafter whether wiseman ought imploy labor place vtterly lost meane recall thee hese stoicks excluded commonweale retired themselues reform men liues make lawes mankinde without incurring indignation mightie vndoubtedly expedient wiseman behaue himselfe thus goe trouble publique customes cause himselfe pointed strangenesse life shall followeth course wholly safe secured may man promise health temperate man yet temperance entertaineth causeth hath beene seene sometimes ship haue beene lost hauen danger greater saile maine sea much hand danger intermedleth manie affaire complotteth cannot assure himselfe solitude innocent sometimes condemned faultie farre often arte costeth deare harmed verie ornament arte finally wiseman regardeth expedient euery thing successe deliberation hand fortune disposeth euents whose iudgement wise man neuer submitteth himselfe yet bring vexation aduersitie thiefe condemned killeth perceiue thou stretchest thy hand receiue rent letter bring thee pay thee golde see thou vse fruition may gratefull vnto thee possesseth rich least needeth tell thou wilt say short sufficeth running leaping carriage bodie intention voyce clause epicure end life deferred content thee present auncients custome hath obserued yet time begin letter word thou art health well mine owne part healthie thinke say well begin thus thou attendest thy philosophy glad truth health without minde sicke bodie also notwithstanding strong able otherwise healthie man might say bodie one madde troubled frensie haue care therefore especially first health afterwards second cost thee much thou behaue thy selfe wisely vnseemely thing man trauelleth obtaine wisedom imploy himselfe exercising armes feed himselfe fat strengthen side thou shalt make thy selfe fleshy brawny vttermost thou canst imagine yet neyther force waight shalt thou equall fat growne oxe besides mind choaked vp great charge thy bodie farre lesse agile quicke conceit containe therefore restraine thy bodie thou mayest end thou mayest giue fayrer spacious place harbor vnto thy minde ouercarefull draw diuers incommodities first trauell exercise spendeth spirit disableth apprehend studie secret hidden secret leade traine dangerous reuolts debauchments foule vilainous custome men occupied betweene wine oyle whose opinion day happily passed haue sweat well stead exhaled sweat haue anew replenished emptie stomacks store another liquor drinke sweat life sicke cardiacque conuersions stomacke certaine kindes exercise easie short loose supple body without great losse time ought haue principall regard runne dance leap vault choose thou wilt vse make easie vnto thee whensoeuer thou dost retire suddenly thy bodie thy minde exercise day night shee nourished entertained little labour neyther cold heat hinder exercise olde age selfe trauell therefore carefully good bettered waxing olde yet alwayes thou hang ouer thy booke thy hand continually labouring thy table must intermission granted minde yet giuen ouer altogether remitted onely carriage man litter otherwise stirreth bodie hindereth studie thou mayest reade dictate speake heare also walking contemne also eleuation thy voyce forbid thee raise certaine degree manner afterwards depresse againe thou wilt learne thou shouldest walke admit hunger hath taught new cunning temper thy pace obserue thy mouth thou eatest proceede farre leuitie thy patience thou shalt giue way boldnesse shall thy voyce discourse begin clamorous accent entrance violently enforced vndoubtedly thing naturall raise voyce little little pleade ordinarily accustomed begin discourse humble submisse manner prosecute liuely lowder accent man first imploreth mercie iudges howsoeuer therefore force thy minde shall perswade thee sometimes exclaime vice vehemently sometime moderately according thy voyce force shall enable thee thou hast humbled drawne lower straine pitch let fall faile let tempered according abilitie discretion speaker breake ru icke vnciuill manner intention exercise voyce minde voyce exercise v haue disburthened thee small businesse requitall shall take paine beholde last day next neighbour last epist xvi philosophie necessarie life true onely action proficient dispose thine action counsa le skilleth whether ate fortune philosophie teacheth obey god contemne fortune casualty clause likewise epicvrvs liueth according nature rich despise opinion know friend lucilius thou perfectly vnderstandest man liue happily nay scarcely tollerably without studie wisedome life made happie perfection tollerable onely beginning sufficeth onely thou know behooueth thee also imprint thy soule assure continuall cotemplation lesse propose thing honest conserue man hath proposed himselfe must perseuer continuall diligence adde strength till good may become habituall good minde thou needest therefore court many affirmatiue long discourse know thou hast profited much know minde thing thou writest proceed neyther fained disguised yet tell thee freely mine opinion haue alreadie hope thee yet entire assurance thou wilt beleeue thou shalt conceiue otherwise thy selfe beleeue thy selfe suddenly easily sound obserue thy selfe aboue thing se whether thou hast profited eyther thy science thy life selfe philosophie vulgar craft neyther ostentation consisteth wordes deedes must made vse passe time withall extinguish tediousnesse idlenesse formeth conformeth minde disposeth life guideth action sheweth v wee ought eyther flie follow guideth helme directeth course saile amidst shoales rockes life without man assured daily hourely fall innumerable thing require counsel man may receiue selfe som one may say whereto serueth philosophie destinie god ruleth thing fortune commandeth ouer men thing certaine cannot changed vncertaine prouision may made god hath preoccupated al deliberation men alreadie hath determined ought done fortune permitteth nothing vnto counsaile whatsoeuer must lucilius intend philosophie whether destinie detaine v captiues irreuocable lawes god gouernor world disposeth thing fortune confusedly enforceth altereth humane affair philosophie must retreat exhort v obey god willingly resist fortune constantly teach v follow god beare casualty ar call question whether haue interest whether prouidence power whether fate ineuitable bondes draweth v subiection sudden casuall power absolute mistris returne exhort thee suffer thy selfe waxe colde permit heate constancie thy minde weakened entertaine sort viuacitie agilitie present contained therin may grow habitude thy infancie haue knowne thee well thou hast fixed thine eie present letter importeth peruse well thou shall finde thou needest maruaile continue still liberall men good yet others well said whomsoeuer spoken may tearme mine owne epicurus saith thou liuest according nature thou shalt neuer poore according opinion thou shalt neuer rich nature hath neede little opinion infinite thou lord wealth many mightie men doe possesse fortune enricheth thee beyond measure priuate man although couer thee golde cloath thee purple bring thee height delight rich thou mayest couer earth marble mightest onely possesse rich treade adde herevnto moreouer picture statue else soeuer arte engine hath inuented thou shalt learne couet alwayes naturall desire limited deriued false opinion haue end limit false ground goeth right way end error infinite retire thy selfe therefore vaine thing thou wouldest know whether thou askest haue naturall blinde desire consider whether may rest neerer thou approachest farther daily flieth thee assured according nature epist xvii philosphie deferred thing laide aside embraced shall poore wished thou shalt play philosopher freely nature desireth little shall wanting clause accounteth pouertie grieuous rich likewise burthensome defect minde cast away thing thou beest wise rather ende thou mayest wise addresse thy selfe speedily thy power get good minde thing detaine thee eyther vnbinde thee also bond breake thou wilt say hindered home affaire take course reuenue may maintain without thing end pouertie may hinderance whilst thou sayest thou seemest know power strength thing whereof thou thinkest thou seest generally summe much philosophie profitable thee thou doest subtilly examine part neither knowest thou yet much helpeth v sort may succor v great affaire may vse tully word sort shee assisteth v great thing applieth selfe lesse thing beleeue take aduice counsell thee busie thy selfe thine account thou searchest exempt thy selfe pouertie wilt thou say desireable rich haue hindered many men studying philosophie pouertie alwayes free alwayes safe enemy trumpet soundeth poore man knowes well al rum threatneth surprise yeelding vp towne lost take care get away carrie must need make voyage sea man attendeth entrance launching forth hath great troupe seruants attend must needes nourish vpon fertilitie forraine countrey easie fill belly well taught desire filled costeth little appease hunger dainty mouth much pouertie contented satisfaction supplie necessitie wilt thou refuse make thy companion whose manner richest themselues doe imitate thou desirest en oy freedome thy minde eyther behooueth thee poore like poore man man cannot profit studie without care frugalitie voluntarie pouertie lay apart excuse say thou hast yet thou hast neede thou mightest compasse summe thou wouldest retire thy selfe world consecrate thy selfe wholly vnto philosophie contrariwise ought especially sough thou deferrest seekest attaine last thou oughtest begin sayest thou recouer whereupon liue learne afterwards thou oughtest get thing hinder thee liuing well nothing hindereth thee dying well reason pouerty recall v philosophie necessitie selfe ought behalfe endure hunger diuers men haue voluntarily endured siege onely price patience yeelde selfe discretion conquerour much great perpetuall libertie promised assurance neyther affrighted god man sometimes hunger enforceth v whole army haue su fered extreame necessitie yea great feede vpon rootes hearbes support horrible famine suffered make wonder get kingdome strange another man seruice doubt endure pouertie free minde madnes needeth preparation maintenance hand man may attaine vnto philosophie without prouision supply touching thy selfe thou wilt attaine therevnto thing thou esteemest last instrument life speake aptly accession contrariwise whether thou hast thing apply thy selfe vnto whence mayest thou know whether alreadie thou hast much thou hast nothing seeke rather thing feare want necessarie supplyes nature contented little let wiseman accommodate himselfe happily extreame necessitie doe surcharge shall escape life shall cease troublesome himselfe haue wherewith weare prolong take good part endeuour himselfe thing necessarie bestow bellie backe appertaineth vnto content himselfe shall laugh occupation rich going coming sweat get rich shall say end searchest thou longer way wherefore expectest thou gain thy vsurie succession olde man profit merchandize thou canst become rich suddenly concerneth thee recouer wisdome pay thee hand giueth rich whomsoeuer maketh seeme superfluous good payment another man thine part thou art rich discharge thy selfe therefore thou hast much euery age shalt thou finde sufficient might place end letter taught thee euill custome man may salute king parthia without present thee man may bid adiew gratis therefore borrow epicurus pay thee manie obtayning rich hath beene end change miserie hereat wonder vice thing themselues minde occasion made rich tedious made pouertie grieuous euen one put sicke man bedde wood bed golde place soeuer remoued beareth alwaies griefe like manner difference thrust sicke mind rich pouertie euill alwayes followeth epist xviii wiseman temperately ehaueth himselfe publique ryots tainted little nothing manner howsoeuer profitable dayes abstaine spare resemble poore sore exercise trie pouertie come clause rom epicvrvs wrath assisteth madnesse december moneth wherein cittie much busied euery one publique giueth way lasciuiousnesse eare filled rumour report preparation made ryot time extraordinary difference betwixt saturnals delight little di ference opinion hee seemeth haue way erred saith time past december moneth yeare thee heere would willingly inquire thee thine opinion ought done whether change thing ordinarie custome lest seeme distaste common fashion wee fall frame selues doe men doe wont done time tumult turbulent estate cittie pleasure holydayes sake changed garment knew thee well matter committed thy iudgement neyther wouldest thou permit thing resemble roundcap multitude neyther also euery sort vnlike vnto except happily dayes especially ought command mindes retire themselues abstaine pleasure wherein world disordered receiueth certaine proofe firmitie neyther yeeld su fer selfe transported adulation thing inuite superfluitie matter farre difficult worthie noble mind sober alone time people surfeiteth drunkennesse hath temperance discretion selfe sequester man selfe wholly popularitie neyther particularize himselfe ouermuch neyther intermix himselfe thing manner man may celebrate festiuall day without drunkennesse pleased tempt constancie thy minde according counsailes many great men aduise thee choose certaine dayes wherein thou maye content thy selfe least cheapest dyet mayst cloath thy selfe hard course garment say thy selfe world much feared fulnesse thy securitie let thy mind prepare selfe vnto aduersities fortune iniuries confirme selfe euen height fauours middest peace souldier exerciseth selfe armes skirmish wearieth himselfe superfluous labour end able exercised time requireth thou desirest man eare vpon occurrence exercise hand accident euery moneth exercise themselues imitation pouertie haue profited arre feare pouertie selfe oftentimes ent ained apprehended thinke command thee go somtime take ill supper poore man contenting thy selfe bre win whatsoeuer else whereby luxurie smootheth ouer playe tediousnesse rich aduise thee thy bedde thy apparrell truely poore thy bread stale mouldie thou entertaine ard pittance three foure dayes yea sometimes end may vnto thee pastime proofe belee e e lucilius thou shalt leap ioy satisfied little thou ha vnderstand satisfie selues haue need fortune sufficeth necessitie oweth v spite displeasure yet hast thou reason accomplishing perswade thy selfe thou hast done much doest thou many thousand slaues beggers doe daily honor thou canst giue thy selfe thou doest voluntarily shall easie thee endure alwayes attempt somtimes let v therefore prepare selues casualty lest fortune surprise v vnprouided let v make pouertie familiar vnto v shall assuredly rich know grieuous matter poore master pleasure epicurus certaine dayes wherein sparingly niggardly repressed h hunger proue thing wanting full consummate pleasure much wanted whether thing desert man employ much labour repayring himselfe saith epistle wrote poliaenus charinus magistrate preoccupate weapon fortune begin therefore lucilius follow men customes take dayes thy selfe wherein thou mayest retire thy selfe thine affaire content thy selfe little begin haue conuerse familiarity pouertie olde guest set proude wealth nought make thee worthy god modest thought man worthie god hath contemned rich whose possession debarre thee desire thou mightest possesse without feare one meanes thou shalt obtaine thou canst perswade thy selfe thou mayest liue happily without regard otherwise fleeting benefites thou canst well want let v begin conclude epistle first sayest thou pay thou owest send epicurus pay thee debt immoderate wrath engendreth madnesse true thou must needes know thou hast slaue enemie affection kindleth selfe al men ariseth wel loue hate well amongst serious thing playes pastime neyther skilleth great cause grow kinde minde meeteth matter great fire falleth greatest soundest tymbers haue sustayned great fire againe drie tree apt ired nourish sparkle long therefore sort pray beseech thee thy letter doe import better thing intreat friend hand implore god behalfe withdraw thy selfe thou mayest busie affaire thou canst forcibly deliuer thy selfe haue ouerlong beene prodigall time let v begin age play good husband distastfull thee haue liued stormie ocean let v die quiet harbor yet would aduise thee affect singularitie name thy retirement neyther thou oughtest boast conceale neuer much condemne urie mankinde end thou mayest oyde would haue thee locke thy selfe vp hermitage burie affaire world euerlasting forgetfulnesse behaue thy selfe sort r treat thine apparent eminent shal haue libertie liue according good liking perceiue whether ought wholly hide themselues thine owne part thou mayest vigor thy wit elegancy thy writing thy many great famous alliance haue brought thee forth face world thou art alreadie farre engaged knowledge men though hou wert confined furthermost corner world yet would thy former action discouer themselues thou canst concealed alwayes lu thy former light attend thee whithersoeuer thou retirest thy selfe canst thou settle thy selfe repose without hate man without desire agon e minde shalt thou leaue thou mayest imagine haue forsaken vnwillingly thy client th se one affecteth thee gapeth somewhat thee shall thy friend time past men affected friendship hunt th af er profit art thou afraid older sort abandoned thee chaunge willes consider counterpoize thing pretious libertie cannot purchased deerly finally bethink thy selfe whether thou hadst rather lose either thing belong vnto thee thy self liue haue begun epist xxiiii epistle worthie ranked amongst best exhorteth feare euils come although threaten rather propose happen forme man selfe examining extenuating feares last death contemne reason great men haue done plebeans slaues haue done shouldest thou aspire take visard thing thou fearest paine tender woman hath suffered childbed finally thou art borne bee tossed grieue die acknowledge thy destinie yet epicvrvs precept neither wish death neither feare thou writest vnto thou art disquieted mind euent thy iudgement furie thine enemie doth denounce thee thou thinkest perswade thee propose vnto thy selfe meane time good successe feed thy selfe vaine hope needeth v call anticipate calamity befall v soone lose present good feare euill come vndoubtedly great folly make man selfe miserable present sometimes hereafter must leade thee securitie another way thou wilt disburthen thy selfe care make account whatsoeuer thou fearest shall befall thee alreadie happened euill soeuer measure thy selfe taxe thy feare thereby shalt thou iudge vndoubtedly either thine euill great long neither mayest thou spend much time gathering example conforme thee euery age stored whatsoeuer part affaire either ciuill externall thou fixest thy memorie thou shalt meet wit either proficient wisdome great towardnesse thou condemned worse fortune befall thee banished led prison metellus tooke exile couragiously rutillius also willingly one vouchsafeing returne good commonweale refusing sylla returne dayes nothing denied socrates disputed prison whereas promised flight refused make escape yea remained intent take men feare two dreadfullest thing say imprisonment death mutius thrust hand flame bitter thing burned farre intollerable thou suffer thine owne act thou seest vnlearned man neuer strengthened precept death griefe onely furnished militarie fortitude exacting punishment himselfe frustrated attempt stood looking right hand dropping away enemy fire thou shalt meet men estate fortune age haue cut course misfortune death beleeue lucillius little ought death feared nothing preferred benefit thereof heare therefore securely confidently threat thine enemie although thy conscience make thee confident yet many thing haue credit beside cause hope iust prepare thy selfe iniustice thing remember thou esteeme thing simply despoile tumult bruit accustomably giuen thou shalt find nothing terrible feare thou seest befall yong child befalleth v also greater boyes affraid loue frequent disport euerie day see masked disguised men onely ought take maske thing themselues yeeld true naturall appearance shewest thou sword fire troope grinning hangman thee take away pompe vnder thou liest hidden wherewith thou terrifiest fooles thou art death late slaue handmaiden hath contemned againe shewest thou whippes torment vnder mightie preparation seuerall engine seuerall ioynts fitted torture men thousand instrument plucke man piece lay aside thing astonish v command groanes exclamation irksomenesse cry extorted middest torture vndoubtedly paine goutie man contemneth man sick paine stomacke daintinesse endureth tender woman suffereth childing light endure short suffer tosse thing thy minde thou hast oftentimes heard thou hast often said approue effect thou hast truely said truely heard villainous reproach wont obiected v handle word philosophie workes thinkest thou supposest thou first time death banishment griefe houered ouer thee thou art borne let v thinke thing may bee hereafter done aduise thee surely know thou hast done admonish thee thou drowne thy mind sollicitude dulled haue lesse force thou hast reason raise rouse withdraw priuate cause publike say thou hast mortall fraile bodie forraine iniurie tyranny may onely hurt pleasure thems lues may b transformed torment licacie meates causeth cruditie stomake drunkennesse trembling astonishment sinewes pleasure flesh lust generall deprauation hand foot ioynts become remaineth nothing since good euill equally taken permit place put thee memorie verse thou hast made thinke thou hast written others thy selfe shamefull vnseemely thing speake one thing thinke another odious write one thing thinke another remember thou deb ting sometime place diddest say fall suddenly death little little walke vnto death die daily part life daily scantled also whe encrease life doth decrease haue lost infancie youth man estate briefely time passed vntill present day death v day w liue w diuide death euen hou eglasse last part land falleth onely part discouereth houre also fal e last houre cease onely causeth death consummateth time attaine thither come thereto long thing thou haddest described according thy accustomed stile thou wert alwayes great neuer wittie thou fittedst thy word truth saydest death hath degree first fast attempt rauish v last rather thou shouldest reade thy selfe epistle appear vnto thee death feare last ely suffer perceiue thy bent thou vncapable certaine solid science complete man hath honour gather nosegayes stay himselfe build certaine vsuall wordes trust vnto memorie hee ought trust himselfe let speake retaine base thing olde man one stept yeares wise nothing notebooke said zeno sayest thou cleanthes thou long art thou directed others command say shall committed memorie produce somewhat thine owne thinke therefore neuerauthors alwayes interpreter lying hid vnder shadow men haue generous nature neuer dared publish learned long space time haue exercised memorie men labour one thing remember another thing know remember keepe thing memorie committed contrariwise know make euery thing owne neyther hang example oftentimes looke backe master saith zeno cleanthes make difference betwixt thee thy booke long wilt thou learner last employ thy selfe teach others profiteth heare may reade liuing voyce saith hee doth much recommended another man wordes serueth stead register adde hereunto neuer owne master first thing doe follow ancestor wherein man hath reuoked former againe follow yet question neuer found shall content thing found moreouer followeth another man hath found nothing worse seeketh nothing shall follow step mine ancestor truely keepe olde wayes finde one short take maintaine v haue managed thing lord guide truth open vnto men yet borne away much left posteritie finde epist xxxiiii hee glad lvcilivs proficiencie rom formed moreouer exhorteth goe forward euen perfection grow great leape ioy shaking min olde age grow young againe often vnderstand thing thou doest writest much thy selfe exceedest thy selfe long since thou hadd st forsaken troupe common societie tree grown beare fruit delighteth husbandman shepheard take pleasure fruitfulnesse flocke man beholdeth oster childe otherwise reputeth young are owne thinkest thou befalleth haue formed yong spirit haue trained vp raw suddenly see ripe challenge thee mine thou art mine labor first saw thine inclination laide hold thee exhorted thee encouraged thee neyther permitted thee pace sof ly pricked thee forward doe like henceforward giue thee courage long thou shalt speedily runne forward thou reciprocally art exhort thing haue desired hitherto sayest thou greater part time spent euen beginning worke said occupie halfe busines mind greater part good desire become good knowest thou call good mean perfect absolute man whose act discordant epist xxxv wisheth friend good man otherwise man friend although loueth let therefore doe especially learne liue conueniently constantly wisely arnes ly intreat thee studie doe mine owne businesse haue friend come passe except thou perseuer beauti ie thy selfe thou hast begun thou louest thou art friend anie difference betwixt two else vnlike friend loue h loueth assuredly friend cause friendship alwayes profiteth loue sometimes hurteth thou doest thing profite least wise well thou mayest learne loue well aboue thing haste thy selfe time thou studiest feare thou learn another euen winde carrieth firme hath good foundation varieth perfectly happeneth wise man measure proficient hath yet attained difference manner moued yet passeth shaken place sort moued epist xxxvi memorie plato saith king descended slaue slaue descended king thing hath long varietie mingled together fortune hath turned topsieturuie therefore gentleman well composed nature vnto vertue onely expected otherwise thou recallest mee antiquitie man thence nothing first beginning world vnto day line alteration hath deriued v noble villeinies maketh nobleman haue court full smoakie image man liued glorie neyther v minde maketh nobleman base condition soeuer enobleth v rise aboue fortune thinke thy selfe therefore thou art roman knight libertine thou mayest attaine thou alone mayest free amongst libertine sayest thou thou distinguish good euill people iudgements must regard whence come whether goe thing may make life happie absolutely good may depraued turned euill wherein erre affect afterwards flattered toled thought fit passe eloquent thou mayst coiecture seemed short vnto neither thy time mine first sight seemed either titus liuius epicurus much sweetnesse detained allured without delay ouerread sunne inuited hunger admonished mee shower threatened yet reade ouer much delighted gladded would say vnto thee wit hath man minde abilitie pawsed risen degree hath beene vehemencie continuate forme composition masculine holy notwithstanding mixture sweetnesse grace thou art great vpright course aduise thee proceed thou matter also somewhat therefore chosen fruitfull may rauish man minde excite write thy booke haue reexamined yet iudgement setled seeme one hath heard ouerread suffer likewise make inquisition thou needest feare thou shalt heare truth happie man thou art hast nothing man lie vnto thee farre euen cause taken away lye customes sake epist xlvii ought behaue selues liue seruants familiarly error age pride contempt yet according man disposition vertue one either freely seuerely bee handled haue willingly vnderstood come thee thou liuest familiarly thy slaues becommeth thy prudence answerable thy wisdome thy slaues nay rather thy companion thy slaues nay rather thine humble friend thy slaues nay rather thy fellow seruants thou knowest fortune hath much power ouer one ouer therefore laugh thinke abiect base thing sup seruants ouerweening custome hath enuironed supping lord troope attending seruants farre eateth digesteth excessiue greedines loadeth ee distended belly greater labour hee may vomit vp thing surfet hath ingested vnhappy seruants haue scarce leaue moue lip end speake murmure stilled rod scarce casuall thing escape whip cough sneese hicket great penaltie threatned speech renewed silence interrupted liuelong night stand fasting waite mute commeth passe speake lord presence haue libertie discourse onely libertie speake master conferre whose mouth sewed vp readie hazard head master turne imminent perill owne neckes banquet spake torment silent furthermore prouerb lesse arrogancie published many seruants haue many enemy haue enemy make meane space let passe many cruell inhumane thing abuse men beast whereas set supper one wipeth away spitting crouching vnder table gathereth reliques drunkard another cutteth vp deerest fowle conueying cunning thorow breast hinder part certaine conceit caruing cut peeces vnhappy liueth one thing cut vp wilde fowle decently miserable voluptuousnesse sake teacheth learneth necessitie another skinking wine attired womanlike fashion striueth age cannot lie childhood yet hee drawne backe sweete faced haires either shauen pulled vp rootes martiall habite attendeth watcheth hee night hee diuideth betwixt lord drunkennesse lust chamber man banquet boy another censure ghuests permitted attendeth vnhappie expecteth flattery intemperance either mouthes tongue reuoaketh next day ad caterer haue certaine subtill knowledge lord best liking know sauour meate hold best pleasing appetite affecteth eye meate quicken loathing stomackes hee loatheth fulnesse longeth day cannot abide sup thinketh diminution maiestie sit table seruant god forbid find master saw callistus master attend doore excluded amongst many entered set seruile schedule brest sold brought forth saile amongst ridiculous abiect slaues slaue fauour set saile amongst abiect first rancke fruitlessely prostituted crier basely made vendible master yea himselfe thought vnworthy house lord sold callistus many thing callistus sell master wilt thou thinke thou termest thy slaue borne seed enioyeth aire equally breatheth liueth dieth thou shalt thou mayest see noble thee seruile many men fortune depresse marian slaughter noble birth thrice tribune election senator one made shepheard keeper cottage contemne man fortune thou mayest transferred whilest thou contemnest intrude selfe large field discourse dispute vse seruants respect wee cruell proud contumelious yet summe precept liue thine inferiour thou wouldest thy superiour liue thee ten thou bethinkest thy selfe power thou hast ouer thy seruant b thinke thy lfe much power thy mast r hath ouer thee sayest thou haue master better thy fortune happily thou shalt haue knowest thou yeares hecuba began serue time cr sus time darius mother time plat time diogenes liue thy seruant kindly court ously vouchsafe conference admit counsaile assurance contentment liueth selfe thing one cannot befortune attend wise man true wise man careth thing knoweth liue vnto himselfe principall good knoweth liue lieth men affaire miserie ambition hath banished citie cannot see happie himselfe like fearefull slothfull creature hath hid feares liueth loathsome disliking liueth belly sleepe lust liueth himselfe liueth man yet constancie perseuerance first designes thing valued obstinate idlenesse retaineth hath authoritie also touching building selfe speake write thee nothing certaine onely know outwardly show maketh passenger two caues maruellous workmanship alike spacious entrance builded hand one whereof neuer admitteth sunne filled reflection vntill set place planted planetrees middest whereof runneth brooke falleth afterwards sea lake acherusium diuided euripus sufficient nourish much fish although man take daily spared sea affordeth good fishing time tempest restraineth fisherman one may catch fish easily greatest commoditie house hath behind wals thereof baya exempt incommodities thereof pertaketh pleasure delight selfe knowledge giue commendation beleeue place fit inhabited yeare long opposite westwinde intercepteth conueniently hindereth blowing vpon baya inconsiderately seemeth vatia make choice place might bestow idle time old age yet little nothing doth place profit tranquillitie spirit minde commendeth thing haue seene liue pensiue melancholie house pleasure haue seene othersome liue solitarie place much businesse wherefore thou art thinke therfore thou art little thine ease thou art thou art separated diuers occupation one haue secret study going commings citie thou shalt see time long voyage make v loose ouergreat friend possessed minde seeth alwaies see therefore pray thee studie sup walke liue miserable restraint thing hidden thought see thee lucilius content heare thee truely thee doubt whether begin write epistle bookes vnto thee epist lvi setled minde enioyeth selfe intendeth study yea euen amiddest presse men teacheth example inward silence peace wished furthermore sloth euill mother desire let die silence necessarie seemeth retired studie behold different cry sound euery side lodged euen ouer bathe represent vnto thy selfe sort voyces may draw eares hatred stronger doe exercise spread hand loaden leade either trauell imitate laboureth heare groan soone haue giuen libertie heir retain breath heare wheesings waightie breathing man alleth hand vnmannerly sot taketh vpon annoint men content serue would doe one inferiour people heare stroake hand striketh shoulder according hee layeth either flat hollow changeth sound perchance casteth balles annointed pitch nourish fire vnder baynes commeth beginneth reckon lost count likewise cleanseth ordure theefe taken also taketh pleasure heare voice ring bath likewise number full leape great shout cast themselues bayne moreouer put rancke least doe thing haue voice word fulmouthed draweth haire armepit incessantly breatheth forth small trembling voice end hee may better noted amongst rest neuer holdeth peace time riddeth armepits haire one constraineth crie man h areth afterward infinite crie cakesellers saudsigemongers crackling merchant cooke skullions sell meate euerie one proper tune end may better marked iron braines thine sayest thou deafe art thou thy spirit troubled amidst dimme diuersitie cry since chrysippus fell downe almost dead heare goodmorrowes men gaue saluting mine owne part honestly sweare vnto thee care little cry flouds fall riuer although haue heard say although thy bone laid rest repose sometimes without repose shall therefore requisite v awake selues managing affaire occupie selues search good art science perceiue sourge idlenesse cannot endure place receiue nothing misery displeasure yet notwithstanding verie caue feare wearinesse hath cast v ambition reuiueth flourisheth wholly lost wearied onely repulsed seeing affaire grew answerable wee shew man sad himselfe vnhappy folly also ambition griefe sayest thou shall forget friend vndoubtedly thou promisest verie short remembrance must continue longer thy griefe least occasion fortune suddenly change wrinckles thy brow smile grant thee long time length whereof notwithstanding might calme allay greatest sorrowes world make end bitter griefes soone thou shalt cease flatter nourish thy griefe opinion sadnesse forsake thee keepest thou entertainest thy sorrow charily soeuer thou keepe escape thee sooner sharper aboue thing let v labour remembrance friend loose agreeable pleasing vnto v man taketh pleasure remember subiect whereon hee cannot thinke without torment notwithstanding cannot otherwise name friend haue lost may reduced memorie without touch attaint sorrow touch pleasure conceiued mindes wee giue credit vnto thinke th friend health eate hony cake memorie deceased yeeld ioy intermixed little bitternesse would deny sharpe thing haue acrimonie hurtfull displeasing stomacke yet opinion remembrance friend deceased agreeable pleasing vnto lose haue lost doe therefore lucilius thy deiscretion requireth forbeare giue euill interpr tation benefit fortune took away giuen let v enioy friend greedie desire know whether shall continue v long time noe let v thinke haue oftentimes left made long voyage oftentimes abiding place haue seene shall find haue lost time aliue may man endure make reckoning account friend haue bewaile afterwards miserably neuer loue euen haue lost therefore abundantly weepe afraid left grow doubt whether loued thus seeke take testimony amitie wee haue friend doe iniurie conceiue euill opinion thinke cannot comfort v much one onely haue lost haue selues doe selues greater wrong haue receiued fortune hand hath onely taken one v haue made againe scarcely loued one could loue one man robbed lost onely one coate rather bewaile misfortune bethinke meanes hee might escape cold finde something couer shoulder wouldest thou esteene great foole thou hast buried thou louedst seeke another thou mayest loue better get new friend bewaile olde know well thing pretended speake verie vulgar knowne vnto euery man yet pretermit though world hath vsed hee reason counsaile could finde end sorrow met time contemptible wiseman finde remedie sorrow wearying himselfe rather thou shouldest relinquish thy sorrow thou shouldest left desist soone thou canst although thou wouldst thou canst long auncestors limitted tearme yeare woman mourne mourne long might mourn longer men prefixed distinct time time honest yet woman wilt thou name could scarcely drawn pile husband burned dragged dead carcasse whose moan continued whole month nothing groweth soone hatred griefe new findeth comforter draweth vnto solace inueterate derided without cause eyther fained foolish yet doe write vnto thee euen haue immeasurably bewayled annaeus serenus deere friend write heartsgriefe might numbred amongst example sorrow hath ouercome present time condemne mine owne action thorowly perceiue greatest cause mourning neuer thought might haue died thought onely younger farre young destiny called v order birth let v therfore continually meditate well owne mortalitie loue haue said serenus yonger purpose must die might also hauing thought herevpon fortune surprising sudden strooke thus know thing mortall mortall vnder vncertaine lawe may done day euer may done let v thinke therefore deere lucilius shall quickly come thither lodged lament happily opinion wisemen sauor truth place receiue v suppose haue perished sent v epist lxiiii praise qvintvs sextivs wisedome selfe true author thereof venerable notwithstanding may adde thereunto thou wert yesterday v may demanded whether yesterday onely therefore added v thou art alwayes certaine friend came suddenly vpon whose arriuall chimney smoaked accustomed smoake kind wont fume kitchins intertaine feast terrifie watch night little smoake signified guest come diuers different discourse happeneth sit banquet reducing nothing resolution passing one thing another afterwards booke quintus sextius father man much knowledge thou wilt beleeue stoicke although would denie read vnto v good god man replenished constancy courage thou shalt find like amongst philosopher men writing haue goodly title rest without life make institutios dispute cauill adde courage haue none thou hast read sextius thou wilt say liueth full vigour free man leaueth alwayes replenished great assurance howsoeuer minde disposed read confesse vnto thee addressed prouoke casualty freely exclaime ceasest thou fortune come encounter thou shalt doest see readinesse cloath selfe courage serueth subiect may approue may expres e vertue wisheth freely might behold foaming boare amidst idle folde sterne lion hils descend golden crest cattell offend desi e haue somewhat may ouercome suffer exercise patience sextius likewise hath admirable qualitie sh w thee excellency happy life wil put thee hope ob ine thou shalt know lodged place high notwithstanding man hath may mount thereunto amongst thing vertue may giue thee thou maist admire therat without losing thy hope attaine truely onely contemplation wisedome oftentimes robbeth much time beholde lesse astonishment doe heauens world oftentimes cast mine eye neuer seene therefore reuerence honor intention wisedome inuerters also delighteth goe take possession thereof heritage common vnto many thing gotten thing laboured let v pl part good ather family let v increase inheritage left v nd let possession descend posteritie ample profitable assured full good happe honest thing therefore shall haue place credit although heauie troublesome good man haue although poore banished sicke well set one side good man full rich side one consent vnto nature one dead young another olde one moreouer dead infancie hath enioyed good haue onely sight life equally subiect die although death hath suffered liue long others hath cut threed life euen flower age hath interrupted beginning birth one dieth middest supper another sleepe death hath beene one also haue strangled amiddest embrace minion adde also dead sword haue beene slaughtered sting serpent haue beene crushed death vnder ruine dead long conuulsion sinewes little little hath tortured man may say end better others worse death equall meanes whereby come thereunto diuers point ended one death great one hath one measure person put end life say like good one good nourisheth selfe betwixt pleasure delight sealeth nothing aduersities disaster one hath gouerned pleasure sweetnes good fortune another hath euer borne force tyrannie yet one good wholly equall although one hath martched plaine easie pathes place tedious dangerous briefe end wholly like good
