letter thing common spring began open selfe approched alreadie towards summer time hot waxed warme neither yet trusted oftentimes returneth winter wilt thou know vnassured yet dare aduenture bath selfe cold water yet doe temper cold thereof sayest thou suffer either heat cold lucilius mine age contented enough coldnes scarcely may thawed middest summer therefore part time lie couched mattresse thanke mine age hath tied couch giue thankes cannot act greatest discourse book time thy epistle come betweene thinkes thee affected minde write backe vnto thee answered thee face face therefore entreate thou demandest spake thee v examine question thou wilt haue thee whether euery good destred bee good sayest thou endure torment couragiously suffer fire great constancie endure sicknesse peaceably followeth desired yet see nothing worthy wished truely yet know man hath payed vow hath made beaten whip made lame gout made longer racke thou must lucilius make distinction thing shalt thou finde point may wished could well wish torment alwaies estranged force must need feele would wish might endure vertuously couragiously honorably rather wish war e neuer happen proclaimed begun would wish generous courage might suffer wound famine necessitie warre bringeth foolish would desire bee sicke must fall would desire also might thing intemper tely effeminately euils incommodities desired vertue whereby incommodities suffered stoicks thinke constancie patience torment euils neither ought desired detested man wisheth ought desire thing wholly peaceable pure exempt sorrowes opinion wherefore cannot thing good desired furthermore vertue desired good without vertue followeth good desired againe constant patience torment desired aske thee againe fortitude wished contemneth prouoketh peril fairest admirable part flie flame present himselfe wound sometimes auoide open breast receiue fortitude desired patience suffering torment wished part fortitude separate thing said shall nothing shall deceiue thee suffer torment bee wished suffer couragiously courage wish vertue yet euer wished himselfe vowes open professed particularly made obscured many thing comprehended one vow desire honest life honest life consisteth diuers action regulus tombe catoes wound rent open owne hand r tilius banishment inuenomed cup translated socrates prison heauen wished selfe honest life wished thing also without sometimes cannot honest thrice fouretimes happy men vnder troytowne walles dismembred lay parent eye difference makest thou either thou wishest vnto one thou conf ssest desired decius made vow die commonweale seeking nought death galloped horse swarmes enemy another emulated father vertue hee pronounced solemne word alreadie familiar vnto thrust himselfe mainely throng enemy hauing care be ch god effect intention vow supposing good death thing desired doubtest thou great good die end leaue happie memorie man vertuous enterprise one endureth torment constantly employeth vertues although may patience onely might appeare shew selfe fortitude whose patience sufferance tollerance branch prudence without counsell conceiued perswadeth endure valiantly thou canst flie constancie cannot deiected place giueth ouer resolution feare torture inseparable societie vertues done honorably one vertue doth aduice counsell allowed vertues although seeme done one desired supposest thou thing wished come pleasure idlenesse receiue painted tapissed adorned gate sad pleasure vowes celebrated reioyce adoration veneration whole assembly thinkest thou kinde regulus wished returne hand carthaginian put vpon thee minde generous vertuous man separate thy self little opinion common sort assume faire magni icent forme vertue thou oughtest bee honored v gaud garland sweate blood behold marcus cato thrus ing pure hand sacred brest enlarge wound yet sufficiently deepe whether length wouldest thou say vnto would thou wouldest much grieued thou doest happy vnto thee thou doest place friend demetrius commeth minde termed secure life one subiect fortune incursion dead sea haue nothing awaken thee nothing moue thee nothing whose aduertisement assault thou mayest make triall firmitie thy minde liue alwaies repose hath neuer troubled tranquillitie calme relent sea attalus stoick wont say rather fortune nourish campe delight suffer torment constancie well massacred endure constantly doth well heare moreouer epicurus saith sweete neuer giue delicate name thing honest seuere burned yet remaine inuincible desired fire burne ouercome nothing worthie vertue whatsoeuer done direction command good desirable epist lxviii perswadeth repose e ioyned philosophie boast thereof entreate selues selues enquire vice amend conclude repose aboue affaire serueth great commonweale thy minde go retire hide thy selfe repose rather hide thou thy repose thou canst learne stoicks precept least thou shalt learne example preceps also thou shalt learne approue vnto thee thou wilt send ouer euery commonweale neither alwayes neither without end moreouer haue giuen wiseman commonweale worthy himselfe say world commonweale although retired may bee rather forsaking little corner hee goeth place great spacious lodging himselfe heauen vnderstandeth mounted chaire throne rather descended base place shut secret thy bosome wiseman neuer profiteth much humane diuine thing become obiects eye returne vnto began perswade thee vnto man may know thou wilt liue repose behoueth thee couer resolution vnder cloake retirement whereby thou mayest intend philosophie better thou shouldest obscure thine intent vnder title thou must call sicknesse feeblenes idlenesse foolish ambition glorie nothing certaine beast tracted confound step euen place lurke like must thou doe otherwise thou shalt want follow quest thee many passe gate opened without entring peepe cranies closed coffer closed whetteth theefe breake open man maketh reckoning vnlocked lockpickers assault doore open manner common people thus doth ignorant desire enter forcibly others men secret therefore expedient man boast retirement kinde boasting e hidden much sequester man selfe sight people man locked vp tarentum man retired naples man many yeares hath ouerstrid threshold vndoubtedly summoneth world come see suffer report passe citie retired thou hast retired thy selfe thou must doe nothing men may talke thee speake thou thy selfe shalt thou talke thy selfe men willingly entert ine others haue alwayes ill opinion thy selfe accustome thy selfe speake truth heare also aboue thing speake thou often imperfection thou feelest thy selfe man knoweth owne infirmity therefore man disburdeneth stomacke vomit another stuffes continuall eating another emptieth weakeneth bodie meanes fast often tortured paine gout abstaine either bathing themselues drinking wine without obseruance manner diet ordinarily ouercome sickenesse wherewith tormented likewise certaine part soule cause infirmity ought recouer diligently must bethinke selues doe repose take cure mine vlcer shew thee foote swolne hand wholly mortified dried sinewes contracted leg thou wouldest giue leaue lie one place take pitie regard griefe euill cannot see farre greater inflamation aposteme haue brest thou praise neither thou say great man hee hath despised thing hee hath condemned fury humane life hee fled ala haue condemned nothing mine owne proper action thou must desire come vnto end profit thy selfe thou art deceiued hence thou expectest succour heere dwels physitian patient rather thou art gone thou shouldest say thought man happy learned man gaue eare vnto deceiued heard nothing saw nothing might desire might allure returne againe vnto thy opinion thy speech know thou hast profited somewhat rather thou shouldest pardon repose enuie seneca commendest thou repose spirit vnto thou growest epicure thy opinon length recommend vnto thee repose end mean thereof thou mightest doe thing great excellent th n thou hast left behinde thee knocke great men gate keepe reckoning old men haue child haue great reputation court momentum power full enuie thou wilt speake truth abiect man farre surpasseth reputation amongst lawyer allowance pay seruice dignity gotten thereby multitude client cannot well followed one recouer great reputation ought make great account ouercome men prouide alwaies may ouercome fortune would god beene thy minde heretofore haue followed purpose would god wee held discourse happie life vpon instant wherein death presenteth selfe sight yet let v delay beleeue many thing experience haue beleeued discourse reason super luous harmefull let v like set forward iourney late diligence would recouer time haue lost let v pricke forward spurre age yet proper studie alreadie clensed skum hath alreadie left vice could conquer heate youth wanteth little hath wholly extinguished saiest thou shall pro thee thou learnest euen period thy yeares intent may die better yet oughtest thou thinke age proper vnto wisedome long experience continuall frequent sufferance casualty hath mortified ouercom selfe hath triumphed ouer affection hath attained knowledge profiteth concerneth selfe true time good remaineth little man soeuer olde soeuer hee hath attained wisedome yeares hath compassed epist lxxix place changed ought reposed bodie end minde may pacified fixe wholsome studie auoyde thing distract v thou change country transport thy selfe one place another first often change token instable vnsetled minde thou canst neuer make profite thy retirement vnlesse thou giue ouer trauell wandring countrey countrey thou wilt settle thy minde limit thy bodie place thy continued remedy profite thee much thou must breake repose forgetfulnes thy former life suffer thine eye forget suffer thine eares accustome themselues wholsome counsailes ofttimes thou shalt walke street thou shalt inde passing something may renue thy affection euen would despoile himselfe loue ought flie remembrance beautie hath loued also discharge himselfe affection thing desire wherewith burned time past must retire eye eares hath forsaken affection reuolteth suddenly side soeeuer turne selfe shall finde readie recompence employment euill without reward auarice promiseth v money lust manie diuers pleasure ambition purple applause thereby power authoritie whatsoeuer authoritie may doe vice sollicite thee reward must thou liue without taking thing scarce effected whole age vice haue increase long libertie subdued brought subiection much lesse may done diuide time short little parcel hardly continuall watch labour bring one onely thing perfection truely thou wilt listen meditate hereupon exercise thy selfe receiue death seeke occasion shall counsaile thee thereunto skils whether come v perswade thy selfe foolish men prouerbe vsuall speech false faire thing die good death thou mayst beside thinke thus thy selfe man dieth prefixed time thou loosest none thy time thou leauest behinde thee another man epist lxx sight pompey admonishment time past thought vpon swiftnesse slight thereof death hand hauen trouble neyther eared desired intertained sometimes reason violent passion perswadeth many excellent thing purpose long space time haue seene thy pompey seeing thought recouered againe former youth whatsoeuer done whilst young man thought could yet doe little since wee saile life lucilius sea virgil saith shore citties flie likewise swift course time lose sight first childehood youth whatsoeuer intercurreth betwixt youth old age con ined one anon also better yeares olde age last place common end humane race beginneth discouer selfe foolish thinke rocke port ought one day desire neuer refuse man hath beene cast carried young yeares ought complain would short cut hath ended nauigation thou knowest acker wind mocke detaine wearie gentle tediousnesse peaceable calme swiftly borne away sudden gust thinke befalleth v life hath brought rauished swiftly thither whether although would haue delayed must need come othersome hath pined burned thou knowest alwaies retained good liue liue well therefore wiseman liueth much ought much alwayes see place ought liue person manner ought doe diuers trouble sorrowes suddenly surprise intent intercept peace openeth prison himselfe neither doth onely desperate extreamity soone hath least suspicion fortune taketh diligent heede whether day last make great reckoning whether hand another man hatred receiue death whether sooner later feareth endangered lose much man haue great losse water dropping ewer skils whether man die sooner later die eyther well ill importeth much die well flie perrill euill life therefore thinke rhodians speech e feminate tyrant cast caue nourished thereof manner wilde beast perswaded abstaine meate answered man ought hope thing whilst liueth suppose true yet ought buy life euery rate certaine thing although good although certaine yet would attaine confession feeblenesse faintnesse heart shal beleeue fortune hath power thing ouer liueth rather suppose fortune nothing ouer knoweth die yet sometimes although assured death dependent man know punishment de tinated yet must e set ha punishment follie die feare death come kill thee expect puttest thou thy selfe forward vndertakest thou charge another man crueltie dost thou enuie thy hangman officer execute thee wilt thou spare labour socrates could haue ended day absence might haue rather died hunger venome yet remained full thirtie dayes prison attending death minde thing might pacified long time might intertaine many hope hee might yeelde himselfe vnto lawes suffer friend enioy socrates euen vntill last great follie could haue beene seene despise death feare prison scribonia woman great authoritie aunt father side drusus libo young man weake braine descent noble hoped farre greate fortune might hope time himselfe time borne away senate litter frequent obseruances neerest friend forsaken shamefully guiltie conuicted person executed began aske counsaile whether hasten death hand expect scribonia pleasure hast thou said finish another ought execute could wayes perswade murthered himselfe owne handes without cause assured within three foure dayes beene found aliue die death whatsoeuer best liking enemie finished another man haue executed thou canst make generall iudgement violence forraine tyrant denounceth thee death whether thou oughtest expect diuers reason draw v one opinion one death accompanied torment simple facile allow euen would chuse ship saile house dwell like manner would chuse better death depart life furthermore euen longest life best longest death worst nothing wherein wee giue contentment soules maner death best like let soule depart issue selfe inforceth whether desire dagger halter poisoned cup may suddenly seize veines let proceed breake bond seruitude euerie ought endeuour approue life vnto others death vnto himselfe pleaseth v best follie think thus say couragiously enough much rashly kinde death generous thinkest thou lieth thy power make choice counsaile shall subiect common report censure thinke onely dispatch thy selfe speedily power handes fortune otherwise want conceiue euill opinion thine action thou shalt finde yea euen haue made profession philosophie denie man ought violate shorten life maintaine foule offence man murther himselfe better exspect end nature hath determined speaketh thus seeth cutteth way libertie eternall law hath done nothing better giue v one onely entrance life diuers issue shall expulse crueltie sickenesse tyrannie man may escape euen middest torment driue aduersities farre one thing wherein cannot complaine life retaineth man great good humane affaire one miserable owne default takest thou pleasure life liue art thou displeased therwith thou mayest returne place whence thou camest heale thy headach thou hast ofttimes let bloud extenuate thy bodie thou hast opened thy veine thou needest open thy breast deepe vast wound lancet giue way great libertie pricke consisteth securitie maketh v fearefull slacke dislodge one v thinketh must depart one day house doth custome indulgence place detaine auncient inhabitant although owne vndoing wilt thou alwayes keepe libertie bodie inhabite thou shouldst leaue make account one day thou must lose company thou shalt afterwards constant resolute anie necessitie shall constraine thee depart thinke vpon end couet thing without end nothing world remembrance meditation whereof necessarie happily vaine man thinketh thing haue wee prepared mindes pouertie rich remaine v alreadie armed contempt paine felicitie whole healthfull bodie hath need make proofe vertues haue gotten authoritie ouer selues suffer death losse friend constantly yet fortune hath conserued made suruiue vnto v loue day shall haue neede vse practique onely thing ought vndoubtedly come thou must thinke great personage onely haue courage force breake bond humane seruitude thou must thinke cato onely could rent soule hand could pricke poynard since men bad condition may great heate courage haue attained place assurance vnable suddenly finde wherewith make themselues away liking chuse instrument proper thereunto haue laide hand first thing could encounter haue made vse weapon nature wayes hurtfull long since alman one combate beast sport show morning retired fayning would withdraw himselfe discharge natural necessity suffred go secret place without guard stopped sticke staffe spong fastned cleanse cleere priuie part wholly throat forcibly closing vp passage breath stifled himselfe braue death contemne vndoubtedly although scarce cleanly honourably follie greater die effeminately must die assuredly strong worthy man deseruing election death best liked couragiously vsed sword found resolution minde cast himselfe depth sea cauitie clouen rocke dispoyled commodity found meanes might beholding vnto himselfe onely meanes weapon death end thou mayest know nothing hindereth v dying want let man iudge list violent man action prouided resolued vpon thing assured ought preferre base villeynous death cleanliest seruitude world haue begun vse abiect example contiue euerie one inforce himselfe doe best shall perceiue death contemptible person abiect base think catoes scipioes whose memory entertaine admiration inimitable proue presently vertue accompanied many example amiddest men miserable destinated sport spectacle beast amiddest chiefetains ciuill warres long since sure guard souldiers carried forth wretch sent morning spectacle stouping downe head pressed sleepe suffered hang lowe put betweene cartwheel held long place wheele turning selfe brake necke auoyded punishment chariot carried forth punished nothing may hinder man hath die deliuered nature keepeth v open place last necessitie fauourable aduise issue end shall esteeme conuenient hath diuers meanes power set himselfe libertie may chuse shall well thinke may easily deliuered hath hard hap finde occasion let take hold first shall present selfe best although strange vnheard wanteth courage wanteth inuention die thou seest sla e miserable miserie toucheth quicke awaken themselues deceiue keeper though neuer diligent man greatest courage hath onely commanded also found mean death haue promised thee diuers example men condition haue spoken second combate made vpon water one barbarian thrust iauelin throate giuen combate enemy haue long since said fled torment shame attend death hauing armes hand spectacle much magni icent much honest men learne die well kill abiect contemptible spirit may haue pertake long studie reason ladie mistresse thing hath instructed reason warneth v diuers manner death one end auaileth nothing know whence beginneth must one day come reason warneth thee lie thy power die without griefe cannot doe best thou canst lay hold presenteth selfe lay violence thy life iniurious thing liue rapine worthy thing die violently epist lxxi chiefest good continually eye counsel action referred therefore onely honest adulterate fame mixe internall thing onely freed minde againe good equall contempt differeth honour proceed honestie giueth cato example dilateth worthily likewise honest death differeth life academikes make degree happinesse neither honestie intended therefore blessed may torment wax pale tremble grieue yes naturall shall ouercome strength minde yet presently difference betweene wise men studious reade diligently marke admire thou askest counsell thy affaire time time remembring thy selfe separated large sea since greater part counsaile dependeth opportunitie time must fall necessitie sometimes certaine thing counsaile brought vnto thee time contrarie allowable counsailes fitted affaire affaire passe away swiftly speake truth roule away impetuously counsell therefore ought giuen daily yet sometime ouer old day must bred swiftly say vnder hand found shew thee oft thou wilt know either fled ought affected haue regard vnto chiefest good scope thy whole life thereto must consent whatsoeuer doe shall dispose euery thing except purpose himselfe alreadie certaine straine whole life man although colour ground hand represent similitude thing except alreadie resolued intendeth paint therefore erre wee wee v deliberate part life man debateth whole hee must know whereat aimeth shoote arrow must aime guide arrow hand counsailes therefore erre haue whereunto directed knoweth harbor shall make hath winde fitting must need fall casualtie must effect much life v liue casually happeneth wot know certaine thing euen oftentimes seeke conuersant present part know end soueraigne good though eye neither many word long circumstance shalt thou gather chiefest good must show prouerb saith finger without extending many thing purpose diuide part thou mayest say chiefest good honest thou shouldest wonder onely one good honest rest false adulterated good thou perswade thy selfe perfectly louest vertue loue small matter whatsoeuer shal touch thee howsoeuer seeme others shall happie successefull tormented thou lie secure tortureth thee sicke thou curse fortune giue way thy sickenesse conclude thing men seeme euill shall sweete vnto thee returne thee profit thou canst ouercome resolue nothing good honest incommodities may iustly called good made honest vertue many seeme promise greater thing humane nature capable without reason respect bodie let returne minde shall measure man god take courage lucilius best men dismisse studie letter philosopher affect reduce magnificent thing world syllable teach base trifling matter diminish waste vnderstanding thou shalt become like vnto haue inuented thing teach endeuour thus much philosophie might rather seeme difficult great follow haue authoritie ouer thee socrates reduced philosophie vnto manner said chiefest wisdome distinguish good euill end thou mayest happie saith permit thy selfe sometimes esteemed foole let whosoeuer outrage thee word offend thee deed yet shalt thou uffer nothing vertue thee thou wilt saith blessed thou wilt entire honest man suffer thy selfe contemned man performe hath equalled proportioned good neither good without honestie honestie equall difference betwixt catoes pretorship repulse skilleth whether cato ouercome pharsalian field whether ouercome good wherein cannot ouercome though confederate conquered equall good wherewith returned conquerour vnto countrie composed peace equall selfesame vertue euill fortune ouercome good confirmed yet vertue cannot made greater lesser alwaies measure yea cneius pompey shall lose armie faire lustre pretext commonweale principall citizen chiefest band pompeyes confedera e composed senate bare armes shall defaced one battell wreckes ruines great empire shall noised scattered whole world one part thereof shall fall egypt another africa spaine worse miserable commonweale cannot haue good ruinated let happen whatsoeuer may although iuba succoured owne kingdome knowledge passage constant vertues people although fidelitie inhabitant vtica broken many mishap deficient fortune scipioes name abandoneth africa selfe hath long since beene prouided cato shall neither feele losse detriment yet hee conquered account thou amongst catoes repulse wil suffer equall constancie well hath beene contrarie vertue estate pretor day refused sported night would kill himselfe read cared little lose life pretorship perswaded himselfe resolued endure might happen stout confident minde endure change commonweale may man see exempt change earth heauens structure great world although bee gouerned god subiect thereunto shall alwayes retaine faire order obserueth day shall come shall cast accustomed course thing alter certaine station must borne encrease extinguished whatsoeuer thou seest wheele winde v al wheron sustained stayed thing firme solide shall come nothing bee defectiue nothing hath age declination nature causeth thing descend one place space vnequall time shall yet shall perish dissolued v dissolution die respect nothing eye dull minde hath addicted selfe body foreseeth otherwise shee would constantly couragiously suffer owne friend dissolution deathes hoped thing goe turnes death life thing compounded shall dissolued dissolued shall reassembled god gouerneth whole world employeth eternall arte worke therefore cato hath represented minde eternitie time say mankind whatsoeuer shall condemned die city place soeuer haue dominion ouer neighbour haue beene greatned honoured forren empire time shall come shall enquired builded sundrie sort dissolution shall extinguished warre shall destroy idlenesse long peace conuerted slothfulnesse foolish expences fatall adiunct great rich shall consume others sudden inundation sea shall hide fertile field earthquake shall swallow vp bottomlesse bosome cause haue therefore grudge grieue small moment outstrip publike fate constant soule must obey god whatsoeuer law great vniuers commandeth let suffer without cunctation delay either shall translated better life remaine brightnes tranquillitie amongst diuine thing certainly shall remix selfe nature returne whole neuermore suffer incommoditie paine soueraigne good marcus cato shall consist honest life honest death vertue intended socrates said veritie vertue encreaseth doth vertue also shee hath perfection full thou must wonder heare good equal well take certaine resolution sudden current fortune bringeth v thou admittest inequalitie thou wilt reckon amongst lesser good constant torment thou shalt reckon also amongst euils thou shalt terme socrates vnhappie prison cato infortunate renting open wound couragiously inflicted thou shalt iudge regulus vnhappiest man world paying penaltie obserued faith vnto mortall enemy yet one delicate soeuer effeminate bee hath dared say thus deny blessed yet deny miserable ancient academickes confesse amiddest torment paine happie perfectly fully manner allowed happie hath attained soueraigne good soueraigne good cannot haue degree aboue accompanied vertue prouided aduersities ouercome prouided remaine entire safe although bodie crushed sunder certaine remaineth entire speake vertue excellent couragious animated incited offendeth minde oftentimes yong men generous hope disposition put vpon beautie honest thing hath prouoked contemne casualty vndoubtedly wisdome infuse teach perswade v onely good honest neither remitted intended rule man measureth would make straight thou beare whatsoeuer thou changest iniurie right therfore wil say vertue also straight admitteth crookednesse intended iudgeth thing nothing iudgeth shee cannot bee made straighter thing done straighter one must need answerable equall sayest thou thing alike sit table banquetting tortured doth seeme strange vnto thee thou hast occasion wonder euill thing sit banquet good thing tortured done lewdly honestly matter cause either good euill vertue wheresoeuer appeareth thing measure price iudgeth another man vnderstanding owne presently lifteth vp nailes scratch mine eye say good suffereth aduersities constantly maketh honest iudgement prosperitie equall say good triumpheth inuincible courage led triumphant chariot alike thinke nothing done cannot owne infirmitie censure vertue wonderest thou reioyce see themselues burned wounded harmed slaine fettered sometimes suffer pleasure sobrietie sufficeth penaltie prodigall dissolute man trauell lesse torture idle man effeminate taketh pitie industrious studie hell slothfull like sort thing force seeme ouer feeble opinion hard intollerable whereas forgetfulnesse finde many thinke torment want wine trouble rise earely nature difficult recreant effeminate ought iudge great thing great courage otherwise seeme error certaine thing straight let downe water seeme crooked bowed behold skilleth thou seest minde dimmed beholding thing examining true giue yong man well borne good spirit say supposeth fortunate hath borne burthen aduerse fortune constant minde shoulder hath wholly trodden fortune vnder foote wonder temperate tranquillitie admire high minded men deiected standeth men suppressed euill torment thing call aduerse euill thinke soule astonished weakened smothered vnder burthen none may befall wise man remaineth alwayes vpright ouercharged soeuer hee bee nothing lesseneth courage nothing tedious vnto must suffer neuer complaineth fortune hath bafallen sort may befall man whatsoeuer shee knoweth owne force abilitie suffering great burthen put wise man rancke men exempt dolour would doe rocke hath sense remember selfe compounded two part one irrationall may feele bitings burning paine reasonable neuer shaken opinion exempt feare inuincible part man chiefest good lodgeth accomplishment whereof minde wandereth vncertaine doubtfull hath attained perfection assurance immutable firmitie hath begun neuerthelesse ascend vnto highest follow vertue although approcheth good wholly perfect yet vnable yet accomplish sometimes stay himselfe way temperate sort vehemencie strength mind yet hath ouerpassed thing incertaine remaineth yet danger disaster blessed vertues accomplished loueth himselfe hath made proofe constancie thing men feare prouided hee may receiue honest reward deuoyre seruice hee endureth onely embraceth rather heare spoken hee honest heare said happie haue retired selfe thither whither thy expectation draweth lest thou shouldest suppose vertue whereof speake seeme extend selfe aboue naturall thing wiseman shall tremble shall feele paine shall pale sens appertaine vnto bodie originall calamity appeareth euill approued passion astonish soule make confesse shee slaue engender repentance wiseman vndoubtedly surmounteth fortune vertue diuers men haue made profession wisdome notwithstanding haue beene terrified light threatnings place error exact proficient spoken wiseman striue much lieth beleeue praise yet perswade yet although perswaded selfe haue ready hand exercised addressed casualtie euen wooll taketh staine colour first drinketh vp othersome without often maceration boyling wit haue conceited certaine discipline forthwith make vse science except deepely imprinted soule hath taken deepe roote long residence therein hath deepe died superficially coloured soule performeth nothing hath promised may quickly learned word namely one onely good vertue vndoubtedly without vertue vertue lodged better part reasonable shall vertue true immoueable iudgement whence shall proceed heat soule whereby appearance thing may moue heate shall become cleare certaine behoueth iudgement esteeme thing good equall themselues shall atchieued counsaile vertue regard corporall good good bodie yet entirely perfect good well may esteemed rate shall without supereminencie great difference betwixt one shall greater lesser like sort ought men confesse great difference follow philosophie one hath farre profited therein dare lift vp y fortune yet perseuerantly oftentimes obscured beames cleere light hath profited much h dare encounter face face haue attained perfection full assurance must needes fall thing imperfect grow ruine frustrate themselues anon come decay dissolution shall come vnto decay perseuer grow forward inforce themselues remit anie thing studie faithfull intention shall grow backward man findeth aduancement profit left let v therefore diligent perseuer remaineth yet haue ouercome greatest part profit desire profite herein conscience shall beare witnesse whole minde see well also thou hast inspiration thou prosecutest great feruencie thing faire let v make hast life shall cause great good otherwise delay truely loathsome one conuerse base matter let v endeuour time may except begin owne shall come passe contemne fortune shall come passe suppressing affection bringing vnder obedience may say thus haue ouercome askest thou haue ouercome persian farre distant medes warlike nation dacae auarice ambition feare death haue vanquished conquerours vanquisher whole world epist lxxii delayeth answer lvcilivs petition vpon iust occasion sheweth studie goodnesse deferred v badly ought intend onely pretermitting thing nothing happeneth may hinder especially wise proficient sort difference betwixt externall thing neyther adde detract wiseman alwayes contented himselfe know well thou demaundest hand recollected meditated thereupon long time since made tryall memory therefore followeth easily know well feele selfe like hath befalne happeneth bookes mouldie whose leaues cleaue together must dilate mind whatsoeuer thing haue beene heard therein ought refreshed brought vse may alwayes readinesse often haue neede vse let v deferre present requireth much labour much diligence assoone may make longer residence place take taske hand thing thou mayest compose thy coach deserue bed repose solitarie place yet dayes wherein man occupied must doe somwhat yea whole dayes occasion occupation neuer scantie see selues one spring mani worst wee giue selues delayes soone haue made end say wee wholly dedicate selfe end troublesom matter addict selfe vnto studie thou must expect till thou haue leasure follow philosophie thou must contemne thing alwayes man cannot finde time may sufficiently long although continue v yeares infancie vntill longest life man skilleth much whether thou omittest philosophie intermittest remaineth interrupted euen thing bent soone let slip doe forcibly retire themselues departeth continuation retireth selfe returneth wholly vnto beginning must reiect affaire occupation must studie dispose must wholly dispossesse driue v time vnfitting wholsome studie many studie thing ought studie shall occasion may let truely whose minde affaire watchfull ioyfull person onely ue ioy interrupted haue yet attained perfection regard wise ioy continuall keepeth tract fortune occasion countermand alwayes peaceable reposed hath dependance another expecteth fauour fortune hand men applause felicitie bred owne house would leaue soule entred engendred therein might occasion fall make remember mortall slight surpassed vpper skin hee feeleth say incommoditie good greatest hath neuer shaken well wot outwardly incommodities euen vpon strong able bodie appeareth som itch pimple vlcers inwardly euill difference say betweene man hath alreadie acquired perfect wisedome yet attaine betwixt man healthfull beginneth recouer himselfe long tedious sickenesse thinketh himselfe good health fit feuer shortest man except carefull health feeleth time certaine shaking easily falleth relapse former infirmitie wiseman cannot fall againe nay neuer attainted therewith touching body hath health time physitian hath recured cannot promise perpetuitie hee oftentimes recalled almost time resusitated soule healed euer one time teach thee know man health content himselfe may trust himselfe knoweth mortal men vowes benefites giuen demaunded haue moment blessed life thing whereunto man may annex somewhat perfect whence nothing may taken continueth eternally whose ioy perpetuall may reioyce owne good whereunto common sort aspire inconstantly flowe hither thither fortune giueth nothing warrantize yet benefit fortune pleasing vnto v tempered reason directeth maketh v allow exterior thing vse whereof displeaseth desired ouerardently attalus wont vse comparison hast thou seene dogge snatching peece bread open throat morsell lesh master casteth deuoureth incontinently giuen still openeth mouth hope one cast falleth v whatsoeuer fortune casteth vpon v expectation swallow without pleasure still expecting affecting second pray fareth wiseman full thing befall securely receiueth layeth vp ioy great continuall owne one hath good profiteth somewhat hath yet attained perfection one shall somtimes deiected sometimes incouraged sometime raised high heauen otherwise rauished lowe earth ignorant haue little experience neuer make end precipitation fall confusion epicurus chaos voyde infinite another third kind wanton wisedome yet cannot attaine yet sight thereof might say may clap hand neyther shaken neyther doe fall yet continent alreadie harbor since great distance betwixt high low since middest feele yet storme followed danger returne vnto wicked life must addict selues occupation must reiect entred would set place let v hinder beginning lesse labour keepe beginning see take end epist lxxiii philosopher disobedient obedient faithfull prince ambition palatine ffect enuie alwayes vnquiet often displeased loue li e quietly vnder full good merchandize impute benefit also although happen vnto manie length counselleth aspire vnto vertue god stoicks pride make wiseman equall deceiue themselues iudgment suppose haue wholly addicted themselues philosophie disobedient rebellous magistrate king contemne whose authoritie publique affaire administred contrariwise one reuerenceth respecteth without cause king cannot greater good vnto man world may enioy peaceable repose must necessarily publique assurance openeth way intention haue liue well reuerence author thesame good lord father truely farre light witted irresolute men infinitely bound vnto prince notwithstanding haue men thinke owe mor man cannot imploy liberalitie grea soeuer may satisfie mbitious desire increase alwayes glutted thinketh receiue new benefit hath alreadie forgotten olde cou tousnesse hath vice great ingratitude adde hereunto none imployed conuersant publique affaire respecteth time hath ouerstripped lookes outstrip pleasant matter vnto see many men come grieuous vnto one ouerpasse dignitie sort ambition hath vice neuer respecteth past ambition onely inconstant wandring couetousnesse likewise beginneth alwayes end sincere poore man hath forsaken court palace preheminencie commonweale retire himselfe noble intent end loueth whose authoritie lawfull doe thing securitie alone payeth gratuitall testimonie acknowledgement confesseth himselfe indebted vnto great good although knowe good euen honoureth reuerenceth master whose instruction despoyled vice like sort respecteth vnder whose protection gouernement may exercise honest discipline king protecteth others also power denieth euen amongst others haue trauelled sea haue beene partaker one calme hee thinketh himselfe bound vnto neptune hath brought home great quantitie precious merchandize merchant payeth vow greater courage passenger doth also amongst merchant bringeth perfunes purple pretious thing solde waight gold reknowledgeth fauor liberally doth hath laide downe poore merchandize thing serue ballist loade ship benefite thi peace appertayning doth deepely content vse well many magistrate mightie men peace troublesome warre art thou opinion make vse peace imploy drunkennesse ryot sort vice extermination necessarie enterprise warre shall much obliged except happily thou wert opinion wiseman iniust hee thought hee wayes obliged gouernour publique common benefit owe much vnto sunne moone yet shine alone particularly bound vnto yeare god tempereth gouerneth although haue ordained particular honor foolish auarice mortall men maketh diuision good assigneth propertie vnto beleeueth nothing publique profit wiseman iudgeth nothing aptly common betweene men good cannot common portion appertained particular man made partaker little part soeuer enioy common thing adde hereunto also reason greatest truest good diuided little light vpon euerie priuate man come wholly euerie man possession present prince make vnto people particular take much powle hath beene promised euery one common banquet common dole flesh receiued hand almes distributed prises indiuisible good peace libertie also intire particular vnto euery one therefore wiseman considereth whose mean publique necessitie constraineth beare armes intend watch stand sentinell wall pay infinitie tax warre bringeth giueth thanks vnto prince doth philosophie teach v especially dutifully thankfull benefites faithfully requite onely acknowledgement sometimes serueth payment therefore confesse much bound vnto whose wise gouernement prouidence great happie repose befalne able passe terme life tranquilitie quiet interrupted publique occupation god melibe gaue peace god ile honour without cease calmes contentment principally ascribed hath procured v greatest good whereof thou seest yoaked teame permit plow earth pleasant fit mine oaten pipe tune best befits much ought esteeme repose partake god maketh v become god thus say lucilius thus call thee heauen short way sextius wont say ivpiter could doe good man ivpiter hath meanes liberall towards men among two good men better richer betweene two haue equall knowledge gouerning ship thou wilt call better gouerneth carricke great vessell full rich lading aduantage hath iupiter ouer good man onely long time good wiseman reckoneth himselfe nothing lesse vertues determined shorter time euen two wisemen dead fulness age happie whose vertue hath taken end lesser year god likewise surmounteth wiseman felicity although exceed age vertue greater longer iupiter hath th se thing hath giuen vse possession thereof vnto others onely vse appertaineth vnto cause others may vse wiseman likewise glad see possession good man hand maketh small account also iupiter doth supposeth himselfe haue aduantage aboue iupiter cannot haue vse wiseman let v therefore beleeue sextius sheweth v faire way crieth way heauen sobrietie temperance patience aduersitie god disdaine man enuie man entertain stretch forth hand ascend wonderest thou heare men goe vnto god god commeth vnto men nay neere commeth men soule good without god certaine diuine seed dispersed body men growe answerable originall growe alike vnto graine whence tooke beginning entertained bosome good husbandman euill choaketh barren faggie ground finally stead corne beareth chaffe obiections lastly sheweth blessed life circle perfect small great nothing added nothing taken therefrom externall thing must reiterated faire honest enioy thou hast minde thy letter hath delighted happie himselfe iudgeth thing good subiecteth power fortune dependeth another man man sorrowfull losse child another carefull sicke dishonest noted infamie thou shalt see one man tormented loue another man wife another transported loue hee beareth owne wanteth one likewise distracted repulse receiueth affected dignitie another disgusted honor possesseth greatest number men thus miserable assault touch impendent death feare euery side presseth tormenteth incessantly nothing whence thinke assaile therefore liued enemy country ought looke euery side euery voice heare turne neckes thitherward except feare driuen breast liue continuall heartbreake suspition found haue beene sent exile depriued good also occur kinde pouertie irkesome poore rich thou shalt meete shipwracked haue suffered like thing vnto shipwracke either wrath enuy common sort dangerous weapon wound better sort hath ouerthrowne vnawares secure manner gust wont breake forth seeming curite calme sudden lightning whose cracke neighbouring country haue trembled euen neerest ire remaineth much amazed beene striken like sort accident come violence calamitie oppresseth one feareth rest maketh abilitie suffer equal heauines doe suffer men misfortune surprise vnawares astonish mindes see euen onely noise sling although charged frighteth bird like manner wee onely tremble stroake least cracke heare man therefore blessed hath credited himselfe opinion nothing blessed without feare life miserable incombe ed suspition whosoeuer hath addicted himselfe much vnto casualty hath made himselfe great villanous one onely vertue remaineth vncorrupted shee onely remaine alwayes entire vertue good nothing may happen may hinder good wisdome danger change wisedome cannot bee rauished shee cannot fall folly haue old thee happily thou remember diuers haue contemned trod n vnder feete vulgar inconsiderate heate either desired feared haue beene haue thrust hand flame whose smile tormentour could interrupt buriall child haue shed one teare haue presented themselues death without feare loue wrath couetousnesse hath oftentimes made seeke perrills therefore short resolution soule pricked forward good euill vertue onely good marcheth proudly betweene one fortune despiseth thou enter opinion good honest vertues shall trouble man might attaine desired thing selfe contrarie reason whence vertues proceed truth alwayes accompanied reason opinion contrary truth false thou must needes confesse good man carrieth great pietie reuerence towards god cause patiently endure may befall well knoweth befalne god thing conducted thus thinke onely good honest honestie consisteth obedience god patient sufferance accident may follow constant entertainment fortune willing acceptance god performance violent ought topyard striken winde hath lesse force ouer bodie ship haue entered capreas promontorie whence pallas high stormie mountaine spy ship commanded content themselues maine sayle topsayle marke know alexandrian ship amidst course people ran thus hastily sea shoare felt great pleasure sloath thinking receiue letter mine agent made hast know estate affaire stood brought long agoe nothing hath beene gotten lost opinion maintaine although olde rather little soeuer haue make vse haue time liue especially since entred way neede accomplish iourney imperfect thou stay either midway stand side prefixed place life imperfect honest wheresoeuer thou endest end good intire ought likewise often couragiously end great cause mightiest holde v tullius marcellinus thou knowest familiarly temperate youth quickly olde man surprised sicknesse incurable yet long tedious commanded suffer much began deliberate conclude vpon death intent called together diuers friend euery one naturally timerous gaue counsaile would haue entertained themselues slatterer one studied please gaue aduice thought would best pleasing demanded question friend asticho worthy man may dignifie title wherein worthily deserueth praise man couragious valiant counsailed opinion nobly began thus torment thy selfe friend marcelline thou deliberatedst important affaire great matter liue thy slaues liue beast also great matter die honestly prudently valiantly bethinke thy selfe long time together thou hast done thing meate sleepe lust circle world commeth onely valiant man strong man miserable man haue die master die kill afterwards admonished marcellinus himselfe euen supper ended remainder deuided attend life ended somewhat bequeathed beene attendant whole life time marcellinus man gentle facile disposition liberall euen thing proper good therefore distributed small summes amongst weeping seruants comforted himselfe needed eyther sword shedding bloud three day abstained chamber caused pauillion raised afterwards bath brought thither lay long time caused water oftentimes cast vpon little little fainted failed without certaine pleasure said slight fainting wont bring vnapproued vnto v sometimes subiect sounding haue made relation storie vnto thee know distastefull thee thereby thou shalt vnderstand manner thy friend death neyther difficult miserable although procured owne death yet departed escaped sweetly life neyther storie vnprofitable thee necessitie oftentimes exacteth example wee ofttimes must die yet die yet man ignorant knoweth one day must die time approacheth neere playes coward trembleth weepeth wouldest thou esteeme foolishest men weepe hee liued thousand year agoe foolish weepeth shall liue thousand yeare equall thou shalt neither wast thou two time owne thou art cast vpon point although thou mightest prolong long wouldest thou prolong weepest thou wishest thou thou losest thy labour cease thou hope prayer powerfull change de inies decree firme fixed led eternall powerfull necessitie thou shalt goe thither whither thing goe thinkest thou new matter thou art borne vnder condition thy father hath like hap hath thy mother met withall haue thy predecessor knowne shall befall men thee inuincible successe order force change tyeth traineth thing great number people shall follow thee thou ar dead many shall accompanie thee thou wouldest opinion constant diuers thousand n die thee yet many thousand men beast shall los liues diuers sort death verie tant thou makest difficultie die diddest thou thinke one day thou shouldest attaine thither whither thy iourney alwaies intended iourney without end thinkest thou recount vnto thee present example diuers great personage tell thee young lad memorie young lacedemonian neuer lost hauing scarcely haire vpon chin taken prisoner cried dorique tongue serue confirmed wordes effect soone commanded doe seruile base office commanded emptie close stoole beate brain wall libertie neere man serue st thou rather thy sonne die thus waxe olde idlenes therefore thou shouldest perplexed die couragiously fchildes play thinkest thou thou wilt follow thou shalt enforced make thy power another man wilt thou take vpon thee young man courage say serue miserable wretch thou art slaue vnto men thou art slaue vnto thing thou art slaue thy life life want courage die true seruitude hast thou thing thou shouldest expect thou hast spent pleasure attended retained thee new vnto thee odious vnto thee thou hast surfeited therewith thou knowest taste wine taste methegling skils whether hundreth thousand vessel wine passe thy bladder thou art sacke thou hast often learned oyster mullet fauoreth thou knowest well thy foolish expence hath reserued nothing time com thou hast alreadie deuoured thou art drawne vnwillingly thing besides yeeld thee discontent taken thee thy friend thy country hast thou much euer honored sunne thou wouldst haue deferred thy supper thou wouldest sooner choake vp brightnesse sunne thou couldest hath beene euer done thee worthie light confesse pray thee amitie thou bearest senate palace nature thing withdraweth thee dying spite thy teeth thou leauest shamble thou hast left nothing thou fearest death wouldest thou contemne middest thy pleasure thou desirest liue thou knowest well hast feare death life death caligula passing thorow latine way one ledde prisoner long beard hoarie haires besought giue leaue die said liuest thou yet answer must made vnto death might bring comfort hast thou feare die liuest thou yet saith liue employ selfe manie honest affaire leaue office function life vnwillingly discharge faithfully industriously knowest thou one office life die thou leauest office number dueties thou art accomplish vncertaine determined life short thou hast respect nature thing nestor statilias life short ordeined ingrauen tombe liued ninetie nine yeares seest thou poore woman vaunteth selfe long life could haue supported glorie beene fortune haue liued full one hundred yeares fareth life stageplay skilleth long well hath beene acted importeth nothing place thou makest end life die thou wilt thinke onely make good conclusion epist lxxviii sickenesses yea euen young yeares reliefe found honest study saith friend also remedy remedy contempt death thither calleth lvcilivs disputed many thing deepe manly true griefe impatiently suffered see thee vexed often deerely tendered restrained therein imagined constantly might die patiently might endure losse cause commanded selfe liue yet sometimes liue manly designe tel thee recomforted time thou hand owe life lesse cannot owe haue beene furthered recouerie health meanes friend exhortation watching discourse entertained verie much comforted nothing lucilius best men recrea eth comforteth sicke man otherwise miserable matter thou hast lost thy desire die haue affection liue retire thy selfe therefore vnto remedy physitian shew thee long thou shouldest walk much thou shouldest exercise teach thee follow repose whereunto idle health addicted reade aloude exercise strengthen thy breath passage passage lung stopped saile make thy stomacke desist gentle motion exercise meat thou shouldest vse thou shalt call wine strengthen comfort thee thou shouldest intermit l st prouoke exasperate thy cough teach thee remedy infirmity whole life contemne death nothing distast full flie feare hereof three thing euery sicknes tedious feare death paine bodie intermission pleasure death enough spoken say feare proceedeth infirmity nature sickness haue delayed death many men hath proued securitie seeme perish thou shal die thou ar sicke thou liuest death attend thee thou art recouered wh n thou art freed sicknes thou shalt escape thy death thy infirmitie le v returne incommodity proper sicknes paine reason pain self either spirit hindred performe naturall course changed worst lose force maketh vigorous inciteth v corrupt humor wanteth force flow thither whither passe choaketh depriueth part sense ouer much choaked gout feete hand paine felt ioynts nerues appeased haue stopped stupified part haue tormented first assault sharpnes pricking tormenteth violence extinguished time end paine bee wholly stupified paine teeth eye eares violent bred narrowest straitest part bodie lesse vndoubtedly head violent sooner changed madnesse stupiditie therefore comfort intended griefe thou must necessitie cease feele thou feele ouer much afflicteth ignorant men torment feele body proce deth hence accustomed content themselues good minde entertaine much friendship body therefore great prudent man retireth minde bodie part conuersant better diuiner part onely necessitie sake fraile still plaining thou wilt say tedious thing man want accustomed pleasure abstaine meates suffer thirst hunger confesse vpon first abstinence tedious thing little little desire diminished thing wee desire gouerned restraine themselues themselues thence commeth passe stomack tempered fed rauenous appetite growne hatred thereof desire appetite die themselues grieuous thing want thou hast desisted long moreouer griefe hath intermission remission furthermore man warrantize himselfe euills come preuent remedy threaten menace sicknesse hath precedent signe yea euen returneth custome thou mayest beare infirmitie patiently thou contemnest extremitie wherewith threatneth thee make thine euils greater charge thy selfe complaint paine light opinion aggrauateth contrawise thou begin exhort thy selfe say nothing effect verie little let v endure suddenly haue end thou shalt make light whilest thou suffered man thought euer rise often haue friend bewailed often haue beene giuen ouer physitians haue beene tortured racke much stretched although true yet alreadie passed pleasure takest thou remembrance forepassed paine refresh thy miserie already past considering likewise one adde euill lieth himselfe againe thing agreeable recount euill past also thing naturall reioyce vpon end miserie must therefore driue v two thing one feare future euill remembrance past present appertaineth vnto mee yet shall finde himselfe difficulty may say perhaps heareafter calld minde moue v reioyce let sight force yeeld shall ouercome enforce himselfe griefe hee shall ouercome many dayes doe draw vpon themselues ruine resist thou retirest thy helfe vnder presseth oppresseth thee hangeth ouer thy head menaceth thee followeth thee falleth vpon thee great waight thou makest head thou wilt resist thou shalt repulse many stroaks wound wrestler receiue vpon face whole body yet suffer torment might bee published vertue constancie minde tranquillity spirit wee obtaine euer comba e wee could surmount fortune feele cruell paine shouldest thou otherwise doe feele thou endure sort woman doe euen enemie chargeth strongly flie speedily like sort euils fortune sendeth v charge violently loseth courage playeth coward griefe euer violent wee constant suffer light thing whether haddest thou rather either thy sicknes long violent short long hath intermission giueth place refection giueth much time must end forsake thee depart short violent sicknesse either doe one either suddenly end suddenly mend thee skilleth whether since one paine hath end may also profit thee much diuert thy thought thing dreame thy paine set thine eye thou hast sometimes vertuously honorably done discourse thy self noblest stratagem cast thy remembrance vpon thou hast greatly admired time constant haue ouercome griefe present themselues vnto thy thought stretched legge suffer varix cut perseuered reading booke likewise neuer ceased laugh whilest wrathfull torturer wondering thereat wrought vpon tooles instrument crueltie shall paine ouercome reason hath beene ouercome laughter tell whatsoeuer thou wilt discent rhumes vertue continuall cough maketh man yeeld vp part bowel feuor scorcheth intrailes thirst ioynts feete hand griefe paine hath contracted dislocated flame racke burning glowing place laid vpon swollen wound renue paine make pierce deepe yet cruell yet haue beene haue suffered without complaining small matter hath besought giue ouer toy hath neuer answered trifle hath laughed outright heart wilt thou laugh paine sicknes thou wilt say suffereth doe nothing hinders mee function sicknesse attainteth bodie minde therefore stayeth feete runneth tieth shoomakers hand hindereth smithes hammer thou hast well learned make vse thy soule thou shalt admonish thou shalt teach thou shalt heare thou shalt learne thou shalt demaund thou shalt remember thy selfe beleeuest thou thou doest nothing thou temperate thy sicknesse thou shalt shew sicknesse may ouercome leastwise may endured trust vertue findeth place euen bed selfe armes following warre doe onely testifie valiant heart one may daunted feare man may approue valour courage euen couerlets sleeping cloathes thou hast enough employ thy selfe fight valiantly thy sickenesse constraine thee doe nothing get mastery ouer thee thou shalt serue worthie example great matter glory man come see v sicke cast thou thine eye vpon thy selfe praise thy selfe beside two sort pleasure sicknes hindereth corporall yet taketh away wholly rather thou wilt iudge according truth inciteth pleasure drinking man hath thirst meate tastefull hungered man findeth long abstinence eateth greater appetite touching pleasure minde greater assured physitian forbiddeth patient whosoeuer followeth vnderstandeth well contemneth blandishment sens vnfortunate sicke man hee mixeth wine snow renueth cold drinketh mixed great cup mo sels ice hee breaketh oyster fished lake lucern opened table heareth round hall rumor cooke bring serue meate together fire keepe warme prodigality foolish expence hath already ound inuention intent meat cooled lest pallet mouth already hardened finde nothing hot cooke attendeth supper vnhappie sicke man shall eat disgest hee shall haue whole boare messed seruice sent away course common shal serued pulpes sowles men adayes disdaine see intire assembled dish apart wrong hast thou receiued hereby thou shalt sup like sick man yea hereafter like whole man thing shall easily suffer brothes warme water thing perceiue vertue hath dignified life death hath followed wholly good faith haue decked disguised himselfe continued whether seemed vpon warning vnprepared suddenly dissembling profiteth nothing fained countenance slightly forged externally deceiueth vertue way soeuer turne one thing deceiueable stabilitie lie thin thou shalt easily see thorow thou diligently looke vpon epist lxxx common sort went men whereby soiled owne bloud hee may endure scorching sunne hottest sand day long much easily may mind strengthned inuincibly entertaine shocke fortune end cast ground trode vnder foote may yet raise furnishing without expence whatsoeuer may make thee good thee needest thou make thee good thy better mayest thou deliuer thy selfe seruitude tyrannizeth ouer world slaues themselues seruile condition whatsoeuer borne euen ordure thereof striue meanes cast stocke cattell haue bought pinching owne belly pay liberty wilt thou endeuour charge soeuer obtain libertie thinkest thy selfe free borne man castest thou thine eye vpon thy coffer cannot bought vaine thing therfore cast name libertie table manumission neyther bought sell may haue thou must giue thy selfe good thou must demand thy selfe pensiuenes deeply groundeth selfe breast although trifling affliction befall passeth away like light cloude ioy called rich fained sorrow grieuous rotten much grieuous dare discouer misery amidst thou wilt estimate know wholly take royall ornament much mischiefe lie hidden thereunder speake others thou wilt estimate thy elfe lay apart thy money thy house thy dignitie consider well thy selfe thou art inwardly thou trustest men shew thee thou art epist lxxxi beginning concerneth vngratefull man followeth question whether ought bee thankefull vnto formerly helped v afterwards hurt v disputeth matter subtilly diffusedly distinguisheth diuersly thou complainest thou art fallen vngratefull man hand first time either thanke thy fortune thy diligence although diligence place make thee nothing except make thee wicked thou wouldest auoid perill thou shalt neuer doe man courtesie thus left thy benefit perish another man hand shall perish thine owne better neuer recompenced neuer giuen yea euen bad haruest returne tillage oftentimes whatsoeuer hath beene lost vsuall sterilitie barren ground hath beene redeemed plentie one good yeare great matter finde one gratefull man make triall many vngratefull man hath certaine hand giuing benefit oftentimes deceiued let faile som time assured sea sailed shipwracke past vsurer forbeareth lend hath met banckrupt minde quickly benummed fruitlesse idlenes incontinently forsake whatsoeuer distastefull vnto let thing make th e bountifull thou wilt thing whose euent vncertaine haue happie issue behoueth thee assay oftentimes hereof haue sufficiently spoken book haue written benefit better dispute another point iudgement sufficiently expressed decided whether befriendeth v afterwards hurt th v hath equally benefit whether acquit adde thou wilt hereunto also afterwards hurt v time profited v thou expect seuere sentence iudge would follow rigor law release respectiuely say although iniury bee great yet let remaineth iniury bee giuen benefit hath hurt first hath profited therefore must haue regard time thing manifest need admonition necessarie know willingly hee hath profited vnwillingly harmed benefit iniuries measured minde would giue benefit ouercome shame pertinacie instant suite hope whatsoeuer owing examined minde wherewith giuen neither weighed greatnes thereof wil fro whence proceedeth let coniecture taken away benefit exceeded measure former benefit iniury good man sort make account himselfe deceiue himselfe adde vnto benefit take iniury another would iudge gratiously would doe forget offence remember fauour assuredly act iustice saith giue man appertaineth thereunto benefit acknowledgement iniury reuenge leastwise euill acceptance shall bee true one doth iniury another giueth benefit force iniury extinguished benefit wee ought pardon although desert precedent pardon due hurt v hath done v kindnesse yet take alike prise benefit iniury euery one knoweth owe benefit gratefully imprudent rude base conditioned fellow may restore benefit recompence anon hath receiued knoweth much obliged wiseman onely knoweth rate thing taxed foole spake late although haue good either restoreth lesse oweth doth time conuenient place lauisheth casteth away recompence satisfie wonderfull proprietie word thing custome ancient language designeth thing vnto v effectuall meat duetie teaching lesson thus truely wont say man hath referred requited man fauour requite willingly returne thou owest say hee hath returned thankes demanded vnwilling euery place returne another man hand giue satisfaction say hath remitted benefit hath paid word proper acquit man money lent wayes pleasing subiect referre much say goe acknowledge beare backe vnto thou hast receiued word signifieth voluntarie relation reknowledgement hee hath referred say reknowledged hath appealed sommoned himselfe wiseman examine thing himselfe much hath receiued therefore deny man knoweth reknowledge benefit wiseman man knoweth giue benefit except wiseman one glad giue another receiue man numbreth amongst thing wee seeme name extrauagant strange vnto men greekes call paradox saith man therefore knoweth requite good turne wiseman therefore man knoweth pay creditor hee oweth hee buyeth thing pay price thereof selleth lest blame fall vpon know epicurus saith much metrodorus assuredly saith wiseman onely knoweth reknowledge fauour againe man admireth say wiseman knoweth loue wiseman onely friend requite fauour part loue friendship nay rather vulgar casuall amongst many true friendship againe man wondereth say faith wiseman himselfe said supposest thou hath faith knoweth acknowledge benefit let therefore cease defame v preferred maintained vncredible thing let know true honesty lodged wisemans breast image appearance honest thing common sort man knoweth requite courtesie wiseman foole sort also acknowledgeth conceiueth meanes may let knowledge rather faile learned wiseman compare thing worth worke although made eyther greater lesser time place cause ofttimes rich powred house could thousand penny could giuen season great difference whether thou gauest succourest whether thy liberalitie hath saued engreatned ofttimes giuen small followeth thereby great difference whether man hath taken backe againe giuen receiued benefit end might giue least returne examination thing hath sufficiently debated comparison benefite iniurie good man iudge rightfull yet fauour benefite addicted side consideration person greatest moment affaire thou hast giuen benefite person slaue thou hast done iniurie faith remit whole iniurie appertaine vnto himselfe summe matter shall facile gratious compensation shall suffer himselfe charged account neuer pay benefit iniurie except great constraint incline alwayes side maintaine part desiring acknowledge benefite affecting requite deceiued whatsoeuer willingly receiueth benefite hee restoreth much ioyfull hee payeth hee borroweth much ought content dischargeth himselfe great debt restoring benefite hath receiued obligeth himselfe receiuing also vngratefull men deceiued satisfie creditor ouerplus besides principall suppose vse benefit gratuitall yet increase delay much satisfied much slackly satisfied ingratefull restoreth benefite without vsurie therefore ought haue respect length compare receits laying must labour much v lieth gratefull good truely euen iustice commonly beleeued appertaineth others greatest part thereof returneth selfe man hath profited another hath profited himselfe speake intent wherewith hath succoured would succour hath beene defended would defend good example returneth giueth also euill example doe finally fall vpon author neyther finde pittie suffer iniuries acting haue taught others may done reward vertue lieth put execution vnder hope reward reward good action haue acted gratefull another willingly lend egged thereunto former example might performe thing pleasing agreeable gratefull shall yeelde profit contenteth minde end thou mayest know speake truely haue meanes expresse gratuitie except shewing selfe vngratefull cannot yeeld satisfaction except vnder pretext iniurie ought willingly follow counsaile although danger noted infamie man iudgement stimates vertue man deuoted therunto lost reputation good man would make shipwrack coscience therefore said thou art grat full thine owne good another man happeneth ordinarie common thing recouer giuen thee great contentment proceedeth estate happie soule haue acknowledged benefit wickednesse maketh men miserable vertue maketh bl ssed gratefull vertue thou hast restored vsuall thing attained stimable matter say conscience haue gratefull seizeth minde diuine fortunate contrarie affection vrged great infelicitie man miserable ingratefull dally presently miserable let v therefore flie ingratitude cause yet owns least part wickednesse least feared redoundeth vnto others worst may speake thickest remaineth tormenteth possessor attalus accustomed say malice mischiefe drinketh greatest part owne poyson venom serp nt cast destroy others keepe within themselues without owne preiudice like vnto poison pernicious nourish vngratefull man tormenteth himselfe becommeth leane hateth hath beene giuen must restore extenuateth contrariwise dilat th iniuries augmenteth man miserable forgetteth benefit hath receiued remembreth iniuries contrariwise wisdome speaketh honourably sort benefit commendeth selfe delighteth selfe continuall remembrance thereof euill sort haue one pleasure short whilst receiue benefites whereof wiseman feeleth long perdurable ioy delighteth receyuing hath receiued whereof feeleth continuall immortall pleasure contemneth thing whereby harmed neyther forgetteth negligently willingly turneth thing worst neyther seeketh may impart fault rather layeth blame men error fortune themselues taketh exception neyther men word lookes whatsoeuer falleth excuseth gratious interpretation remembreth iniurie rather benefit setleth remembrance first best changeth minde towards haue well deserued except iniuries surpasse much difference manifest euen though shut eye also onely continueth man greatest iniurie benefite whereas benefit equal iniurie remaineth sparke beneuolence mind euen guiltie man acquit opinion iudges equally diuided alwayes whatsoeuer thing doubtfull humanitie inclineth better wisemans minde whereas merit equall misdeedes forbeare owe desist willing beholding doth wont doe generall acquittance debt notwithstanding satisfie man gratefull except contemne thing maddeth besotteth common sort thou wilt thankefull benefite thou must make account suffer banishment shedde thy bloud fall pouertie see thine owne innocence ofttimes stained subiect base scandlous rumour costeth man small matter approue himselfe gratefull esteeme nothing deerer benefite long aske nothing basely haue receiued askest thou maketh v forget courtesy receiued desire couetousnesse thing would receiue hereafter thinke haue alreadie obtained onely would obtaine hereafter rich honour power thing opinion repute great esteeme base abiect owne value retire v vertue know estimate thing whereof ought make election according common report counsaile nature mother thing haue magnificence wherby draw mindes vnto except accustomed admire therefore praised coueted therefore coueted praised euerie particular man error hath made publique publique shall make errour euerie one euen haue beleeued thing let v also beleeue common sort nothing honest gratefull minde citties nation yea barbarous sauage region subscribe hereunto good euill agree point praise pleasure rather labour som say paine greatest euill may scarcely call euill one shall repute rich chiefest good another shall say found ruine mishap humane life one man rich fortune hath found thing giue great diuersitie opinion world maintaine said one voyce ought thankfull vnto haue deserued well hand nation though different manie thing consent agree herein yet notwithstanding interim repay benefites iniuries chiefest cause euery one hath become vngratefull could sufficiently gratefull furie growne head dangerous thing giue great benefit one thinketh dishonest part requite desireth liue make restitution reserue thy selfe thou hast receiued redemand exact contenteth haue pleasured thee hatred pernicious ashamed hath violated benefite epist lxxxii delicacie effeminate life sluggish idlenesse also ought dedicate studie especiall philosophie defence v feare externall euills yea death selfe deceueth man minde louer right honestie better part thee safetie fortune may doe thee iniurie pertinent matter feare thou shouldest iniurie thy selfe keepe course thou hast begun compose thy selfe habit life temperately effeminately rather thou shouldest liue ill effeminatly interpret thou ill vsually spoken amongst common sort hardly sharply laboriously wont heare liues diuers men praised enuied liueth effeminately say euill little little minde made effeminate groweth remisse negligent vndertaketh similitude idlenesse sloth wherein buried befitting man bee sterne rigid againe delicate also iudgeth one hath vertue blessed yet vertue selfe sufficient blessed life pleasure may make man blessed vertue vertue selfe foolish distinction man denieth vertue time without pleasure thus alwaies ioyned vnto inseparable also sufficient alone absurd said one shall become happie euen vertue alone shall become perfectly happie thereby thing may done doe finde blessed life hath perfect good cannot ouercome thing thus perfectly blessed life th life god hath better thing blessed life diuine life hath nothing wher unto lift vp selfe furthermore blessed life needeth thing euery blessed life perfect blessed blessed life doubtest thou blessed life chiefest good therefore bee chiefest good chiefely blessed life chiefest receiueth augmentation aboue shall chiefe blessed life indeed without chiefest good thou shalt bring one blessed shalt thou make great many innumerable difference chiefest good vnderstand chiefest good speake hath degree aboue selfe lesse blessed another followeth desire life blessed rather owne life bl ssed man preferreth nothing owne life incredible either thing remaineth blessed rather haue rather hee desire better thing certainly much wise much extend himselfe thing best euery manner way desire obtaine blessed still yea ought desire say whence error doth come know blessed life one quality thereof greatnes placeth best estate therefore alike long short broad narrow distributed many place part gathered one esteemeth number measure part taketh therefrom excellent therein excellent blessed life full namely end eating drinking sacietie eateth man eateth lesse difference either full man drinketh lesse difference neither thirst hath liued fewer yeares difference many yeares haue made wel blessed man yeares man thou callest lesse blessed blessed name cannot lessened valiant without feare without feare without sadnesse without sadnesse blessed interrogation endeuour answer thus bring false controuerted true thing namely valiant without feare therefore shall valiant man saith feare euils hanging ouer part mad man one wit valiant man indeed saith feareth moderately altogether without feare speake th se thing againe returned vnto thing smaller vice vnto place vertues feareth indeede seldome lesse wanteth badnes vexed lighter yet think mad feareth euils hanging ouer true saith euils know uils iudgeth dishonesty alone ill ought securely looke vpon danger contemne thing feared men part foole mad man contemne euil thing much one wise much shall feare seemeth saith valiant man shal thrust danger shal fear shall auoyde warinesse feare becommeth therefore doest thou say shall feare death band fire weapon fortune knoweth thing ill seeme thinketh thing eares humane life describe captiuitie beating chaines pouertie tearing asunder member eyther sickenesse iniurie whatsoeuer thou shalt bring hereunto number amongst imaginarie feares thing eared fear ull supposest thou bad whereunto time owne accord must come seekest euill giue place hese thing called euill yeeld owne libertie vnto endure thing libertie perisheth except contemne thing lay yoake vpon v would doubt would become valiant man knew valor vnaduised rashnesse loue danger desire fearfull thing knowledge distinguishing euill fortitude diligent defending selfe patient thing wherein false shew bad thing therefore sword thrust throat valiant man first one part another hewed forth see owne bowel owne armes space end may feele torment set vpon againe fresh bloud trickleth downe dried bowel wilt thou say man doth feare doth feele griefe certainely feeleth paine vertue putteth sense man feareth vnconquered high looketh vpon dolour thou demaundest minde vnto vnto exhort sicke friend euill hurteth hurteth maketh worse dolour pouertie make worse therefore bad false saith propounded thing hurt doth also make worse tempest storme hurt pilot notwithstanding make worse certaine stoicks thus answer pilot made worse tempest storme thing purposed cannot effect keepe course worse made skill work arist telian therefore saith pouertie dolour whatsoeuer like thing shall shal take vertue shall hinder working thereof rightly said except condition pilot wiseman vnlike purpose leading life without faile effect assayeth doe doe thing aright purpose pilot without faile bring ship hauen seruile art ought performe promise wisedome mistresse goue nesse art doe serue wi dome commandeth ouer life iudge must answere another sort namely neyther skill gouernour made worse tempest yet administration art gouernour hath promised prosperous successe vnto thee profitable endeuour skill gouerne ship appeareth much force fortune hath hindred hath beene able say neptune ship neuer right hath satisfied skill tempest hindereth worke pilot successe therefore sayest thou doth thing hurt pilot hindereth entring port causeth endeuours vaine eyther beareth backe detaineth disarmeth hurteth pilot one doth saile otherwise doth much hinder shew pilot skill euery one say pilot calme thing hinder ship pilot pilot two person pilot hath one common haue gone aboard ship wherein himselfe also passenger proper gouernour tempest hurteth passenger pilot furthermore art pilot anothers good appertaineth carrieth art physitian appertaineth doth cure wisedome common good proper ownes selfe doth liue therefore peraduenture pilot hurt whose promised seruice others let tempest wiseman hurt pouertie dolour tempest life workes hindered pertaine men alwayes himselfe indeed greatest fortune hath opposed selfe vnto manageth businesse wisdome selfe wisdome haue said anothers owne good furthermore indeed hindred profite men necessity presse pouertie hindred teach commonwealth may managed teacheth thing pouertie managed worke extended life long thus fortune thing excludeth act wiseman doth verie thing whereby fobidden doe thing fit chance gouernour bad ouercomm r good say hath exercised himselfe sheweth vertue well prosperous aduerse affaire neyther looketh vpon matter thereof vpon selfe therefore neyther pouertie dolour thing turneth backe vnskilfull driueth headlong hindereth hast thou rather pressed maketh vse iuorie phidias know make image made brasse marble vnto thou hadst offered baser matter would haue made one thereof could mad best wiseman shew vertue may wealth pouertie shall able countrie banishment commaunder souldier sound weake fortune soeuer shall entertaine performe memorable thing thereby certain tamer wilde beast teach fiercest creature terrifie man meete suffer yoake contented haue shaken fiercenesse tame euen keepe companie master vseth often thrust hand lion kisse keeper commandeth tyger aethiopian player commandeth elephant fall vpon knee walke vpon rope wiseman skilfull subdue euill thing dolour vsed furie great moderation pietie admirable left countrie defended eyther scipio must depriued rome rome libertie nothing saith derogate lawes nothing decree amongst citizen let equall right countrie vse benefit without haue beene cause also argument libertie vnto thee depart haue increased expedient chuse admire greatnesse minde departed voluntarie banishment disburthened citie matter brought
