city old washed euery day armes legges worke gathered filth ouer washed euery nine day place one say apparant vncleane thinkest thou smelled warre labour playing men neate bathe found forth filthy men shrub although old may translated another place necessarie v learne bee old men none planteth orchard oliues another man haue seene speake namely orchard three foure yeares old plentifull fall leafe yeeld forth fruit yea also tree couer thee hath beene slow make shade yong nephewes vnbore virgil saith beheld might spoken truely seemely neither desired teach husbandman delight read passe thing adde hereunto needfull reprehend day spring bean dunged limons set millet doth new yeares care beget set one time whether springtime sowing thou mayest iudge hence moneth iune wherein write thing vnto thee neare vnto iuly day saw gathering bean sowing millet returne orchard oliues saw disposed two sort remoued trunkes great tree boughes cut brought one foot length bodie tree root cut head onely left whence hang besmeared dung put hole afterward heape earth troad pressed downe nothing h saith effectuall stamping hard namely excludeth cold winde lesse also shaken suffereth springing root go forth lay hould vpon ground needfull tender yet lightly stick therunto light tossing also vp downe plucketh vp againe scarce tree vntill root plentifully hide selfe ground euery matter made naked saith new root doe come stocke tree ought stand aboue vpon earth three foure feete presently garnished neither shall great part thereof old oliuegardens withered scorchingly drie also hath beene another manner planting kinde haue set ground strong boughes hard barke ccustomed tender tree come plant haue rough illfauoured thing also haue seene old vine translated shrub small string also may gathered vine largely bee spread abroad also may take roote body thereof haue seen th set onely moneth februarie also moneth march layed hold vpon embraced elmes none owne tree speake great plentie externall thing admonition vnto others wils deedes might bee follow small disputation wherein approoueth casuall thing amongst good onely may called commodity haue suffered shipwracke haue gone aboard shalt take gold pitcher also viper therefore doth pitcher giue gold vnto containeth viper giueth gold although haue viper sort gaine made sacriledge sacriledge dishonest wicked hath gaine euen pitcher viper bad gold lieth viper sacriledge heinous deed bad gaine againe argued condition thing vnlike take away gold without viper heere cannot make gaine without sacriledge gaine added mingled wickednesse whilest obtaine fall many euill thing good whilest wee obtaine rich fall many bad thing therefore rich good proposition saith hath two signification one whilest obtaine rich fall many bad thing many bad thing doe fall whilest also wee would obtaine vertue one whilest hee hath sailed studie hath suffered shipwracke another hath beene taken another signification thus whereby fall euils good consequent proposition rich pleasure fall euils rich fall many euils rich onely good bad yee onely say good furthermore saith yee grant rich haue vse amongst commodity doe ye number reason shal profit indeed many discommodities come v men answere thus vnto thing ye erre impute discommodities vnto rich hurt man either doth folly hurt euery man wickednesse men euen sword killeth man yet weapon doth kill rich therefore doe hurt thee rich hurt vnto thee posidonius speaketh better suppose saith rich cause euill thing themselues doe thing prouoke doe one efficient cause necessitie forthwith must hurt another precedent cause rich haue precedent cause pu fe vp minde bring forth pride procure enuy farre forth estrange minde fame money yea hurt delighteth v good thing ought want manner blame pure doe corrupt solicite minde lift vp indeed dilate without swelling thing good cause confidence rich cause boldnesse thing good cause magnanimitie rich insolencie insolencie nothing else false shew greatnesse sort sayest thou rich good also bad bad thing themselues hurt haue said haue efficient cause haue precedent cause indeed one prouoking drawing mind thereunto shew forth likely shape good credible men vertue also hath precedent cause vnto enuie many wisdome many iustice enuied neither selfe hath cause like vnto contrarily likely shape ver ue set mindes men may call vnto loue admiration thereof posidonius saith must reason thus thing giue neither greatnesse confidence securitie minde good rich good health thing like vnto cause none thing therefore good yea also hee enforceth reason sort thing bad giue neither greatnesse confidence securitie minde contrarily beget insolencie pride arrogancie casuall thing enforced therefore good reason saith shall commodity indeed one condition whether thing may selfe whether anie thing may time time hath begun world whether also world somewhat hath beene time hath also beene innumerable question concerning mind whence may beginneth long may whether may passe one place another may change house may cast one forme liuing creature another may serue sent forth may wander whole world whether bodie doe hath ceased doe thing v shee vse libertie shall flee denne whether may forget former thing begin know sel e led bodie hath departed high whatsoeuer part diuine humane affaire thou shalt comprehend thou shalt wearied huge abundance thing superfluous implement learning bee willing know may sufficient kinde intemperancie following liberall art maketh men troublesome full word vnseasonable pleasure themselues therefore learning necessarie thing haue learned superfluous thing dydimus grammarian wrote foure thousand bookes wretched read many superfluous thing booke sought country homer true mother aenaeas whether anacreon led lustfull drunken life whether sappho whore vnlearned thou shouldest know goe deny life long also thou shalt come owne men shew many thing ax cut praising learned man costeth great expence time great pouertie euen vnto hath made rich haue ceased possesse thing whilest would haue owne first men begotten without corruption followed nature captaine law according iudgement better part nature submit necessarie thing cost simple care men labour delight thou wilt desire workemen thou follow nature would haue v bee entangled hath furnished v vnto whatsoeuer thing hath constrained v cold intollerable selfe fertill without labour large vse people robbed whatsoeuer nature brought forth pleasure lesse haue found shew inuention another neither could either much little one diuided amongst agree yet deceit vnto yet wisemen sith name greatest worke notwithstanding deny men high spirit freshly sprung god world yet wasted strength sent forth better thing wit valiant prepared labour wit consummated withdrawne earthquake water fire mortall thing condemned perish therefore neither death infamie feared man ovr liberalis sad fire wherewith colony lyon burned vp related vnto accident might moue man much one loueth country exceeding much thing causeth seeke resolution one minde namely hath exercised thing supposed might feared wonder vnthought mischiefe almost vnheard hath beene without feare sith without example fire hath vexed many city hath destroyed none also fire set vpon house enemy hand faileth many place although forthwith bee raised vp againe notwithstanding seldome doth deuoure nothing left sword scarce also time hath beene grieuous pernicious earthquake ouerthrow whole townes lastly neuer hath beene terrible fire nothing remained another burning one night hath laide along many faire workes euerie one might haue made seuerall city haue beene famous falleth forth great peace could indeed feared warre beleeue armes quiet euery securitie spread abroad throughout whole earth lyon pointed gaule sought fortune hath permitted publiquely hath afflicted feare suffer great thing hath space ruine thereof onely one night betweene great citie none conclude longer telling thee hath perished perishing liberalis thing incline affection firme vndaunted euils thereof neyther striken without cause vnexpected thing doe aggrauate noueltie addeth weight misery neyther man hath grieued thing hath admired therefore nothing ought vnprouided v minde sent vnto thing wee must thinke whatsoeuer accustomed whatsoeuer may done fortune cannot take away euen florishing cannot much assault shake much shineth beautifully hard difficult vnto alwayes one way runneth vpon v sometimes calleth owne hand vpon v sometimes contented owne strength shee findeth forth danger without author time expected pleasure themselues cause dolour doe arise warre ariseth middest peace helpes securitie passe ouer feare enemie friend foe fellow calmes summer driuen sudden tempest greater winter storm without enemie suffer hostile thing great felicitie hath found forth cause slaughter vnto self thing faile disease set vpon temperate consumption vpon strongest punishment vpon innocent tumult vpon secret chance chuseth new thing forgetting reneweth owne strength whatsoeuer long continuance many labour much fauour god hath builded vp one day scattereth dissipateth gaue long delay euils hasting hath said day houre moment time sufficeth ouerthrowing empire comfort weakenesse affaire thing repaired great speed finished increasings goe softly make hast losse nothing priuate nothing publique firme well destiny men city turned feare neerly attendeth choysest pleasure although occasion trouble outwardly mischiefes breake forth place least expected kingdomes stood ciuill forraine warres ruined without opposition commonwealth could support felicitie al thing therfore thought vpon minde confirmed thing may happen thinke vpon exile torment warres sickenesses shipwrackes fortune may bereaue thee thy countrey thy countrey thee cast thee desert make place desolate wherein people almost stifled thronging let whole condition man life set eye let v consider mindes would oppressed neither stupified vnusuall misery new much happeneth oftentimes much may part fall must wholly apprehend inconstancie affaire world often haue city asia achaia bin ruinated one earthquake many city syria much hath earth deuoured macedon often hath miserie afflicted cyprus often hath paphos beene buried owne ruines oftentimes haue wee heard newes destruction whole city amongst rumour ordinarily spread small part thing let v therefore erect selues aduersities whatsoeuer thing may happen let v know great reported rich citie ornament prouinces inserted receiued built vpon hill ouerhigh burned time also shall consume foundation city thou hearest praised magnficence rich seest thou achaia foundation famous city consumed nothing extant wherby may knowne time past haue beene onely thing framed hand doe perish onely thing man art industry hath planted doth time ouerturne mountain top moulder whole region come nought place couered sea stood far sight fire hath consumed mountaines hollow wherof flamed time past hath eaten away highest promontory sollace sailers brought proudest hill humble shoars workes nature vexed therefore ought suffer patiently destruction city thing stand must fall end remaineth thing whether windes shut internall force blast haue shaken weight vnder held force flouds secret hath throwne downe thing stand violence flame hath broken ioyning together ground oldnesse nothing safe hath little little ouercome vnwholesomnesse skie hath cast people situation hath corrupted desert long thing reckon vp wayes destiny one thing know workes mortall men condemned mortalitie liue amongst thing perish like comfort apply liberalis set fire certaine burning loue countrey peraduenture consumed might better builded vp oftentimes iniurie hath made place greater fortune many thing haue fallen might rise higher greater timagines enemy prosperitie citie say grieued firing rome one thing knew better would rise againe burned citie also like striue greater certaine thing may restored haue lost wish may longlasting builded better signes lucke longer age come hundreth yeare scarce colonie beginning thereof age scarce long enough man lead forth frequencie waxed well againe oportunitie place notwithstanding hath suffered grieuous chance within space olde age man therefore let minde framed vnderstanding patience lot let know nothing fortune dare doe hath right empire hath doe rule doe city doth men none thing fretted haue entred world wherein men liue lawes pleaseth obey pleaseth depart way thou wil angry thing foolishly vniustly resolued vpon thy selfe necessitie tyeth highest lowest therefore returne fauour de tiny thing dissolued cause thou measure v tombes monument vnequall bignesse doe compasse way dust maketh equall borne vnlike die alike say citties inhabitant citties well ardea taken rome maker mankinde hath distinguished v birth famousnesse name longer come end mortall thing ambition saith depart thou let law thing presse earth alike suffering thing man fraile another man certaine owne vntill next day alexander king macedonian began like wretch learne geometry might know little earth whereof possessed little thus say like wretch vnderstand hee beare false sirname great small thing thing deliuered subtile learned diligent attention mad man could perceiue sent thought beyond ocean sea teach saith easie thing master said thing alike difficult vnto thinke thou nature thing saith thing whereof thou complainest vnto easie thing giuen vnto none whosoeuer shall make thing easie vnto himselfe vprightnesse minde meet thou grieue thirst hungry waxe olde longer stay amongst men befall vnto thee thou sicke lose somewhat doe perish notwithstanding cause thou mayest beleeue thing make noise thee none thing bad nothing intollerable hard feare consent vnto thing thus thou fearest death report foolish man fearing word demetrius accustomed elegantly say speech vnskilfull much esteemed breaking winde difference saith difference curing mad man madnesse restored health wee haue excluded false opinion presently apprehend ought doe yet admonition would confirme right apprehension iudgement haue good euils likewise man doe good may befall man obedience commaundement authoritie serue doth admonition authoritie great vse consequently admonition vertue diuided two part contemplation truth action institution teacheth contemplation admonition action iust action exerciseth sheweth vertue perswadeth profiteth act likewise profite admonisheth therefore vpright action necessary vertue admonition sheweth iust action followeth admonition necessary two thing greatly fortifie minde assurance truth confidence admonition produceth credite giuen beleeued minde conceiueth high hope filled confidence admonition therefore superfluous marcus agrippa man great vnderstanding onely happy publique good amongst raised ciuill warres wont auow hee much indebted sentence concord small thing increase discord greatest ruined saith made become good brother sure friend sentence familiarly entertained minde forme part philosophie consisteth like sentence doe like part vertue consisteth discipline another action thou must learne thou hast learned thou must confirme action onely decree wisemen profitable also precept restraine oblige affection edict philosophie saith diuided science habite minde hath comprehended thing knoweth ought auoide yet wise except spirit transformed thing hath learned third part consisting precept composed two precedent decree habite consequently superfluous make vertue complete whereas two sufficient reckoning consolation vnnecessary also consisteth neyther exhortation perswasion neyther argumentation taketh originall habite composed strong minde although part proceede habitude minde best habite minde one furthermore thou sayest respecteth perfect man one hath attained summe humane felicitie man attaineth slowly meane must shew vnperfect man yet one toward way ought hold action may wisedome may addresse selfe without admonition considering hath already ledde spirit outward cannot moued right way touching feeble neede conductor may say vnto thou shalt shun thou shalt doe besides expect time wherein himselfe may know best done shall meane space erre erring shall hindred attayning whereby may contented himselfe must therefore gouerned till begin able gouerne himselfe child taught forme letter finger held hand directed led teach fashion counterfeit letter commanded follow example reforme writing minde strengthned instructed proposing example vnto may follow thing whereby approued part philosophy superfluous furthermore demaunded whether alone sufficeth make wiseman answere question another time present omitting argument doth appeare vnto v neede aduocate may giue v instruction contrary precept people man cannot speake thing toucheth v wish v good hurt v also curse v imprecation impresseth v false feares loue others spoyleth v desiring prosperitie driueth v good forraigne wandring vncertaine whereas might draw felicity selues say wee permitted follow right way parent seruants draw v vnto euill man erreth himselfe onely spreadeth follie amongst neighbour learneth likewise therefore vice common sort euery priuate man people amongst conuerseth hath giuen making others badde becommeth badde himselfe hee hath learned worse afterwards teacheth one knew wicked gathered put together great heape iniquitie made discouered let bee therefore guide may pull thee eare driue thee bruite citties reclaime thee flattery common sort thou abusest thy selfe thou thinkest vice borne v steale vpon v ingested v let v therefore represse opinion buzze eares frequent admonition nature neither tyeth obligeth v vice hath ingendered v intire free nothing might incite auarice hath placed open sight hath put golde siluer vnder feete kickt trode vpon whatsoeuer kickt trode vpon hath addressed face towards heauen would beholde feare tribute life neither hope thou lucillius neither demand thou exemption furie paine bladder hath tormented thee banquet hath little pleasure continuall passion ome neerer thou hast beene put feare thy life knowest thou desiring old thou desirest incommodities ordinarie long life long way finde dust dirt raine would liue feele discommoditie whatsoeuer effeminate speech becommeth man clodivs corrupted bribe adultery force conscience offence condemned also punished internall whip gnawe thou abusest thy selfe lucilius thou thinkest dissolutenesse neglect good manner vice euery man reproueth age wherin liueth imperfection age time men blamed age hath beene free vice thou beginnest estimate libertie loosenesse euery time ashamed say neuer world offend openly cato man beleeue mony stirring iudgement wherein clodius accused adulterie secretly committed caesar wife violating ceremony sacrifice said made people sight whereof men much exempted onely woman admitted attend picture male beast couered likewise money giuen iudges villainous rest exacted way salarie licence violate matron young nobleman sinne committed absoluing acting crime guilty adultery diuided adultery neyther secured life time made iudges like vnto himselfe thing done iudgement wherein cato nought else gaue testimonie cause set downe ciceroes word thing exceedeth beleefe hee sent person required hand promised intreated gaue good god wickednesse iudges ouerplus paine lay passed night certain woman young nobleman brought vnto haue minde enquire much money receiued succeeded wilt thou haue wife seuere fellow cato one rich say crassus thou shalt lie thou hast committed adultery condemne crime faire lasse thou desirest shall come vnto thee promise thee shall accompany thee night neyther delay good man many famous worthy men must consent herein make glorie consisteth diuers men iudgements namely distant therefore good glory saith commendation giuen good men good man commendation speech speech voice signifieth something voice although good man voice goodnesse whatsoeuer good man doth alwayes good clappeth hand hisseth neither man say clapping hissing good although applaud admire whatsoeuer snee ing coughing therefore glory good word tell v whether good concerneth praiser praised praiser much thou shouldest say another man good health mine praise worthy honest action therefore good concerneth praiser action commeth v praised question answere briefely obiections first question day whether good may composed thing distant party haue reason secondly praise desireth many suffrage may contented one good man iudgement onely competent iudge say resemble good saith shal fame depend vpon estimate one man infamie tied misreport another man glory also saith vnderstand spread largely requireth consent many men condition different good man haue good opinion estate good men haue like thought knew would iump opinion one man haue one iudgement cannot differ doe necessarily agree opinion therfore one thinketh importeth much spoken cannot opinion opinion one man saith sufficeth giue glory renowne vnto another answere herein opinion one auaileth much euery one demanded answere alike place iudgements tha disagree diuers affection different thou shalt finde thing world doubtfull light suspected thinkest thou men mindes alike vndoubtedly man opinion alwayes truth pleasing good truth neither changeth vigor colour amongst wicked falsity wherein accord nothing inconstancie repugnancie discord lie praise saith voice spread aire word meriteth name good say praise commendation good men deliuered good men referre word sentence although good man hold peace yet iudgeth man worthy commendation hee commended besides difference betwixt two word praise praising requireth explication deliuering funerall oration vse word praise praysing consisteth wordes saying one worthy praise vnderstand word iust iudgements men rather speech praise shall right opinion without speaking priseth himselfe good man furthermore haue said praise hath relation thought vnto word expresse praise conceiued inwardly vttered knowledge many men praiseth iudgeth ought praise tragique poet saith magnificent thing praised praiseworthy man meaneth praiseworthy man worthy praise another poet time saith praise nourisheth art speaketh flatterie corrupteth art nothing hath much soiled eloquence study addicted eare applause people fame would published bruited praise would respecteth wordes contenteth selfe iudgement accomplished onely amongst silent likewise amongst oppose themselues declare difference betweene praise glorie glory consisteth many men iudgments praise good men returneth good praise saith eyther praised praiser one great good praised nature hath created louer men reioyce haue done well one contentment haue met men take pleasure vertuous act might haue done many thus disposed good enioy haue part also mind think men good mine especially men cause good proceeds vertue euery occasion vertue good could enioy vertuous true praise common good praiseth praised certainly iust sentence good honour iudge partie obtaineth profit cause doubtest thou justice good debtor creditor iustice equity praise man meriteth praise consequently common good praiseth praised haue sufficiently answered cauillers purpose sow subtilties draw philosophie majestie straight farre better goe open direct way finde pathes loose selues therein constrained returne backe great trouble preiudice disputation nought else pastime men would cunningly beguile one another rather tell mee naturall thing extend minde infinitie great generous thing man mind endureth circumscribed limit common god first acknowledgeth himselfe natuturally bred region land whatsoeuer ephesus alexandria countrey greatest extent peopled whatsoeuer inuironed continent heauen countrey say round composed sea land mixed together within extent ayre seperateth vniteth thing celestiall terrestriall many god disposed due order intentiue execute commission secondly endureth circumscribed yeares year saith mine age locked vp great wit time thorow humane thought hath pierced day must make seperation betwixt bodie soule thus vnited see leaue body found restore selfe vnto god neyther without sort feele selfe detained heauie earthly prison delayes mortall life make entrance better longer life euen mother wombe containeth v nine monthes prepareth v remaine therein alwaies another place soemeth striue hand foot soone readie breathe liue aire meanes space time betwixt infancy age aspire vnto another birth nature another originall another estate thing attendeth v cannot yet suffer heauen mean great extent betweene v cause beholde thou setled eye determined houre last vnto soule onely body whatsoeuer good world thou beholdest thee look baggage moueables inne must passe nature leaueth v naked issue world vpon entry thou hast brought nothing thee neyther shalt thou carry away thing thee nay thou must leaue world great part thou hast brought thee thou shalt spoyled skin inclosed thee last cloth couered thee thou shalt leaue thy flesh bloud dispersed thorow thy whole body thy bone nerues shall taken thee supporter many fraile fleeting thing day thou fearest much thou callest thy last birth day eternity lay aside thy burthen delayest thou long since thou forsookest body say thy mother womb thou wert hidden enter world striuest thou dalliest thou thy mother thou wert borne laboured hardly deliuered thee thou sighest thou weepest infant doth soone borne wert thou pardoned thou wert new born without knowledge thing issued hote soft couch thy mother entrailes thou hast breathed freer aire feeling thy selfe touched hand somewhat hard thou wert soft tender couldest endure without cry wondered thou remainedst astonished daunted amongst many thing vnseene considering thou neither haddest knowledge apprehension thing let new thing vnto thee seperated wherof time thou hast beene portion acquit thy selfe willingly member superfectlesse lay aside body wherein thou hast inhabited long time shall cut piece deuoured brought nothing art thou agrieued go world cau e infolde infant mother wombe shall broken rotten louest thou earthly good thine foulds wrap thee day come vnfould draw thee company villenous stinking wombe fly wor forward courage estrange thy selfe thing yea thing necessarie done meditate somewhat high sublime one day secret nature shall discouered vnto thee obscuritie shall cleared shining light shall reflect vpon thee euery side thinke thy selfe great brightnesse many celestiall body mixe light together faire cleere shall neuer obscured darkenesse heauen shall glorious one part another day night reuolutions region ayre thou wilt confesse thou hast liued darknesse thou shalt freely see whole light thou beholdest obscurely thorow th se narrow circle thine eye farre yet without astonishment wilt thou say diuine light thou shalt see place thought suffer soules gather rust durt hindereth v eyther humbling heart low raising high shee maintaineth god witness thing approued depend haue day eternitie alwayes eye whosoeuer hath apprehension hereof soule hath feare army trumpet amazeth nothing threat may make feare expecteth death without feare whereas esteemeth soule remaineth subsisteth aboad prison bodie departing dissipated ceaseth demeane himselfe sort death pretendeth serue suruiue som sort althogh taken sight yet man great vertue country glorie wondrous value come memorie thinke much good example profite v thou shalt finde memorie worthy personage lesse profitable v presence epist ciii malice treason men amongst themselues yet doe thou lay apart thou curteous willing doe good vnto men regardest thou euery side thing may befall thee happily may chance vnto thee meane fire ruine inconueniences happen vnto v lay waite v rather consider auoyde thou danger attend surprise v casualty rare although grieuous suffer shipwrack ouerturned coach man daily man expecteth danger prepare thy selfe euill contemplate open eye euill frequent obstinate neyther one flattering tempest threatneth riseth house cracke fall smoake foretelleth fire kindling mischiefe man doth sudden neerer euill secretly hidden thou art deceiued thou trust look meete thee haue face men heart sauage beast first assault beast violent cannot auoyde nothing necessitie moueth hurt either hunger feare enforced fight man taketh pleasure destroy man thinke thou danger man end thou mayest thinke office man consider one end thou offended end thou offend reioyce euery man profit sorie harmes bethinke thy selfe thou oughtest performe auoid liuing thus gettest thou thou mayest alwayes auoide men doe thee outrage thou canst chuse deceiued especially endeuour thy selfe take thy retreat philosophie shee defend thee bosome sanctuarie either shalt thou safe safer men iostle one another except walke way al thing beware boast thy philosophie many men proudly boasting vainely vaunting thereof haue perished let suffice thee shee spoileth thee thy vice reprocheth men abhorre publike manner behaue selfe modestly without causing men thinke condemneth shee doth selfe man may wise without making shew thereof without enuying man epist ciiii sicknesse cure charitie wife changed abode recreation sake hereupon excellent discourse vpon trauaile profitable selfe except made minde let amended affection cut euery station estate pleasing likewise another kinde trauaile haue recourse vnto ancient great men behold thought imitate rooteth vice planteth vertues inuiteth lvcillivs fled grange momentanum thinkest thou shun citie feuor began seaze vpon alreadie laid hold forthwith therefore commanded coach made readie although wife paulina physitian hauing touched pulse finding arterie beating incertainly contrary nature said beginning feuor yet notwithstanding resolued selfe set forward remembring speech gallio lord master achaia feeling himselfe surprised feuor forthwith embarked himselfe cry sicknesse proceeded aire country bodie tould paulina recommended health vnto whereas know soule translated liueth mine content sake begin haue care health although old age hath fortified diuers difficulty yet present begin lose benefit age thought old man yong man ouer much tendered cannot require wife loue entirely doth hath begged much hand cherish selfe tenderly otherwise must giue way vnto honest affection sometimes also vrgent cause require soule honor friend recalled though torment retained betwixt teeth vertuous man bound liue long liketh long must without respect wife friend laboureth nought else end life demaundeth death ouer delicate let soule haue commandement ouer selfe profit obliged requireth shunne death onely owne cause likewise shee vpon point dislodge leaue bodie reenter againe end may enabled doe friend seruice argument great minde returne vnto life another man good diuers great personage haue many time done also esteeme great humanitie maintaine old age intentiuely fairest fruit whereof consisteth maintenance health liuing orderly accustomed thou knew thing either pleasant profitable wished thy friend moreouer great ioy profit therein greater contentment may dearely beloued man wife cause thou shouldest become louing thy selfe paulina therfore cannot impute feare vnto mine also demandest thou therfore successe determination going country soone gotten foggie aire rome stinck smookie chimneyes thereof stirred power forth whatsoeuer pestilent vapour held inclosed felt alteration disposition much thinkest thou strength encreased came vnto grange sooner entered mead beganne rush vpon meate strong appetite thus therefore present haue recouered selfe leannesse bodie hath securitie health beginneth decline vanished beginne studie diligently place yeelds little furtherance thereunto minde assistant selfe list amidst affaire trouble may haue place retirement maketh choice place idleth vainly shall euery finde nooke wherein restraine himselfe reported socrates hearing certaine man complaine lost time trauelling heere returned answere without cause hath befallen thee thou trauelledst thy selfe happie would diuers men could wander themselues first sollicite corrupt terrifie selues auaileth passe sea change city thou wilt flie thing wherewith thou art vrged thou needest another place become another man put case thou wert come athens rhodes chuse citie thou pleasest skilleth manner haue thou shalt carry thither thine owne thinkest thou rich make men happie pouertie yea appearance presumption thereof lamentable opinion shall incessantly torture thee although thou possessest much yet another man hath thou shalt seeme vnto thy selfe much poorer much rich supposest thou honour good shall grieue thee man made consul one hath twice enioyed office shal vex thee thou shalt finde publike register man name oftener thine owne great shall furie thy ambition one shall outstrip thee thou wilt thinke marcheth behind thee wilt thou suppose death extreame euill nothing euill feare danger suspitions wil terrifie thee thou shalt incessantly tormented dreames shadowes shall profit thee thou hast escaped many city greece made thy way flight thorow middest thine enemy peace selfe shall affright thee thou shalt wayes trust thing sured soone thy minde shall shaken soone hath gotten custome entertaine improuident feare thou art disposed entertaine repose contentment thy selfe shunneth flieth stroake turne backes affliction haue greater holdfast v thou wilt iudge grieuous euill lose friend thou hast loued whereas meane great folly bewaile weepe leaues thy faire shadowing tree adorne thy house fallen shaken ground much flourisheth one delighteth thee death shake downe one day morrow wee suffer patiently fall losse leaues tree spring againe oughtest thou endure losse thy friend thou conceitest ioyes thy life shall restored although borne shall whilest remained world neither shalt thou thy selfe euery day euery houre changeth thee others nourishment appeareth easily heere lieth hidden done openly carried away wee selues secretly stolne away wilt thou thinke none thing wilt thou apply remedy wound send vnto thy selfe cause thy care hoping something despairing thou beest wise mixe one neither hope thou without desperation neither despaire without hope trauell profit man selfe tempereth pleasure bridleth desire pacifieth displeasure breaketh vntamed assault loue conclude disburtheneth minde euill neither gi eth iudgement shaketh error detaineth minde short time entertaineth noueltie thing see child stand gaze behold thing haue seene conclude going comming doth make inconstant thought light stirring height euill prouoketh altereth selfe sort earnestly trauelled countrey depart thence hastily manner skipping bird flie thence swiftly came thither trauell giue thee knowledge nation shew thee new formes mountaines spacious vnaccustomed plaines valleyes watered vvith running riuers floud hath certaine notable propertie nilus vvhich encreaseth sommer tygris vvhich loo selfe hauing made long circuit vnder earth reentereth h channell reneweth swift spacious course hovv meander exercise play poet maketh infinite vvindlas turnes retures oftentimes discharging selfe owne channell streameth along bedde neighbour flouds returneth voyage neither make thee healthie vvise must conuerse amongst study amongst author wisdome wee may learne wee desire know seeke yet vnfound meanes must minde bee redeemed miserable seruitude set libertie long thou shalt bee ignorant vvhich thou shouldest flie follovv vvhich necessarie superfluous vvhich iust honest may bee said trauaile errour thi turmoyle vvill comfort thee nothing thou wanderest accompanied thy affection thy euils follow thee would god might follow thee thee thou bearest thy back thou leadest cause euery way weigh thee downe feare thee equall incommodities sicke man must seeke good medicine new country hath one broken leg put member ioynt get coach embarkes ship calleth physitian end may vnite broken set ioynt place dislocated end thinkest thou changing thy country thou mayest heale thy bruised broken minde many place euill great cured carried hither thither trauell neither maketh physitian orator neither art science learned changing place sort wisdome greatest treasure others learned trauels trust mee iourn may retire thee apart thy desire thy displeasure thy feares nkind troopes would trauell flocke thither long euils presse thee macerate thee whilest thou wanderest land sea long thou bearest cause thine euils thee wonderest thou thy flight profit th thee nothing man thing thou fliest mend thy selfe therefore shake thy burthen leastwise containe thy desire within compasse roote wickednesse thy minde thou wilt haue thy trauels delightfull heale thy companion auarice cling vnto thee long thou liuest couetous base companion pride clea vnto thee long thou conuersest proud man thou wilt neuer lay aside thy crueltie hangman company fellowship adulterors enkindle thy lust thou wilt discharged vice thou must retire thy selfe farre euill example auarice dissolution crueltie fraud enemy approching thee wound thee grieuously within thee acquaint thy selfe better sort liue cato laelius bero thou take liking liue among grecian conuerse desert hill without baggage suffered want drink soultered armor often occasion offered water last drunke seest thou honour authority may contemned day repulsed office stood day played ball marketplace seeke another man ruine thou shalt finde hope enuy hatred feare contempt contempt lightest insomuch many haue lien hidden therein safeguard liues whomsoeuer man contemneth kicketh passeth man purposely hurteth contemned person man diligently euen prostrate earth conflict ouerslipped standeth assaulted thou shalt frustrate hope wicked thou hast nothing may prouoke another man wicked desire thou possesse nothing worthy hauing thing greatest price desired although least knowne therefore shalt thou flie enuy thou makest shew thou boast thy fortune thou knowest enioy thy selfe touching hatred proceedeth offence thou shalt auoide thus prouoking man without cause whence common sense defend thee hath beene dangerous many men haue hatred enemy meanes feared shall liue mean humble condition men shall know thou art one may offend without perrill let thy reconcilement easie certaine feared dangerous home abroad thy seruants thy child man hath power enough hurt adde hereunto feared feareth man could terrible securely contempt remaineth meanes whereof power contemned contemned would ought incommoditie hereof good art doe dis usse friendship powerfull mightie man shall expedient thee apply thy selfe entangle thy selfe feare lest remedie cost thee danger would yet nothing shall profite thee quiet conferre least many thy selfe certaine charming discourse creepeth man bosome flattereth otherwise drunkennesse loue betrayeth secret let man conceale hath heard neither let man speake much hath heard conceale matter reueale author euery one hath friend trusteth much trusted himselfe content himselfe one man eares set watch lip shal addresse himselfe people secret becommeth rumour great part curitie doe nothing wickedly cholericke reuengefull men leade confused troublesome life feare much hurt neither hy time quiet feare doubtfull haue done conscience suffereth doe nought else compelleth ofttimes looke backe vnto themselues whosoeuer expecteth stroake chastised enough whosoeuer hath deserued punishment expecteth something euill conscience may settle awhile nothing may secure thinketh although discouered may discouered midst dream moued man wickednesse speaketh thinketh owne thinketh neuer sufficiently defaced fully couered wicked man hath sometimes fortune hide himselfe neuer assurance hiding epist cvi idle question taken chrysippvs vnto others noueltie vnexpected euent herein ridiculous thing offended hereat complaine thou art eyther wet water sprinckled dirt thou walkest street condition life bath amongst multitude people great highway thing intermitted thing befall delicate thing liue thou art entered long way wherein perforce thou must slip thou must iustle thou must fall thou must wearied thou must xclaime death thou let know come hether sorrowes reuengefull care doe sleepe sickenesse pale weary age doe keepe company must life led thou canst escape thou may st contemne thou shalt contemne thou oftentimes bethink thee come suppose present whosoeuer hath long time prepared himselfe vnto thing performeth greater courage hath premeditated aduersities maketh head afterwards contrariwise man vnprepared starteth backe feare vpon least danger presenteth selfe let v take order nothing may befall v may moue v say thought nouelties distastfull continuall thought bring passe thou shalt apprentice aduersitie haue thy seruants forsaken thee haue robbed one accused another killed man betrayed trampled vnder feete poisoned man borne false witnesse another mischiefes thou canst call memorie haue befalne diuers hereafter happen arrowes shot v diuers great number sticking v othersome darted v approch v neerely othersome shot neighbour doe lesse grieue v leuelled selues let v wonder accident whatsoeuer borne thereunto man hath occasion complaine himselfe men haue part yea equall portion man hath escaped inconuenience might haue felt ordinance equall vnto proposed although men make vse thereof let v command soule continue entire let v pay tribute owe vnto nature without murmure winter bringeth frost wee cold sommer bringeth heat shall sweat heate intemperature ayre trieth body shall sicke shall meete one place sauage beast roarer worse beastes whatsoeuer one shall drowned brought ash cannot alter condition thing may haue resolute heart worthy good man meanes whereof endure accident constantly content selues order nature present gouernment causeth reuolutions thou obseruest raine come faire weather stormes tempest succeed calmes faire season wind blow one see one part heauens hidden v world composed contrary element let v apply soules vnto law let follow obey let thinke happeneth must happen let beware sort taske nature good thee endure thou canst amend follow great god without murmure complaint whose prouidence thing come passe souldier good vnwillingly followeth captaine therefore let v obey readily willingly without intercepting course faire life man life interlaced euill suffer conclusion let v speake vnto god whose ordinance direction round orbe gouerned termes cleanthes doth elegant verse presume translate tongue imitation cicero thrice eloquent orator please thee shall content distaste thee know herein conformable vnto cicero heare cleanthes saith soueraigne father eternall lord highest heauens conduct thy pleasure vnto thy powerfull straight accord make yet mourning without measure ile waite vpon thee bad suffer minde iust might endure strength whither thou wilt god must flie delayes heart feete willing fate conduct forward draw willing let v liue thus let v speake thus let destiny finde v alwayes addressed willing courage thus bounded within hand god greatest kindes contrariwise man faint recreant starteth backe complaineth gouernment world rather censure god himselfe epist cviii philosopher either read heard iudgement thing especiall chosen put memorie animate v good life seeke delight studie vaine studie thou thy amendment neither hard done nature selfe inciteth v vnto honestie seedes incitement thereof mindes grow encrease learned teacher animater doth aide proueth owne example attalvs scholler afterwards sheweth come diuers end mindes reade author philosopher doe like let v obey reade heare louers learning whereof thou enquirest number thing behoueth thee know end man may say thou knowest yet notwithstanding since pertinent thee know thou pressest mee instantly wilt attend book shortly finish containe good order part morall philosophie presently resolue thee yet first write vnto thee desire learning wherewith see thee thus transported gouerned feare lest hinder selfe thou must neither ouerrunne greedily inuade science part attaine whole burthen must fitted strength neither ought embrace able containe draw much thou wilt much thou mayest hold haue thou good courage thou shalt comprehend much thou pleasest minde receiueth enlarged greatned thing remember master attalus taught v besieged schoole came first departed last prouoked whilest walked dispute addressed informe learned meete vnprouoked teacheth saith learneth haue one intention one instruct profit commeth vnto philosopher schooles must daily carrie away good thing either returne wise vnto home better disposed wisedome shall returne power philosophie shee onely helpeth studie also frequent commeth sunne shall sunneburnt although came end sit downe perfumer shop haue stayed therein beare away odour place haue conuersed philosopher must need draw somewhat might profit euen negligent marke say negligent repugnant know men many yeares haue conuersed frequented philosopher without receiuing tincture thereof know yea industrious diligent rather call hostes disciple philosopher come heare learne drawne theater pleasure sake delight eares oration musick comedy thou shalt see great part auditor make philosopher schoole inne idlenesse intention place dispossesse themselues vice r ceiue instruction rule life whereby might reforme manner enioy delight tickleth eares come ables coate downe matter word learne well without men profit heard without owne rowse themselues heare magnificent speech thing spoken bitterly death ought vrged proudly fortune thou art forthwith addressed doe thou hearest affected let commanded forme remaine minde people disswadeth honest thing doe forthwith extinguish manner laid asleepe awakened reuiued seest thou theater ring often thing repeated publikely acknowledge testifie true consent pouertie wanteth many thing auarite thing couetous man good man worst cleanthes said euen breath yeeldeth cleare sound trumpet hath driuen thorow strait long pipe doth last giue larger vent end thereof strict necessitie vice maketh sences cleare thing heard negligently perswade lesse powerfully long deliuered prose ordinary discourse shut vp number good sence inclosed certaine foot cadence sentence darted deliuered arrow strong arme many thing spoken contempt money long oration taught men thinke rich mindes patrimony rich fitteth himselfe pouertie maketh himselfe rich little yet mindes moued like thing spoken verse coueteth little hath need much hath th would vaine subtilties fruitlesse braine speake gainst auarice inueigh dissolutenesse thou perceiuest thou hast profited moued heart thine auditorie prosecute vehemencie impossible discourse tending vnto remedie intirely intended good assembly profitable mind yet obdurate may easily induced loue right vertue truth finde fit conuenient aduocate easily seizeth willing learne lesse peruerted mine owne thou hast commonly heard greekes haue made prouerb men speech life euery man actio answerable speech somtimes kind discourse imitateth publike manner discipline commonwealth hath depraued effeminate moderate one corrupted affected seest thou mind languish member weakened foot hardly moued effeminate infirmitie thereof appeareth euen walking watchfull forward body doubleth pace furious next furie obscuritie ouerflowed discourse thou shalt therefore see eloquence drunken man enfolded extrauagant full libertie behold maecenas manner speech quid turpius amne siluis que ripa comantibus vide vt alueum lintribus arent verso que vad remittant hortos quid si quis faeminae cirro crispatae labris columbatur incipit que suspirans vt ceruice laxa feriatur nemo tirani irremediabilis factio rimantur epulis lagaenae que tentant domos saepe mortem exigunt genium festo vix suo testem tenuis erei filum crepacem molam iocum mater vxor inuestiunt wilt thou suddenly remember soone thou readest sp ech man alwayes trauersed rome street loosegowne euen caesar absence executed office hee deliuered watchword habit thinke man pallace tribunall time oration assembly people alwaies presented himselfe hauing face muffeled cloake without discouering thing eares accustomed doe flie knowne according represented comedy hee greatest height ciuill warres time rome armes feare marched thorow streetes attended two eunuch yet men himselfe hath one wife notwithstanding hath maried thousand time word aboue written badly builded negligently disposed repugnant manner men writing shew manner lesse new particular depraued hee hath beene highly prised sweetnesse nature hee neuer bare armes euer tooke pleasure shedding bloud thing except libertie time credit might permit good reputation hath beene soyled affectation monstrous manner language manifestly appeareth hee rather milkesoppe mercifull obscurity composition ouerth wart vvords conceit oftentimes loftie without pith discouer vnto obserue much felicitie troubled head vice sometimes found man sometimes time repose felicitie produceth soweth dissolution euery side first man beginneth carefully dresse adorne bodie afterwards studie haue rich moueables consequently bethinketh himselfe stately building make large enrich wall marble fetched beyond sea embolish roofes gold beautie pauement answerable richnesse many beames transferreth daintinesse magnificence table searcheth glorie noueltie changing accustomed fashion amongst predecessor thing wont bee serued last supper brought first thing presented entered feast giuen depart man minde accustomed loath vse thing ordinarie accounted contemptible go seekes new language reuiuing renuing vnusuall forgotten word forgeth new regrateth vnknowne newly found reputed elegant figuratiue translation audacious frequent thinke credit themselues speaking halfes abbreuiating speech sort heareth knoweth thinke delate draw draw vnto vice must need vndertaketh great thing doe yet loue wheresoeuer therefore thou seest men take delight obscure corrupt speech hold thy selfe assured manner depraued euen excessiue banquet superfluous rayments witness commonweale sicke libertie coyning new tearmes word custome continued sheweth spirit speake thus entangled lost wonder thou sort corruption pleasing mightiest meaner sort greatest poorest differ iudgements pompe estate rather wonder thou men praise effect vice vice themselues hath beene alwaies done pleasing wit pardon giue whatsoeuer man thou wilt greatest name tell thee wherein age wherein liued pardoned willingly dissembled reckon thee vp many whose vice harmed whose error profited say let thee see great renowne reputed excellent men man censure confoundeth vertues intermixed vice one necessarily draw adde hereunto language hath certaine rule publike custome changeth incessantly altereth yeare yeare men borrow word another age vse stile lawes written twelue table gracchus crassus curio ouer new returne farre appius coruncanus contrariwise haue nothing vulgar triuiall speake barelie corrupted diuers manner much certainlie would vse pompous welsounding poeticall word flie necessarie vse say well one doth amisse one esteemeth theselues necessary mispriseth selues ouer much one pull haire fro leg arme pit let v passe ouer coposition many default may discouer thee one allow crabbed harsh discourse disturbe smooth pleasing stile period pleasing harsh rough repute manly strong affecteth inequalitie stead speaking seeme sing fl ttering fluent structure wordes say word deferred haue attended long word wordes rare salust vsuall almost continued without cause one lighted chance sought thou seest followeth taketh errour example salust said aquis hiemantibus whilst water wintered ar ncius first booke carthaginian warre saith repente hiemauit tempestas say tempest suddenly wintered another place would say yeare colde saith totus hiemauit annus whole yeare wintered another place inde sexaginta minde one vertues haue adorned draw men admiration might seene externall beautie eyther false nothing worth likewise golde money wee much admire make men happy secure nay rather miserable pittied haue thee curious eyther thy wordes composition lucilius haue greater matter thee care thinke vpon seeke thou shouldest write stead busying thy selfe wordes cause thy selfe haue feeling substance thereof fortune take nothing yet escapeth finger much lost vnto men say one happie rich desire haue much good hee confesse thinkest thou worse case haue miserie enuie could wish desire rich consult take profite whether wisedome one thing wise another shall auaile mee knowe whether good badde aduentures see desire wish thee wisedome selfe may wise shall wee equall rather doe thou mayest shewe mee way may attaine vnto tell mee must eschue desire study may confirme infirme minde may driue farre mee vice carrie transport mee th right may surmount many euils may remoue th se calamity haue broken vpon mee may thwart haue engaged selfe teach mee may endure affliction without grieuing felicitie without men enuie distaste may expect last necessarie tearme life selfe shall thinke good speedily seeke flie vnto nothing iudgement absurd dishonest wish death thou wilt liue wishest thou die thou wilt intent importunest thou god gaue thee thou wert borne euen decreed thou must die one day whether thou wilt thou wilt thine owne power one necessitie dayes past haue read shamefull preface certaine man otherwise learned eloquent wordes may die sayeth hee incontinently fond man thou desirest thine owne may die incon inently may speaking wordes thou art become olde otherwise stayeth thee man holdes thee escape thou wilt chuse part instrument nature seemeth good vnto thee command giue thee issue element whereby inferiour world maintained water earth ayre cause life highwayes death may die incontinently wilt thou die day wilt thou assigne thine incontinent may come sooner thou wishest wordes although thou vnderstandest yet wise cannot one time bee good euill two thing doe agree disioynted neyther good euill let v passe ouer speedily ingenious trifle hasten selues attaine thing may giue v help man carefully seeketh midwife come vnto daughter labour readeth vnto ordinance disposition publicke playes man hastily runneth quench fire hath seized house hath leasure study saue man game chest make stronger make securer make equall fortune make superiour may superiour doe learne epist cxviii write vaine epistle rather full profitable lesson perswadeth handle priuate forraine business require nothing fortune neyther depend vpon true good sought definition likewise differeth honestie euery good according nature neyther yet euery thing good according nature thou requirest write vnto thee oftentimes enter account thou canst sufficiently satisfie agreed v thou shouldest write first answer thee behinde hand thee know nothing lost lent thee pay thee therfore thy day neyther doe eloquent cicero wont counsell atticus doe write whatsoeuer came minde although matter whereupon write neuer want matter write vnto thee although omit discourse wherewith cicero stuffeth epistle wit laboreth office fighteth forraine force laboureth consulat eyther vnder caesar pompeis fauour himselfe hard vsurer cicilius neighbour cannot wrest pennie hundreth vpon hundreth better man speake owne misery another man examine himselfe consider many thing man laboureth obtaineth one lucilius worthy thing secure free thing demaund purchase nothing let fortune possesse estate without ribing pleasant thing thinkest thou people assembl pretend office giue court welwishers one publikely protesteth mony giue solliciteth surety priuat friend one man weareth wasteth another man hand kiss attained desireth would loath touch men astonished expect voice crier stand idle xpect faires neither buying selling thing great ioy enioyeth man beholdeth assembly choyce made pretor consul great estate one demaundeth yearely honour others perpetuall power one happie successe battels triumphes rich one marriage child long happie life themselues parent great minde demand nothing make supplication man saith vnto fortune haue nothing doe thee thy commandement know thee catoes repelled vatinians aduanced demand nothing thy hand reduce fortune order fot cause therefore ought entertaine one another entreat continually subiect letter beholding euery side v many thousand men trouble cast themselues headlong mortall ruine trauerse one mischiefe finde another seeke thing incontinently flie soone haue found wherewith likewise disgusted hath contented himselfe giuen supposed thing ouer great wished felicitie vnsatiable men beleeue weake small therefore satisfieth man thou beleeuest thing great thou art estranged hath gotten base lie one seeke mount higher thou accountest highest degree ignorance truth cause men erre thus runne vnto hath appearance good deceiued common opinion afterwards hauing much trauell obtained pretended see thing euill vaine lesse expected part admireth one time another false lustre vanity briefe common sort esteeme thing good greatest lest wee fall error let v enquire good interpretation thereof hath beene diuers haue defined one sort othersome another define thus good inuiteth mindes calleth v vnto h reunto pl asantly obiect good inuite man vnto ruin thou knowest many euil attractiue truth seemeth true differ thus good annexed vnto truth good except true inciteth lf attracteth appearance hath resemblance truth insinuat th solliciteth draweth haue defined thus good moueth desire selfe inciteth motion minde tendeth thereunto opposed sort many thing incite motion mind desired confusion desire better haue done haue defined thus good draweth vnto selfe according nature motion soule ought desire worthy desired let v adde hereunto good honest vertuous ought purchase vnperfect good place admonisheth teach thee difference betwixt good honest somethings haue mixed inseparable betweene neither good hath hone ie neither honest good difference therefore betwixt hon stie perfect good wherein bl ssed life accomplished whose attouchment thing made good also say thus thing neither good euill warrefare embassage iurisdiction thing honestly administred begin good become whereas time indifferent good societie honestie made good honestie selfe good good floweth honestie honestie selfe good might haue beene euill honest could good haue proposed definition good according nature marke say good according nature yet forthwith good according nature many thing consent vnto nature yet small deserue called good small contemptible good least contemned long little good beginneth good little whence thin good perfectly according nature thou doest confe e sayest thou good according nature propertie thou confessest likewise thing according nature yet good therefore good attaineth another propertie haue propertie according nature say much great neither new thing thing changed encreasing infant become yong man hath time proprietie yong man endowed reason infant depriued somethings become great increase thing likewise saith made another thing made greater skilleth whether thou fil bottle wine tonn property wine remain th vessel little waight hony great differ sauour thou settest different example quality remaineth though encreased alwayes hony wine thing amplified kind continue propertie som thing many encreasings changed last imprinteth new qualitie one stone wil make arch say bindeth fastneth clining side tieth th together propertie hath made good epist cxix may desire rich enioy without requiring vnnecessarie end thing exceed nature considered seeketh superfluitie sufficient last sheweth commonly reputed rich poore good god excellent true oftentimes haue found thing expect till thou say crie halfes say vnto selfe thou askest haue found open thy lap meere gaine giue thee teach thee thou mayest become rich sence hereby manifestly appeareth fitly readily moue member bin fashioned thereunto euery one hath agilitie part workman handleth tooles readily master ship knoweth eere helme ship fitly painter doth quickly discerne diuersities colour laid end may apply worke readie hand eye passeth betwixt wax similitude resemblance would draw liuing creature moue themselues euery sort according becommeth wont wonder cunning actor haue hand nimble able represent thing effect readily gesture whose finger nimble tongue art vouchsafed nature alloweth man stirreth member without paine one restrained hath need moue himselfe borne vnto motion performe readily come world science borne instructed therefore saith shall liuing creature fitly moue part moued otherwise feele paine say compelled feare maketh moue aright false slow enforced necessitie agilitie voluntarie motion farre f feare paine driueth hereunto endue themselues naturall motion although paine doe prohibite infant meditateth stand accustomed keepe himselfe feete soone beginneth trie force falleth cry riseth againe often vntill meanes griefe hath exercised himselfe nature requireth hand liuing creature harder backe turned vpon long time tumble themselues stretch feete bow till time haue recouered ordinarie custome place tortuise cast vpon backe feeleth torment notwithstanding ceaseth struggle stirre selfe vntill time feeleth selfe naturall estate hath recouered feete therefore hath sence constitution thereby readie vse member neither haue wee greater token came liue knowledge liuing creature ignorant vse bodie constitution saith define principall fairest part soule sort hath power ouer bodie definition perplexed subtill selues scarcely discouer doth infant vnderstand liuing creature haue beene borne logician end might vnderstand definition might seeme obscure chiefest wisest part citizen true thou opposest said definition constitution vnderstood brute beast constitution selfe easily vnderstood taught nature therefore infant knoweth constitution yet knoweth owne constitution animal knoweth yet feeleth himselfe animal besides vnderstandeth nature grossely summarily obscurely also know well haue soule soule qualitie whence know sence minde wee haue attained vnto although ignorant nature seat thereof sence haue liuing creature constitution must need feele meanes whereof haue sence thing must necessitie haue sence thing gouerneth th obey one v knoweth cer aine thing stirreth affection man knoweth man knoweth hath endeuor whence knoweth euen infant liuing creature haue sence principall part resentiment obscure manifest say saith liuing creature aboue thing accommodated nature constitution man constitution bee reasonable soule therefore man accomodated himselfe liuing creature reasonable liuing creature hee deare precious vnto himselfe man therfore may infant accomodated reasonable constitution yet reasonable euery age hath constitution infant hath one stripling another old man another accomodated constitution wherein remaine infant without teeth constitution agreeth teeth grow agreeable age euen herbe must grow stalke ear hath one constitution tender scarce appeareth aboue furrow another waxeth stronger hath tender stalke yet sufficiently able beare burthen another waxeth yellow readie haruest eare thereof hardened whatsoeuer constitution commeth maintaineth accomodateth selfe thereunto age infant one little lad another yong man another old man another yet infant yong lad yong man although one constitution different yet accord thereof alwayes one nature commendeth vnto boy yong man old man selfe therefore infant accomodated constitution hath infant hee shall haue yong man onely estate wherein hee estate remaineth yet great whereunto ought attaine dependeth vpon nature first liuing creature hath care himselfe must somewhat whereunto rest referred seeke pleasure selfe therefore haue care selfe flie paine selfe therefore haue care selfe doe thing care haue selfe haue care selfe aboue thing liuing creature inferred innate nature bringeth fruit casteth becaus assured guard neerest one committed charge consideration himselfe therefore haue said tenderest creature either dam otherwise haue beene brought light doe presently know hurtful vnto fly thing threaten death chicken small fowle exposed prey grater fowle liue rapine feare shadow passe houer ouer creature entereth life hath feare death saith liuing creature new borne know healthful harmefull first question whether vnderstand vnderstandeth haue vnderstanding hereby appeareth wil nothing vnderstand heron flieth pecock goose whe much lesser yet vnknowne yet hideth self espieth hauke chicken feare cat dog appeareth haue cetain knowledge hurtful vnto gathered experience take heed make triall danger furthermore lest thou shouldest suppose hapneth chance feare none ought neither forget enemy auoided besides made fearefull liuing whereby appeareth attaine vse naturall loue consisteth flesh consequently knoweth meanes whereof flesh may cut burnt b uised reputeth beast contrary enemy armed hurt th se thing vnited together euery liuing creature hath present care conserue selfe shee searcheth may solace feareth may offend repulse thing contrarie vnto nature teacheth teacheth knoweth without discourse without resolution seest thou subtiltie bee haue building hiues maruellous accord haue distributing businesse seest thou mortall creature imitate spider web cunning hath disposing threeds one wouen outright stead foundation twisted round small end may surprise catch net fly layeth snare maketh prey arte borne spider learned therefore creature learned another thou shalt see spider web alike hiues wherin bee rest haue enterances alike arte teacheth vncertaine saith night goe salute bvta nothing notorious preposterous life buta whereunto diuers applyed themselues time haue said cause disorder thinke night hath thing pleasing nothing hindereth day displeasant euill conscience light costeth nothing contenteth coueteth disdaineth thing according cost lesse besides vnbridled person haue immoderate life spoken whilst liue obscured thinke loose labour displeased therefore often doe may make spoken many deuoure good many haue harlot thou wilt haue credite amongst men thou must needes commit lasciuious notable folly citty possessed sin common light heare running vp downe page called butler cooke make stirre aske meaneth answer come bath required broth drinke supper said exceed day liued frugally spent nothing night therefore oftentimes answered called couetous slouen would likewise call lichnobius say one liueth lampe thou must wonder although thou findest many propriety vice diuers haue innumerable face kindes cannot comprehended managing good simple euill manifold disposed sortes man list befalleth manner follow nature facile free haue small difference rest extrauagant neuer accord amongst themselues especial cause sicknesse opinion hatred common life distinguish themselues men garment great costly supper richnes coach seperated disposition time sinne ordinarily whose reward sinning infamie doe seeke may say liue sinisterly therefore lucilius follow way nature hath prescribed v neyther must wander doe finde thing facile expedit striue life otherwise striue streame epist cxxiii thin simple dyet decree minde hunger made desirable rich men vse likewise knoweth whether shall haue neede thereof let neyther custom forraine manner seduce v despise contrary iudgements opinion spent iourney incommodious long came albanum late night finde nothing ready selfe cause laide downe bedde ease wearinesse take good part negligence cooke baker thus debate vpon matter selfe nothing grieuous distaste thee thou endure patiently neyther thing may displease thee except thou thy selfe cause thy fretting baker hath bread farmer hath porter hath plowman hath thou wilt say course bread stay made good hunger tell thee make pleasing vnto thee thy white bread therefore ought eate thing hunger commaund v therefore stay refraine eating till time eyther beginne haue good forbeare loath bad necessarie thing accustome selues frugalie many difficulty time place doe sometimes hinder richest greatest lord long desired dinner man haue whatsoeuer yet may hath vse thing presented thankefully great part libertie wellgouerned bellie patient want thou canst imagine pleasure take wearinesse appeased selfe seeke neyther vnction bath remedie onely time labour hath bred rest taketh away pleasing supper prepared god sometimes haue made sudden experiment force minde finde simple assured whereas minde hath prepared selfe enioyned himselfe patience man cannot see much firmitie hath certaine argument instantly gaue onely equall temperate eye hee hath beheld hath beene displeased hath contested giuen himselfe ministreth himselfe desiring thinketh somewhat wanting custome vnto himselfe neuer vnderstood many thing superfluous began missing vsed ought many thing doe prepare men haue prepared vsual amongst manie amongst cause euils one liue example neyther gouerned reason ledde away custome men would imitate many haue begun doe follow honest frequent errour v supplieth place right made publique men nowadayes trauaile sort troope numidian horseman leades way companie footman attends vpon stirrop indignitie vnto attendant thrust way met show raising much dust honest man came dayes men haue moiles beare vessel crystall made cassonie enameled hand great artist shame thee thou seeme haue carriage might broken litter wherein carrie minion couered themselues haue face anoynted lest eyther sunne colde harme tender skin shame one companie minion hath face faire needeth farded men conference auoided teach vice conuey one place another reputed worst sort men talecarriers som beare vice men speech doth much mischiefe although instantly hurteth yet leaueth seedes minde followeth v euen wee haue left likely hereafter enkindle new euill v euen haue heard excellent musicke beare away eares harmony sweetnesse song hindereth thought suff reth intended serious matter speech flatterer praise vice sticketh longer time mem ries eard neither easie matter extinguish sweet sound minde followeth continueth returneth againe somewhiles remembrance becommeth v therefore beginning stop p eares euill voyces haue gotten enterance admitted audac ous thence men grow language vertue philosophie iustice bruite vaine word felicitie make good cheere liue pleasure haue ample patrimonie called life remember man mortall daye fleete v life posteth away may neuer recouer doubtfull frame selues according fantasie satisfie flesh desire whilest demandeth whilest take take care spare time death forbid selues present carry away thou hast friend boy may moue iealousie thy mistris day walkest thou thy house sober suppest thou thou wert accountable thy father expence thou makest euery day liue assist keepe company liuing folly heape vp rich thine heire deny thy selfe thing great good thou possessest might make thy friend thine enemie hee enioyeth thee reioyceth thy death set farthing seuere bold causers another man life enemy owne men would regent whole world neither doubt thou make choice merrie life good fame speech otherwise fled song syrens vlisses would saile fore tied himselfe mast ship haue power take giue eare vnto countrie parent friend vertues drag th se miserable creature thorow ordure shameful infamous life farre better follow direct way aime end thing length may onely seeme pleasing vnto thee honest may attaine shall conceiue two kind thing one wherof draw v driue v away inuite v rich pleasure beautie ambition briefe flattereth v agreeable vnto v driue v away trauaile death dolor ignominie want must therefore exercise selues lest feare one desire let v make head contrarie let v depart thing inuite v make warre importune v seest thou diuers habit ascend descend thy selfe thou hast crowne victorie applaude thy fortune thou wert great valiant man thou hadst gotten consulate praetorship thou art increased honour like say good man misfortune hath giuen occasion whereby make show liuely force mind repute thee wretched thou wert neuer wretched thou hast past thy life without aduersarie man thy selfe shall able know thy value end man may well know himselfe addressed pouerty thou aboundest rich know constancie thou hast ignominie infamie popular hate thou grow olde amidst applause euerie man inexpugnable fauour seconded certaine inclination men mind towards thee attendeth thee perpetually whence know thou wilt patiently endure losse thy child see thee laugh come world haue heard thee comfort others would willingly haue seene thee thou hast detaineth compelled suffer nothing vnwillingly neither doe serue god assent vnto much rather know thing h ppen eternall vnchangeable ordinance god destinie leadeth v first honor euery man birth hath gouerned rest life one cause dependeth vpon another long order thing draweth done publike priuate therefore thing endured constantly thing fall thing happen chance made ome immutable decree imagine come long since decreed whereat thou shouldest ioy sorrow although euery man life seemeth distinguished different great varietie yet notwithstanding commeth one point haue receiued thing decay selues must die displeased whence groweth complaint ordained hereunto let nature vse body shee list let v merrily constantly thinke thus lose nothing owne answere obiect relieth paradox stoickes tie first cause god secondarie cause whereas christian phylosophy teacheth v contrarie himselfe hereafter hath sufficiently answered hereunto proper be eming good man commit himselfe hand destinie great solace carried away whole world whatsoeuer hath commanded v liue thus die thus necessitie tieth god irreuocable course carrieth away together humane diuine thing creator gouernour thing hath written fate himselfe followeth hath written hath commanded alwayes obeyeth therefore god vniust distributing fate good men ascribed pouertie wound cruell death workmaster cannot change matter subiect suffer thing cannot separated thing cleaue one vnto another indiuisible spirit weake like grow dull fall watch fulnesse like vnto sleepe framed slow element frame man make himselfe spoken needeth stronger fate iourney must ordinar e way must trauell high low must haue stormes must gouerne ship swolne sea must shape course fortune hee shall haue many hard dangerous accident confront himselfe may smooth make plaine fire trieth gold aduersitie valiant men behold high vertue ascend thou shalt know must goe securitie first vnwearied steed clime iourney ceaselesse toyle scarcely reach morrowes prime next highest heaun whence soyle spacious sea see dreadfull eye fearefull heart next whereto hie steepe pro e craues cunning guide doth thetis shake selfe dread lest headlong fall downward glide burie waues golden head generous yong man heard thing like saith way attempt matter shape faire course fall afterwards father notwithstanding desisted terrifie forward minde thus thou mayst continue way carefullest thy posting steed doe stray yet shalt thou passe taurus bend horne crosse thee whither thou dost tend th aenomian archer lion sell shall stay thy course fright thee dwell saith coople thy granted team animated thing wherewith thou thinkest affright resolued stand sunne selfe shall tremble part base recreant minde trauell securitie vertue alwayes climeth hard difficult pathes chap vi fist principall point wherein sh weth euill vice whence felloweth vi tuous endure euill name ought giuen affliction bvt doth god permit good men suffer wrong vndoubtedly permitteth remoueth euils hainous sinnes offence cursed cogitation greedie cousels blinde lust auarice coueteth another man fortune defendeth restraineth doth man require god hand take paine also keepe good men budget acquit god care contemne externall thing democrates cast away rich supposing burthen good minde wonderest thou therefore god suffer happen wiseman good man sometimes would wish hee might sometimes light vpon good men lose child time come themselues must die banished sometime forsake countrie resolution neuer see againe slaine sometimes themselues lay hand themselues suffer aduersities end may teach others suffer like borne patterne thinke therefore god saith cause haue haue taken pleasure vertue complaine haue enuironed deceiueable good haue mocked vaine mindes long deceitfull dreame haue decked gold siluer iuorie inwardly nothing good admire happinesse looke according exteriour greatnesse interiour weakenesse miserable base silthie like walles onely painted outside solide sincere felicitie crust thinne one therefore long may stand vpright shew themselues list shine abuse common eye thing happeneth troubleth discouereth shalt thou see sea villanie filth hidden vnder borrowed brightnesse haue giuen true permanent good examine looke euerie wayes better greater appeare haue permitted contemne thing feared loath thing bee desired shall shine outwardly againe returneth paradox tying god vnto secondarie cause good turned inward world contemneth exteriour part contenteth himselfe contemplation himselfe haue placed good inwardly felicitie want felicitie diuers pitifull dreadfull intollerable thing fall could deliuer euils haue armed mind thing suffer manfully way whereby may walke god without patience euill aboue patience contemne pouertie man liueth poore borne contemne paine either b ended end v contemne fortune haue giuen weapon wound minde contemne death eyther endeth transferreth another paradox placing death po er man whereas man ought attend ordinance god esteeme eth ique hath whetted animated bondman attempt danger therefore thinke requisite temper wrath extinguish taken away exuberant reduce laudable forme retaine without action would languish force vigour spirit bee increased carie v away perforce suffer v returne backe euen body fall headlong downeward haue power stay themselues fit similitude confirme hi second proo e cast downe retaine stay themselue fall irreuocable precipitation hath cut counsaile meanes remedie neither possible keepe themselues attaining thither whether choice would arriue minde hath plunged selfe wrath loue like affection suffered restraine full must needes bee waight nature vice inclined vnto full carie away precipitate bottome chap viii remedie precedent di ultie reason ought carefully obserued marked best therefore forthwith despise first assault resist beginning endeauour wee fall wrath shee beginneth transport v hard matter recouer right way reason hath place soone passion hath gotten vpper hand hath giuen interrest
