affection intent shee suffereth haue progresse changed selfe passion therefore shee reuoke profitable wholesome force alreadie betraied weakned said haue distinct seuerall seates meane passion change soule good euill reason change euill goodnesse therefore shall reason hath giuen place vnto anger seazed oppressed vice rise againe shall shee deliuer selfe confusion wherein mixture worst hath preuailed saith containe themselues anger sort accomplish nothing choler commandeth doe obey somewayes doe nothing appeareth wrath necessarie humaine action preferred shee somewhat greater efficacie reason conclusion aske question whether shee stronger weaker reason stronger may reason giue law restraine considering feeble thing obey weake reason selfe sufficient without effect thing neither desireth shee helpe powerlesse passion angrie owne men containe themselues anger alreadie pacified remitteth owne accord shee height feruour shee stronger doe men height displeasure suffer depart safe secure hate abstaine hurting second passion hath repulsed former feare pleasure hath commaunded wrath staieth selfe reuerence oweth vnto reason reason feeble euil accord passion haue amongst themselues chap ix continuation obiection answer conclude hath nothing profitable selfe neither doth whe courage warlike exploit vertue contented selfe must neuer bee assisted vice oftentimes shee attempt thing shee angrie raiseth selfe farre forth thinketh necessarie intended remitted otherwise arrowes shot engine power shooteth farre shall shot anger saith aristotle necessarie neith r c n thing atchieued without except encourage minde enkindle spirit wee vse captaine souldier learne vse anger false shee giue eare reason follow way shee directed anger whose propertie contumacie resist quieted commanded passeth pride furie shee improfitable minister minde souldier retireth colour retreat sounded therefore suffer selfe kept measure must bee called another name ceaseth wrath vnderstand vnbrideled vntamed suffer pernicious neither bee reckoned amongst number helpes either anger else vnprofitable man exacteth punishment greedie punishment selfe hee must hee bee numbred amongst angrie man shall reputed profitable souldier knoweth obey counsaile affection euill minister captaines reason therefore neuer take assistant improvident violent passion ouer hath authoritie shee neuer may restrain except oppresse equal like vnto feare anger anger cowardise desire feare chap x farre vertue reduced extremitie answer aristotle opinion ethikes saith choler necessari reason constrained haue recourse vice cannot minde remaine certaine quiet hee must needes bee perpetuall agitation trouble secure euils cannot strong except wrathful modestuous except desire quiet except feare must liue tyranny becommeth slaue passion ashamed thrust vertues vnder protection vice moreouer reason looseth power doe nothing without passion beginneth equall like vnto importeth whether passion inconsiderate thing without reason reason feeble force without passion come one one cannot without endure passion bee equalled reason choler saith profitable passion bee small little profitable nature shee bee incapable gouernment reason shall attaine thing moderation lesser lesse hurtfull shee shall therefore light passion nothing else small euill chap xi bvt enemy saith hee seekest draw stronger precept hatred forsaking iudge hast recourse vnto people accident euerie one accustomed angrie thou thinkest men wil judge ought done doe part euerie one judgeth affection allow desirous reuenge wrath reason whereof wholly vnproper effect hindered violence furie euen uerie passion opposite contrarie selfe whereunto inclined whereto runneth hastily therefore neither peace warre euer good maketh peace like vnto warre armes forgetteth selfe warre common commeth man power whilst owne furthermore vice therefore intertained vsed sometime haue done good feuours also doe cure kindes sickness neither herefore better haue wanted wholy abhominable kind remedie recouer health asistance icknesse like manner wrath although sometimes hath beyond expectation profited venomne precipitation shipwrack haue done yet therefore reputed thing intirely profitable oftimes poysons haue preserued life diuers person chap xiiii moreouer thinges wee ought esteeme good better desired greater justice bee good man say like bee better thing taken fortitude good man wil desire diminished part wrath greater better increase wrath vnprofitable ore wrath selfe refuseth increase good thing increase wrath vnprofitable consequently bearing vnprofitable good thing increase becommeth euill wrath saith profitable maketh men hardie fight manner drunkennesse profitable maketh men insolent audacious many haue drunken ouer freely readie weapon manner say renzie madnesse necessarie valiant men oftentimes furie maketh men strong able vvhat hath feare sometimes made coward valiant feare death likewise enkindled weakest hearted men battle wrath drunkennesse feare like filthie fraile prouocations neither confirme v rtue hath need vice doe sometimes little quicken slow idle mind man strengthened anger except haue beene strong anger anger assisteth supplieth place vertue briefe passion recommendable would follow euerie one perfect tetchie infant oldmen sickmen euery creature na ure weake feeble ordinarily froward chap xiiii new obiection theophrastus touching heart good men conceiue euill men cannot saith theophrastus good man bee displeased wicked sence better men cholericke contrariwise peaceable exempt passion without hatered man reason might moue hate sinnes considering errour driueth faultes part wise man haue erre otherwise hate himselfe l bethinke himselfe many fault committeth good manner many thinges hath done require pardon shall bee angrie himselfe iudge pronounceth one sentence owne behalfe another anothers man saith hee found absolue himselfe truth euerie man saith innocent regard witness conscience farre humane man shew himselfe gentle pacified offend rather recon le persecute better lead direct way want knowledge haue straied passion choler physitian bee angrie displeased patient would recouer chap xv bvt cannot bee corrected neither thing capable good hope man may chastise nay may ex ute enders withou transported choler let bee exterminated companie men like infect conuerse since onely meanes let cease euill let bee done without hatred cause haue hate pro take selfe selfe doth man hate limmes hee cutteth wrath miserable cure chace away mad dogges kill re ie vntractable oxe wee arde scabbe sheepe feare least infect flocke strangle monstruous birthes wee drowne owne child likewise borne deformed monster act wrath reason seperate thing vnprofitable helthfull profitable nothing chastiseth refraine wrath chastisement profiteth done iudgement thenc socrates said vnto slaue beaten thee beene angrie hee deferred admonition seruant till conuenient time time admonished himselfe whose affection shall temperate socrates da e trust selfe wrath needeth therefore angrie corrector chastise wicked amisse whereas wrath offence minde faultie himselfe must punish offender chap xvi shall angrie thiefe answer obiection shall displeased witch neither angrie selfe let selfe bloud apply sort punishment stead remedie thou yet hast made entrance errour neither offendest grieuously frequently shalt first bee secretly publikely reprooued thou engage thy sel e sinne word may correct thee thou shalt bee fined thy folly thy fault requireth forcible feeling punishment thou shalt bee banished sent vnknowne place orde ought bee bse ed punishing malefac or thy malice increaseth waxeth obdurate thou haue neede vse sharper remedy precedent thou shalt thrust shackle lockt vp prison thou come incurable thou growest heape sinne vpon sinne thou onely layest hold occasion doe euill neuer faile seeke worst doe euill thou hast occasion wicked custome thou hast taken thou hast drunke iniquitie rt sort tainted deepely tinctured wickedn s inwardly cannot finde issue except thou burst die presently thou hast long time sought death poore man thou art w gratifie thee wee heale thee furie thy spirit wherewith thou art torm nted hauing made thee passe punishment men thine owne let thee see feele onely good remaineth thee say death bee displeased assist greatly helpe time take man life amplification example aboue written answer pr cedent obiection sometimes shew fauour doe good turne well experienced vpright iudge armed authoritie lawes pronounce sentence voice rather pleasing graue furious peaceably yet seuerely commaund hangman execute office shall commaund malefactor head strooken cause beas e wrath necessarie punish thinkest thou law angrie shee knoweth shee seeth shee hopeth ought therefore inuest affection displeased onely defineth conuenient good man angrie euill deedes shall bee lawfull enuie prosperitie euill men vnworthie men flourish yea abuse indulgence fortune fortune may found euill enough well shall hee see commodity without enuie hainous offence without wrath good iudge condemneth euill yet hateth shall wise man hath lik thing hand bee touched minde troubled ordinarie confeffe hee shall feele light motion zeno saith wound wise man soule healed yet remaineth scarre shall feele certaine touch suspition shadowes passion yet without passion aristotle saith affection man vse well serue insteede armes bee true wiseman ought moued ow might vsed laide aside warlicke instrument pleasure putteth armes aristotle giueth nature fight themselues expect man make vse stoick doctrine maintaineth examination aristotle pinion touching passion gouerne know obey vertue hath need instrument sufficiently furnished reason wherewith nature hath fitted v shee hath giuen v weapon firme perpetuall obsequious certaine cannot reinforced master reason selfe sufficient enough onely foresee execute action fond reason seeke assistance wrath stable thing vncertaine faithful perfidious whole sicke moreouer touching action themselues wherein helpe anger seemeth requisite reason selfe stronger hauing marked ought doe remaineth alwaies setled resolution vnable finde thing better selfe change shee departeth neuer place contrariwise pittie hath oftentimes driuen wrath dores passion hath solid strength onely tumor vseth violent beginning otherwise windes arise earth entertained flouds marsh vehement permanent beginneth great violence terwardes fainteth wearied time shee hath inuen nought else crueltie new kind punishment execution done pacified becommeth gentle affection qua leth quickly reason equal moreouer also wrath perseuereth sometimes many haue deserued death bloud two three beginneth bee calmed first assault sharpe euen venomnesse serpent hurtfull creepe nne teeth harmelesse often byting hath spent therefore suffer equally haue offended equally oft time hee hath offended least suffereth object latest anger wholy vnequall sometimes extendeth selfe farther sometimes resisteth ought shee flattereth selfe iudgeth shee list heare leaueth place excuse retaineth shee hath apprehended suffereth iudgement taken although euill reason giueth place either part time likewise afterwards shee demaundeth terme selfe end may haue time discusse truth wrath hastie designes reason wrath reason haue iudged rightfull wrath haue seeme rightfull shee iudgeth reason respecteth nothing question wrath mooued vaine thing nothing purpose assured countenance firme voice free speech exquisite garment delay without delay auour people exaspereth wrath oftimes despight aduocate condemneth pleadeth although truth laid eye shee loueth maintaineth errour shee bee reprooued euill enterprise shee esteemeth honest bee obstinate repent herselfe caius piso memorie man exempt many vice notable example confirming e saith anger ought indued reason sh extingu sheth yet extremely cholericke one tooke pleasure austeritie displeased commaunded souldier brought returned pillage without companion murthered could bring person requested time finde denied condemned die souldier thus sentenced brought without trench alreadie tendered neck vnto hangman suddenly fellow souldier appeared men suppo ed slaine wherevpon centurion charge see execution done commanded hangman put vp sword brought piso condemned end hee might make proofe innocencie since fortune afforded meanes souldiers flocked two embraced one another content companion piso incensed choler ascended tribunall seat commanded souldiers bee ledde death souldier slaine fellow slaine indignitie innocencie condemned manifest perished piso added third hee commanded centurion brought backe condemned bee ledde execution three appointed die one place one man innocencie oh cunning wrath faine cause furie command thee saith hee bee led death thou art condemned thee thou wert occasion thy fellow souldiers death thee commanded see executed thou didst bay thy commander deuised finde three crime hee found none wrath say hath euill gouerned shee angrie truth selfe f seeme sort opposite crie tumult iactation whole body persecuteth hath resolued iniurie reproches curse doth reason must needes bee silently quietly shee ruineth whole house foundation destroieth whole family enemy countrie wife child shee raceth downe house leueleth earth obscureth name enemy libertie doth shee foaming mouth note magigis rate shaking head neither thing vndecent iudge whose lookes time especially ought pleasing staied pronounceth matter consequence needest thou saith ierosme thou art intended strike man bite thy lip first seene proconsull leaping tribunall taking away sergeant rod renting garment garment condemned rent soone enough needeth ouertorne table breake fling away pot beate one head pillers teare haire thumpe thigh breast great anger thinkest thou sodainly vented another man would reflecteth vpon selfe therefore held neighbour intreated pacifie himselfe none thing doth void anger inioyneth euery one deserued punishment ofttimes dismisseth whose guiltinesse forfeit hath apprehended confessing act promise great hope amends vnderstand offence grew malice heart say committed complotted sinister intent giue pardon neither shall hurtfull receiue giue sometimes represse greatest offence committed infirmitie crueltie gently lesse hidden couered inueterate craft punish fault different men different manner one haue committed negligence studied doe hurt hee obserue alwaies euery iudgement execution ordaine one sort punishment correct euill cut shall consider thing past thing come plato saith wise man punisheth euill lea wee fall euill thing past cannot recalled thing come may preuented would make example cursed crime hee executeth publikely end may die others might deterred euill beholding execution aduertisement magistrate beware anger cannot make man magnanimous one ought weigh consider reason thou se st much magistrat exempt passion vndertaketh thing great consequence life death men vnder hand sword indiscreetly committed furious man hand neither ought thinke wrath addeth thing greatnesse minde greatnesse swelling neither body intended aboundance bad humour sicknesse increase pestilent plentie anger passion vile base puffeth vp raiseth aboue thought men make themselues beleeue thought sublime high whereas nothing firme doe haue builded aire sinketh falleth selfe wrath hath assistant sustainer shee proceedeth thing permament durable windy vaine differeth farre greatnesse minde audaciousnesse fortitude insolence confidence sadnesse austeritie crueltie seueritie great difference betwixt constant proud minde wrath enterpriseth nothing great worthy contrariwise iudgement token dull vnhappie man guiltie owne weaknesse sorowfull oftentimes euen body exulcerated sicke complaine touched neuer little womanish childish fault yet incident men men likewise haue childish womanish wit wordes vttered angrie men haue true knowledge magnanimitie seem notwithstanding proceed great generous mind dire abhominable speech let hate feare know written syllaes time know whether wish worse either hated feared let hate forethinketh happen subiects curse betray oppresse addeth hereunto god confound worthie remedie hath found hatred let hate whilst obay whilst approue feare would haue beloued thinkest thou spoken great spirit thou art deceiued greatnesse crueltie thou art giue credit wrathfull men wordes whose boast great threating inwardly heart crauen coward thou must repute true spoken liuie eloquent man man minde rather great good cannot separated ither shall great good shall great meane th greatnesse man vnshaken inwardly solide euen equall one end vnto another cannot bee euill mindes may bee terrible tumultuous dangerous death shall haue greatnesse whose foundation strength goodnesse yet speech action outward childrens anger first good instruction svch mindes therefore bee tempered nourished animated delight wee vse remedy anger sadnesse cured different contrary meanes alwayes haue care increasing shall profit much say haue child well instructed beginning manner gouerning difficult wee must indeuour wee nourish anger dull dampe spirit matter need diligent obseruation second keepe measure neither ani ate discourage much ought proceed bee extolled depressed nourished like thing resemble doe oftentimes deceiue diligent mind increaseth libertie embased seruitude praise rowseth selfe filleth v great expectation yet two expedient ingender insolence wrath therefore gouerned betweene sometimes vse bridle sometimes spur minde may suffer nothing base seruile let neuer haue need intreat thing humbly neither let profit though hee hath submissiuely intreated wee grant thing let bee rather alleadging vnto hath cause demaund haue regard vnto former behauiour hope hee doe better hereafter hee promiseth exercise amongst companion let v neither suffer ouercome bee angrie let v indeuour may bee alwayes familiar hee wont contend exercise hee accustome himselfe haue hurt third en ained ei idl ly daintily ouercome oft hath gotten vpper hand hath done thing praise worthie let v suffer proud boast thereof boasting followeth joy pride much esteeme himselfe boasting wil giue recreation yet wil neither suffer slothfull idle aboue thinges detaine touch pleasure nothing inkindleth wrath ouer delicate daintie education therefore onely childe wee giue libertie pupil left owne pleasure ordinarily corrupted childe hath euery thing whose mother hath ordinarily dried teares eye hath master assigned according fancie neuer suffer injurie patiently seest thou euerie greater fortune attended greater anger appeareth rich men noble men magistrate esp cially whatsoeuer vainenesse leuitie braines findeth fit winde carrie away felicitie nourisheth wrath soone troopes flatterer incamped proud men value man transported choler cannot called couragious free feeble slaue vnto others wilt thou suffer aduertise circumspect looke themselues passion minde doe inuade wicked anger stealeth heart learned clerk otherwise behaue themselues like good men men thinke anger token simplicity ordinarily suppose honest hath part infirmitie chap v hur full wrath th principall remedy thereof whereto tendeth discourse end man suppose himselfe warranted passion induceth men modest peaceable nature become rude violent euen good disposition bodie care maintaine selues health preuayleth nothing plague indifferently la eth holde w ake strong anger danger well disordered men sober peaceable haue care themselues trouble anger causeth th great much first remedie angrie second refraine anger third remedie another man anger first shew th meanes auoyde anger secondly may discharge selues anger beginneth enkindled v thirdly sort may pacifie man displeased temper reduce reason shall subdue anger instructed auarice gathereth locketh vp honest man couetous wrath consumeth gratifieth welcome none angry master hath driuen som seruants runne away hath put death lost angry hee angry wrath hath made father mourne husband bee diuorced magistrate hated candidate repulsed worser likewise ryot taketh pleasure owne delight another man sorrow surpasseth malignitie hatred contented see man become vnhappie make vnhappy two reioyce euils come casually cannot expect fortune hurt hateth hurt nothing grieuous secret hatred wrath concealeth lamentable warre therein men discouer displeasure moreouer publique priuate anger weake forcelesse warre furthermore without recounting damage adde hereafter ambush perpetuall care engender many quarrel wrath intending reuenge selfe punisheth selfe canker humane nature nature inuiteth v amitie anger hatred nature commaundeth v assist one another anger hate one another one commandeth v profite hurt adde hereunto whereas indignation proceedeth ouer great suspicion himselfe seemeth couragious yet weake infirme man lesse suspecteth himselfe contemned man truely valiant knoweth owne worth reuengeth iniurie feeleth euen arrowes recoile backe shot stonie hard marke solid thing strucken procure griefe striketh iniury may pierce great heart farre weaker attempteth farre worthy thing dispise iniuries contumely mind impregnable reuenge confession paine minde great animated iniurie eyther stronger thy selfe weaker ath wronged thee weaker thy selfe spare mightier support thy selfe chap vi one certain argument true magnanimity thou resolue thy selfe effec true magnanimitie approued fit comparison nothing may befall thee may moue thee highest gouerned part world neerest starres troubled cloud subiect tempest afflicted stormes tumult inferiour heauens push forth lightning like sort sublimed high spirit alwayes quiet placed peaceable station restrayning himselfe whence anger borroweth occasion contention moderate venerable setled thou shalt finde none angry man betraied sorrow furie hath reiected former modesty turbulent passion incensed another man hath dispossessed himselfe shame fastnesse man displeased keepeth measure remembr th due containeth tongue hath beene master part bodie could gouern himselfe notable lesson democritus finde true repose profite v infinitely doe nothing eyther priuately publikely exceedeth force neuer doe thing succeede happily vnto man intermedleth many affaire sometimes one man affaire themselues ariseth fault disposeth heart vnto anger euen trauelleth hastily thorow frequented streetes cittie must meete many men one place p another stopped third besprinckled dir trauaile walkes life confouded confused happen many impediment manie quarrel one hath deceiued hope another hath deferred another hath intercepted euents haue beene answerable expectation fortune addicted man yeeldeth euery way correspondence manifold attempt followeth therefore knoweth endure men estate humane affaire thinkes thing befalleth otherwise hee made reckoning end therfore mind may quiet ossed neither said troubled managing many affaire charged mighty affaire exceede strength easie matter carry light burthen cast one shoulder another without letting fal one hath loaded v burthen heauy carry much labour finally discharge vpon neerest v pant vnder burthen reason ouer loden hard v goe forward backewards without staggering chap vii requisite mediocritie temperance managing affaire e intemperating quieting minde know thou falleth ciuill domestique matter affaire light accompanie doth ouergreat exceede might acteth vneasie compasse man hath laid holde puzzle oppresse carrieth finally thinketh hath best hold hee stumbleth falleth burthen rowleth downe vpon troubleth thence falleth often time hee vndertaketh difficult matter would make easie frustrated part thought thine enterprise measure thy selfe together thinges thou wilt manage whereunto thou addressest thy selfe otherwise displeasure thou shalt conceiue leauing thy worke vnperfect make thee maruellously pensiue place wee ought obserue whether man bee violent spirit setled fearefull generous mind repulse inkindle wrath faint abject minde sadnesse let therefore action bee neyther small audacious wicked let v follow thing answerable hope let v attempt nothing wee haue attained make v wonder successe thereof chap viii noble obseruations men let v take order wee receiue injurie wee cannot disgeast let v lead liues temperate familiar men troublesome foolish men invest manner conuersant infirmity bodie deriued transported attouchment soule communicateth infirmity passion approch drunkard hath drawne companion loue wine companie dissolute fellowes hath effeminated man hard rocke auarice empoysoneth dwell neere vnto contrariwise reason touching vertues moderate thing neyther profitable countrey wholsome aire healthful man bodie good mindes scarce setled conuerse good men thing auaileable thou shalt vnderstand thou consider wilde beast tamed men handling fiercest beast laieth furie hath long time bin vnder discipline man whch furious lenified tempered little little moreouer conuerseth peaceable good men becommeth better reason example much likewise findeth occasion displeased practise passion ought therefore flie knowledge disposed easily prouoked vnto anger saist thou many vpon diuers cause doe proude man offend thee contempt rich man contumely lasciuious man iniurie hatefull man malignitie quarrelsome contention boaster lyer vanitie thou wilt endure feared suspicious man ouercome obstinate sweetnes respect let v put selues place displeased doth wrong estimation selues make v angry thing would doe suffer man patient greatest remedie wrath delay first furie thereof may bee repressed mist dulleth mindes eyther may dispersed lesse thicke thing carry thee away headlong say day houre may rectifie wholly vanish case demand delay appeareth anger reason commandeth soeuer thou wouldest know heed slaue found another ought rather haue chastised therefore depriued himselfe authoritie ouer seruants notwithstanding seruant committed fault worthy punishment hee said vnto spevsippvs pray thee chastise seruant stroakes angrie beateth another beaten angrie said shall doe doe willingly let seruant power master himselfe man commit reuenge wrathfull man since plato hath taken authority himselfe taking oportunities intending surprise babilon hee attempted passe ouer huge riuer gynde scarcely passable height sommer water lowest one white horse wont draw kingly chariot carried away violently streame whereat king mightily mooued swore would bring riuer carried away princely baggage passe euen verie woman bee able get oner without wetting shooes said imployed force herein continued long hauing digged nine score chanels turne riuer afterwards reduced three hundreth sixtie armes brooke great channel became drie water dreined many wayes thus spent e time irreuocable losse faires consequence thus abated souldiers courage broken vnprofitable labour lost occasion preparation assault whilst hauing proclamed warre enemy grew od riuer returneth caligula example make anger odious silent willing dismisse thersites safe sound saith rest embassador tell athenian proude speake thus heare spoken without reuenge avgvstvs caesar spake many thing worthy memorie whereby appeareth master owne anger timogines writer history spoken somwhat himselfe somewhat whole family neither lost spoken audacious kind jesting soonest entertained divulged euery man caesar ofttimes gaue warning hereof wished vse tongue moderately seeing perseuered forbad house timagines liued till olde asinius pollios house beloued whole cittie notwithstanding caesar repulse euery man doores open afterwards recited burned history written cast bookes fire contained act augustus caesar thus waged warre caesar man refused friendship man fled though blasted alwayes gaue entertainment height disgrace said caesar endured patiently neyther moued therewith notwithstanding timagines violated praise action neuer displeased entertained enemie onely said pollio thou nourishest beast addressed himselfe giue answere emperour preuented said thy command pollio much good thee pollio said thou commandest caesar presently forbid house said thinkest thou doe haue reconciled made friend pollio time past beene angrie timagines neyther cause dislike towards caesar entertained chap xxiiii profite man take precedent example consideration besides th ought annex better refrain anger let euery man therefore say vnto himselfe often prouoked powerfull philip yet patiently suffered disgrace without reuenging doe priuate house diuus caesar thorow whole world yet content locke vp gate slandered bolde jesting answer proude looke grumbling vntowardnesse slaue expiate fault whip fetter man dare offend mine eares many haue pardoned enemy shall pardon sluggish negligent branglers let age excuse childe sex woman libertie stranger familiaritie domestick offended euen let v bethinke selues often hath contented v ofttimes hath offended otherwise let v endure haue suffered long friend pretended enemie ought doe shall endure wiseman let v pardon foole whatsoeuer befalleth v let v say vnto selues wisest commit many errours man circumspect anger doth sometimes take tardie none mature stayed eyther wordes action whose grauity may fortune drawne inconsiderate action man fearefull offend whilst flyeth offence falleth chap xxv continuation profit gather precedent consideration even poore man taketh comfort miserie seeth great men fortune stagger temperate minde hath bewayled sonnes death corner chamber seeth wofull funeral heire kingdome solemnized borne forth peaceable contented minde shall endure harmed contemned another man whosoeuer bethinketh himselfe potentate great may attempted iniurie wisest doe offend let v thin e selues fault excusable let v consider oftentimes yong yeares haue beene scarce diligent performing dueties immoderate speech scarce temperate wine angry let v giue tim wherein may consider hath done hee himselfe reproue himselfe conclusion hee punish himselfe yet must angrie vndoubtedly true hath exempted himselfe common men raised himselfe higher degree despiseth prouoke propertie true magnitude feele strooken hath furious beast stalking long setled pace looked backe dog barked doe enraged billowes sea insult vaine immoueable rocke angry hath neuer beene shaken iniurie angrie moued present haue mounted aboue incommoditie certaine embrace entertaineth chiefest good equall onely himselfe also fortune whatsoeuer thou doest thou art great enough obscure brightnesse enlightneth reason haue assigned conduct life defendeth anger hurt offence certaine measure offence know farre mine anger transport chap xxvi bvt pertinent answer alledge endure n thing meanes depriue themselues excellent happinesse courtesie produceth sayest thou endure nothing grieuous matter sustaine iniurie thou liest cannot endure iniury suffer anger furthermore thou pretendest charge thy selfe iniury anger sufferest thou cry sicke man strange speech lunatick stroakes thy little child forsooth seeme ignorant doe skilleth errour man becommeth imprudent since imprudence equall excuse attainted therewith sayest thou shall remain vnpunished thinke thou wouldest yet shall greatest chastisement man may receiue hath outraged another haue done outrage man rudely punished subiect whip owne repentance moreouer behooueth v regard consider condition humane affaire end may vpright iudges accident vniust vpbraideth priuate man imperfection common man blacke amongst moore hath redde head curled manner almaines dishonour becommeth well common whole nation defameth particular thing haue set downe depend custome one countrey little corner earth consider therefore whether easier matter excuse practise whole world v inconsiderate improuident v vncertaine irresolute ambitious hide publique vlcer vnder milder wordes v nought whatsoeuer therefore reprehended another shall euery man finde within owne bosome obseruest thou bleakenesse colour leanenesse bodie common plague let v therefore temperate one towards another liue euill men amongst euill men one thing onely make v quiet mutuall facilitie conuersation man hath iniured yet haue harmed yet perhaps hast thou hurt bodie leastwise thou wilt hurt chap xxvii estimate houre day much consideration weakenesse heartneth anger ninth mean refraine looke whole habite thy minde yet thou hast done euill yet canst thou doe farre better iniurie salued reuenged reuenge consumeth much time exposeth selfe many iniuries whilst stung one wee v long time angrie hurt farre better take another course sort sort vice together man thought well wit kicke moyle heeles strooken teare dogge teeth bitten sayest thou know offend first vniust displeased men come vnto reconcile themselues againe restraine thee angrie beast destitute reason ranke number doth something without iudgement skilleth resemble beast thing fault excuseth beast hee sheweth himselfe brutish hath offended first last thou hast cause beleeue although saith doe againe thou shalt see offend thee another whole course life shall trauailed errours must handle sauage thing courteously wont said sorrow may effectually spoken likewise anger whether wilt thou giue ouer neuer better leaue anger left anger fault shall alwayes continue thou seest vnquiet life thou denouncest thy selfe befalleth alwayes swolne vp incensed wrath chap xxviii tenth mean seeke occasi displeasure fvrthermore thou thy selfe seeke occasion meanes prouoke thine anger thou enkindlest thy displeasure thou shalt see depart thee owne motion time weaken daily farre better thee thou shouldest surmount mistresse thee thou art angry man man thy slaues anon thy francklins thy father mother thy child thine acquaintance thou hast newly met withall occasion present themselues euery place except peaceable minde containe gouerne v furie driue thee hither thither new prouocations shall arise thy rage shall continued goe vnhappy man thou wilt loue good time loosest thou bad thing farre better get thee friend mittigate thine enemy gouerne common weale transfer thy indeuours gouernement thy familie looke thee iniurie thou mayest doe another man wound thou mayest inflict eyther dignitie patrimony body cannot befall thee without contention danger although thou encounter thine inferiour although thou see tyed hand foote thy power whatsoeuer thou pleasest oftentimes hath beene seene man striking another force hath put shoulder ioynt arme hand else biting hath broken teeth spoyled gummes anger hath made many men lame hath weakened many yea euen hath gotten matter patience adde hereunto thing feeble world eleuenth consideration hurt ues th n doe enemy perishes without putting danger would crush breake sometimes griefe sometimes casualty hath matched strongest weakest part thing moue v doe harme v hurt men great difference whether man oppose himselfe pleasure whether hinder whether take giue account one whether man take v thing denie v whether cut hope differ whether hee v selfe whether loue another man hatred beareth v haue also honest cause stand v one defendeth ather brother another vncle third friend yet pardon doe thinges doe would condemne nay incredible oftimes allow deed condemne doer chap xxix bvt yet assuredly euery great man affectioneth wel respecteth amongst enemy twelf beware con oud iudgment hate thou praisest least whose miserie requireth thine assistance valiantly aduenturously behaueth himselfe libertie conseruation countrie wisheth himselfe citizen camerado danger shamefull thing hate thou praysest farre shamefull hate man worthie mercie one taken prisosoner retaineth yet remanders libertie sheweth himselfe readie base troublesome business hauing thorow idlenesse gathered much fat cannot come swiftly master horse coach wearied dayes trauaile sleepe refuseth labour fieldes doth bestow himselfe stout pesant doe reason hee liued citie much ease tyed businesse tedious continual let v consider whether cannot doe would require hand doe wee shall beare diuers men wee indeuour selues judge displeased beleeue first assault passion buzzeth are afterwardes although wee b e mooued vpon ground yet pers uer least wee seeme haue begunne without cause damnable iniquitie wrath maketh v obstinate wee nourish increase argument anger bee grieuously angrie farre better examine beginning consider harmelesse thou seest fall bruit beast shalt thou discouer man troubled friuolous vaine thing chap xxx red colour exasperateth bulles thirteenth except thou wilt become beast moued riuolous vaine matte accustomed doe ouertaken anger aspe inkindled shadow white cloath prouoketh beares lion thinges nature hath made fierce dreadfull astonished little matter befalleth disquiet foolish mindes strooken suspition thinges sort time call moderate benefit injury frequent yet truly vrgent cause choler consist angrie dearest friend haue done v lesse courtesie expected men haue done v present readie remedie hath fauoured another man let v delight selues without comparison shall neuer happie tormenteth himselfe man felicitie haue lesse hoped happily haue hoped ought part feared hence arise dangerous displeasure inuade holiest blessedest thinges world iulius caesar killed greater number friend enemy whose immeasurable hope satisfied intention neither euer man carried himselfe better liberally hee became master enemy hee challenged nothing himselfe power distribute could satisfie many importunate desire men desired much one man could hee saw therefore naked dagger follower throne amongst rest tullius cimber time beene affectionate partaker death pompey become pompeians chap xxxi fourtenth haue respect another n good th ne owne neuer thinke tho hast obtained litle verie passion hath raysed subject prince vrged faithfull conspire death whose presence desired time past loose liues hath respect another man good neglecteth owne thereupon wee angrie god likewise one man outstrippeth v forgetting selues much important enuie followeth backes yet great importunitie men although haue receiued much yet suppose themselues indignified iudgement capable gaue praetorship looked consulship gau twelue mace yet made mee ordinarie consull would hee haue vndertake charge numbring yeare failed mee election sought pontificiall dignitie haue beene brought colledge bishop augures companie hath hee consumated dignitie hath allowed nothing towardes charge patrimonie hee gaue mee ought haue giuen added nothing owne rather giue thankes thinges thou hast receiued exspect rest rejoyce yet thou art full amongst pleasure small one see somewhat remayning thou maist hope hast thou sped better rejoyce thou art first amongst others hath thy friendes heart doe many exceede thee consider number march thee surpasseth thou followest chap xxxii askest thou greatest vice thee fi thteenth disg st wra h li le take lea ue consider command ment passion hath ouer h e whereupon founded thou forgest false consideration thou highly prizest thine owne gi te neglectest others let one thing deter v let v bee afraid angrie reuerence sake let v forbeare pittie sake endure vndoubtedly shall performe goodly peece worke shut vnhappie slaue prison ha tie beat sudden breake legges power lost bee deferred let time come wherein wee may master selues speake wee passion shee quailed shall wee see weightie debate especially wee quarrel trouble amongst affect thing thou art angrie thy frackling thy wife thy retainer answer thee afterwards thou coplainest comonwealth hath lost libertie thou thy selfe hast exterminated thine house thou speak vnto thy seruant answere thee thou termest disdaine rebell thou wilt haue speake thou wilt haue hold peace thou wilt haue laugh master saiest thou father family criest thou chidest whereunto hee repared thou hast beene seated place scarce answerable thine honour thou hast beene angrie stood next thee inuited thee preferred thee foole thou art matter place thou art set table attendeth driue slaughterhouse like doe challenge coupled v charge euery side mean conquered conquerour nee e vnto ruine rather let v finish little remainder life quiet peace let death pleasure man ofttimes together are haue forsaken strife debate one hath cryed fire kindled neighbour house enteruiew wilde beast hath diuided thiefe merchant haue leasure wrestle lesser euils greater feare appeareth haue doe fighting ambush doest thou wish thou art displeased death although thou sayest nothing shall die thou loosest thy labour thou wilt doe sayest thou forthwith kill banish disgrace punish pardon rather desireth enemie wounded scabbed man onely badly basely minded whether thou thinkest death one slight euill little di ference betwixt day thy desire vntill punishment one shall endure till time thou shalt reioyce euil conscience misery another man euen drawe breath driue spirit v whilst amongst men let v embrace humanitie let v dreadfull dangerous man let v contemne clemencie written lvcivs annaevs seneca nero caesar first booke argument ivstvs lipsivs bookes written beginning neroes raigne himselfe manifestly proueth first book ninth chapter wheras writeth hee entred nineteenth yeare age vndoubtedly word matter worthy prince would god would reade thence gather fruit mercie magnitude beginneth neroes praise deseruedly beginning moderate afterwards third chapter deuideth writing three part one manuduction explicateth nature clemency leadeth men thereunto firmeth first first whole booke intreateth thereof forefront setteth downe profite clemency greatly beseemeth king clemency well becommeth head commonweale bodie member spareth nourisheth body shee necessary also many offender thou punishest alwayes thou makest commonweale solitude example god spare v likewise regard fame king action obiects men eye least crueltie long security gouerne thu secure annexeth notable action avgvstvs contrariwise tyrant worke owne destruction cruelty hatred perrils prince doth therefore punish seldome mildely temperately minde example parent moderation fruitfully vsed schooles campes amongst beast seruants yea vsed nature example bee whose king hath sting prince punisheth eyther punisheth owne another man cause owne cause ought rigorous liueth high fortune needeth solace reuenge another man cause according law amend make better secure thing seldomnesse punishment effect often set light despised shutting vp setteth downe detestation crueltie mischifes ouerthrowes grow chap nero caesar haue determined write clemencie requisite great men world studie moderate mind may doe better meditate preheminence th haue aboue end sort may serue thee mirrour shew thee hy selfe sort thou mayest receiue perfite contentment thereby although true fruite vertuous action haue done without vertues themselues recompence whatsoeuer worthy themselues yet certaine pleasure examine visit good conscience euery wayes fixe man eye vpon infinite multitude turbulent seditious passionate bathe selues willingly men blouds yea owne haue broken yoake restraineth speak thus himselfe himselfe amongst mortall men haue beene agreeable god haue chosen liefetenant vpon earth haue power life death ouer nation lyeth hand dispose estate condition euery man fortune pronounceth mouth intendeth euery man shall haue possesse life whole nation city conceiue occasion reioyce commandements nation whatsoeuer flourisheth good fauour vpon least inkling shall giue many thousand sword haue beene sheathed peace shall drawne againe power ordaine nation shall exterminated shall bee transported one country another franchised made sub ect king shall conquered whose head shall adorned royall wreath citties shall ruinated builded thus possessed great power neyther hath wrath youthly heate neyther folly insolence men haue often made temperate loose patience neither proude designe make shew power causing men feare glorie frequent amongst monarch haue neuer inforced mee chastise put man death wrongfully sword hidden nay kept sheath bloud meanest subiects carefully spared although man haue many imperfection yet regard man gracious mine eye seuerity hidden clemencie apparant watch haue ouer selfe yeelde account lawes obscuritie haue brought light mine action haue pardoned one reason youth another olde man magistracie obscuritie faultie found occasion mercie bare loue selfe immortall god summon day yeeld vp reckoning readie account whole world caesar thou mayest boldly speake thing thou hast imbraced vnder thy protection safeguard tho hast taken nothing commonwealth eyther violence cunning thou hast wished purchased innocence praise rare yet hath bin granted prince thou loosest thy paine thy singular bountie hath met ingratefull misconceiuing subiects one acknowledgeth good thou hast done neuer man beloued another thou art romane people whose great continuall felicitie thou art thou hast laide waightie burthen thy shoulder man speaketh former yeares either empire augustus tiberius neyther seeke patterne besides thy selfe whereby may gouerne life one yeare thy gouernement sheweth hope yeares follow would hardly imagined thy bountie borrowed time naturall man long time conceale imperfection action suddenly discouer hidden nature thing containe verity grow hath firmitie increase time time waxe better better romane people much perplexed whilst stood expectation whereunto thy generous nature would apply selfe first men desire accomplished assured feared thou wilt forget thy selfe suddenly much felicity maketh men ouergreedie neyther desire time tempered stay themselues vpon good befalne euery one ascendeth great vnto greater haue attained thing hoped embrace strange designes yet thy cittizens confesse happie nothing added felicitie except perpetuall many thing cause confesse thus much namely great assured repose commodity life good befalls man hardly vpon end yeares furthermore iustice placed aboue iniurie represent vnto themselues see excellent forme publique gouernement containeth requisite establish perfect libertie prouided seconded continuall diligence principally great little rauished considering thine affabilitie equall answerable men expectation touching thine vertues euery one partaketh according proportion fortune expecteth lesse thy large general depend vpon thy clemencie neyther one assured innocence rather prostrate himselfe thy clemency readie excuse winke euery man fault chap ii altho gh cie ignity p inces serueth guilty especiall yet innocent vertuous reape profit thereby bvt know thinke clemency emboldneth men wicked standeth stead except fault committed vertue onely ceaseth amongst innocent first euen vse physique honourable amongst sicke amongst whole although nocent cry vpon clemencie yet innocent forbeare reuerence moreouer clemencie hath place person innocent qualitie person putteth danger clemencie onely assisteth innocent oftentimes vertue likewise reason tim may become thing may oppressed punished praised moreouer great part men may grow amendment liues yet must alwayes pardon greater number offend difference betwixt good bad men taken away followeth confusion breaking forth errours must therefore moderation practised know th distinguish good mind reprobate neyther ought prince haue confused vulgar neither restrained clemency great cruelty pardon pardon none must holde meane moderation hard obserued whatsoeuer like equitie requireth must incline humanitie rigor chap ii bvt thing shall fitly decided another place diuision booke present diuide matter three part first shall serue preface induction second shall expresse nature habitude clemencie whereas vice counterfeit vertues cannot diistnguished except thou set downe markes whereby may knowne thirdly enquire minde attaineth vertue fortifieth himselfe thereby vse maketh owne must needes appeare vertues none conuenient man none humane onely amongst v stoicks maintaine man sociable creature made common good others also amongst giue n ouer pleasure whose speech action tend particular profite man seeke repose idlenes hath found clemencie vertue agreeable nature loueth peace restrain th hand others clemenci becommeth man doth prince great power honourable full glorie great potentate vse comfort many contrariwise force pernicious serueth end offend others man cannot sufficiently expresse firme well grounded greatnesse men b much th highly raised aboue th obserue k pe continuall watch safetie common euery one particular vpon whose approach runne away euill ne red prince life grounded vpon good reason neyther basenesse madnesse one man yea sometimes olde decrepit many thousand attempt vpon point enemy weapon redeeme one soule death many one olde weake man sometimes excellent comparison euen whole bodie serueth soule meanes therof seemeth great fairer appeareance wheras soule contrariwise lye hid inuisible without certaine knowledge place remaineth yet notwithstanding hand feete eye doe serue skin bulwarke defendeth stayeth maketh v runne hither thither pleasure couetous trauell whole sea become rich ambitious presently fer right hand burned voluntarily leap fire infinite multitude inuiron one onely soule gouerned guided reason selfe would otherwise depresse oppresse owne force except sustained counsaile chap iiii therefore loue owne refuse vndergoe againe vnitie contexture great empire shall diuided many partes euen shall rome cease commaund shee refuseth neglecteth obey therefore wondered loue prince king tutor publique state name soeuer called priuate familiar men best iudgement doe thinke concerneth commonwealth greater importance toucheth owne particular followeth vpon whose safetie whole commonwealth hath eye deerely lo ed th n time past caesar vnited enbosomed himselfe commonwealth rome one might separated without ruine neede force head chap v seemeth discourse estranged farre mine intended purpose similitude head member clemencie wholy necessarie prince since subiects expose themselues danger speake truth neerly concerneth matter may truely conclude thon art soule commonwealth shee bodie thou seest thinke necessary clemencie thou seemest spare thy selfe thou sparest others thou oughtest therefore beare euill subiects otherwise thou wouldest doe languishing member sometimes neede bloudletting take heed lest veine opened largely sickenesse requireth clemency therefore said agreeable vnto men nature especially best befitteth prince findeth people preserue greater matter wherein shew herselfe little hurteth priuate cruelty prince displeasure warre whereas amongst vertues certaine concord agreement neyther one better honest yet vertues fit person magnanimity becommeth euery mortall man yea euen basest abiectest man world greater manly repulse aduerse fortune yet magnanimity sheweth selfe amply greater fortune appeareth powerfull tribunall neere earth whatsoeuer house clemencie commeth maketh peaceable pallace rarer wonderfull wonderfull whose wrath nothing make head whose seuere sentence euen condemned giue consent man question nay extraordinarily angry dare intreat thing lay hold himselfe vse power mercifully mildely thinke eart man kill contrary law man pardon selfe great minde becommeth great fortune mounteth himselfe high hee raise himselfe aboue embraceth likewise bringeth ground propertie great minde pleasing peaceable setled despising iniuries offence raised higher estate womanish qualitie enraged wrath manner wilde beast generous bite trample downe vnder feete elephant lion passe haue murthered cast downe beast haue noble heart obstinate inexorable cruell anger b commeth king much eminent aboue reason displeasure maketh himselfe equall giue pardon giue dignitie haue endangered deserued loose estate doth man else except hath power principallity life often taken superiour neuer giuen inferiour saue property excellent fortune may neuer wondred hath gotten opportunity doe god doe whose benefite good euill men borne world prince therefore taketh vpon minde god let willingly entertaine subiects good profitable leaue rest men make vp number let reioice som som let suffer chap vi crueltie dispe pleth city country merci maketh fortunate thinke solitude desolation would bee citie world people going comming incessantly spacious streetes cease justle one another oftentimes something hindereth walke violent torrent man would staie three streetes requisite one time three theater much corne consumed gathered many country man leaue none seuere iudge would absolue hee amongst receiuers treasurer shall get quietus est strictly examined doth others euer accuser without fault know whether man difficult giue pardon hath often deserued begge wee faultie one lesse one deliberate purpose driuen vnto aduenture drawne men wickednesse sometimes haue constantly perseuered one good resolution haue lost innocence griefe spight selues neither present doe amisse vntill last houre life shall still full sinne although man hath well purged minde nothing trouble deceiue yet sinning hee attainted innocencie chap vii strong reason perswade prince mercifull subiects haue made mention god behold heare excellent patterne present vnto prince conforme himselfe thervnto say hee deale subject sort hee would haue god deale expedient v god neuer excuse pardon fault persecute v rigour bee great prince world found liue assurance whose member aruspices gather vp mercifull god punish fault mightie men confounding lightning much man hath charge ouer men exercise empire mercifull minde thinke whether state world gracious fairer eye faire bright day thing shaken thundercrackes lightning flash euerie side one estate quiet moderate empire faire shining heauen kingdome crueltie raigneth may compared troublesome obscure time vnder euery one trembleth waxeth pale reason sodaine crackes thunder troubleth others wonderfully troubled part pardon priuate men easily reuenge themselues obstinately may bee hurt sorrow commeth injurie besides feare contempt reuenge injurie seemeth rather bee infirmitie clemencie hee may easily reuenge yet forbeareth obtaineth certaine commendation mercie men bare qualitie may freely exercise hand contest striue giue libertie passion stroke betwixt equal light exclamation much intemperance wordes ill beseemeth majestie chap viii thinkest thou grieuous matter libertie speech bee taken king permitted inferiours saiest thou seruitude emperie condition different lie hidden community exceed whose ver ue appeare struggle long time whose vice lie hidden obscuritie common report awakeneth action wordes therefore men bee carefull reputation men speake much diuers place whether doe well uill many thing vnlawfull thee permitted v thy benefit may walke alone part citie without feare although accompanied man man attend home without sword side fulnesse thy peace thou must liue armed thou canst wander thy fortune besiege thee whether soeuer thou goest great traine follow thee beholde whereunto soueraigntie subject cannot become lesse necessitie common thee god tied vnto heauen permitted descend thence neither secure thee descend throne thy greatnesse thou art nayled thy greatnesse men know dessignes businesse wee may goe forth returne change fashion without publique note taken v thou canst bee hidden sunne great brightnesse inuironeth thee round towards men bend eye thinkest thou thou commest forth thou risest like sunne thou canst speake people world vnderstand marke thou saist thou canst angrie men tremble thou canst afflict man thee shake feare euen lightning fall men perill men feare chastisement mightie potentate full feare euill without cause doe men consider doth may moreouer patience maketh priuate men disposed indure injury offered easily enough clemencie assured safegard great men frequent reuenge represseth hatred men prouoketh infinitie others reuenge ought sooner faile cause libertie speake thou knowest cynna hauing found thee mine enemy campe knowne thee sugg sted born enemie vnto saued thy life restored thee thy patrimonie day thou art happie rich conquerours beare booke equalled e first chap animateth nero continue well begunne gouernment plac bilitie hee hath thetherto vsed secondeth counsailes praise serue spurres good minde chiefly mooued mee nero caesar addresse dedicate discourse clemen vnto thee speech thine rauishe mee admiration ime hard afterwards recited others generous speech argumet great mind greater lenitie studied fitted flatter men eares sodainly brake forth brought thy beautie cotended thy fortune publike eye censure men burrus captaine thy gard man honour knowne v one hauing charge carrie two theefs execution laboured thou wouldest signe sentence giuen deferred diuers time insisted last might dispatched thy owne heartsgriefe thy dist st h drawne writing bosome deliuered thy hand thou cryedst would could neyther reade write speech worthie bee heard nation inhabite romane empire neighbour country scarcely assured libertie likewise minde might arme themselues prosperitie verie worthie reuiued open assembly liuing men whereof king prince might make vse tak oath vnto th ir subiects speech worthie ancient innocencie mankind auour whereof former ag wax yong againe truly bodie wherein v ought accord equitie clemencie resigne ag happie pure chap ii dare well hope promise caesar greater part hereof shall come pas presageth continuance neroes clemencie comfort subiects amase enemy clemencie thin shall little little published spread thorow bodie thine empire thinges shall conforme themselues according example thou giuest good health proceedeth head afterwardes causeth member nimble strong contrariwise languish spirit quickneth bee amated thy cittizens associate shall worthie bountie good maners shal reestablished thorow whole world shal extended euerie place suffer insist little longer one point intent flatter thine care custome rather offend thee speaking truth please thee flatterie cause desire thou shouldest bee familiarly exercised knowledge thy good word action truly one day thou mayest say doe judgment thou sayst doest naturall aptitude thy minde consider selfe many great detestable speech prince entred men heart ordinarie mouthes deadly hate let pursue prouided alwayes feare whereunto resembleth greeke verse willeth dead solid earth fire mixt others kinde know spirit prodigious hatefull haue expressed violent furious conceit plentiful manner haue neuer yet heard proud word vttered good mercifull prince thou art doe forsooth slackly thou mayest remorse delayes also vntill time thou art inforced thereunto thou write draweth thee hatred good letter yet thou doest temporizing delaying diuers time chap iii clemencie definition thereof bvt least time goodly pleasing name clemencie happily deceiue v let v see clemencie one end tendeth clemencie moderation minde restraineth power man hath reuenge himselfe gracious moderation superiour towards inferiour establishing punishment surest way shall bee set downe diuers definition feare least one suffice expresse forme thereof may speake escape v one may therefore say inclination minde tending shew himselfe mercifull ought chastise definition haue opposition although bee one draweth nearest truth wee say clemencie kill men neuer saw met way intent lessen number killing tooke pleasure killing moreouer content murther tortured body busir procrustes pirate first beate prisoner afterwards burne death dust truely pleasure thether therefore doth chiefest good ascend whence may bee drawne force whereby neyther entrance giuen sorrow hope feare thing may indamnifie lessen greatnesse chiefest good vertue may ascend thereunto steppe steepie rocke must broken shee stand stifly whatsoeuer shall happen endure onely patien also willing knowing euery difficultie time law nature good souldier endure wound number scarres though thrust throw many weapon dying loue captaine whose sake h breatheth last vertue haue ancient precept minde march god whosoeuer complaineth weepeth mourneth compelled doe commanded notwithstanding violently enforced doe enjoyned madnesse rather bee drawne follow great truth thorow sortishnesse ignorance thy condition thou shouldest lament misfortune befalne thee shouldest amazed diffident thou couldest endure hapneth well good euill say sicknesse death parent friend weaknesse incumbrance mortall life let v couragiously endure common condition thing created submitteth v vnto obliged vnto endure accident life without troubling selues casualty know auoid borne vnder royall domination libertie obey god chap xvi hee concludeth happie life consisteth vertue shew th counsailes vertue giueth good shee bringeth true felicitie therefore placed vertue wil counsaile thee thou thinke neyther good euill hapneth vnto thee neyther vertue malice afterwardes meanes god thou remaine alwayes irme confident euill far breath thy power thou follow god promised thee thou behauest thy self manner great thinges answerable diuine thou shalt enforced nothing thou shalt want nothing thou shalt free assured exempt dammage thou shalt vndertake nothing vaine thou shalt doe thou pleasest without trouble disturbance thinges shall fall thou wishest aduersitie shall touch thee shall vertue onely thus perfect diuine suffice liue happily suffice say sufficient want contented euery thing desireth nothing whatsoeuer hath gathered thing himselfe hath need externall thing tendeth vnto vertue although hath gotten greater part way yet hath need indulgence fauour fortune yet entangled amidst care life hath yet acquit himselfe bondes tie captiue world difference tied lockt vp som fettered hee hath gotten high lifted vp earth draweth chaine yet full libertie reputed man wholly free chap xvii hauing highly spoken soueraigne good happie life taxeth flatter vice ther fore one barke philosophie alleage accustomed speakest thou better thou liuest whence commeth thou flatterest man greater thy selfe thou esteemest money necessarie aide thou art moued thou loosest thou pest thou hearest news death thy wife thy friend thou art glad thou bee praised spoken well place detraction torment thee thy countrie ground better trimmed naturall vse requireth kee est thou ordinary rule taking thy repast meaneth thy house ter furnished men mooueth thee drinke wine older thy selfe euery thing well ordered thy hous whence commeth thou plantest tree serue vse shade whence thy wife weareth reuenew rich family hanging care cause thy page richly apparelled hast thou art thy house know serue table thy plate set vpon thy boord rashly euerie man pleasure serued course thou hast caruer cut vp thy dainty adde hereunto thou wilt hast thou good beyond art thou master many good thou knowest number art thou dishonest negligent thou knowest three foure thy seruants dissolu thou hast great number thy memorie sufficeth contain name hereafter assist thee speaking euill besides propose selfe thou thinkest present behold answer wil make thee wise satisfie thy displeasure b tter shall wise require therefore selfe equall est better worst sufficeth cut day day part vice checke imperfection health neither shall entire prepare vngu nt exact remedy paine gou e contenting self trouble often bee losse furious burning bee compared thee swiftnesse pa e weake runner chap xviii speake selfe drown vice fo alreadie hath gott n ground reproach new wiseman condemning men vice beginneth owne hath desire carrie nothing away themselues thou wilt astonished seeme vnto thy selfe left without thy selfe depart thee rich request thee high esteeme briefe rich serue thou art slaue thine chap xxiii rich honest regard getting respect possession vse giue ouer therefore forbid philosopher haue money man hath condemned wisedome perpetuall pouertie wise man may haue great wealth taken man bought effusion men houered way way without staying selfe resolutely good without declining also vnto euill tell thee befalleth mee giue infirmity afterwards name thou pleasest great loue parsimony confesse like bed heat motion body men body serenus healthfull enough yet yet well accustomed thereto haue certaine trembling agitation resembling calme sea l ke tempest ceased haue therefore need harder remedy wandring erre waye thou desirest bee shaken great perfect thing approacheth felicity god stable seate mind grecian call nonlatin alphabet wherof democritus hath written excellent volume call vnto himselfe march equall traine fauourable himselfe behold hi attempt good eye ioyfull content neither raising depressing himselfe ouermuch called tranquillitie let v enquire generall wee may attaine hereunto thou shalt take much p blique remedy thou wilt meane discouer whole vice whereby euerie man may know part thou likewise mayst vnderstand le trouble tho hast loathing thy selfe tying themselues faire shew labouring vnder great title would willingly discouer themselues know shame entertaineth cause vexed leuity anxiety cotinuall change p rpose alwaies better pleased haue left tho watch gape vaine hope adde vnto men likewise tra sported life mean inconstancie thorow sloath liue would beganne moreouer innumerable property one effect vice displease themselues springeth intemperature mind fearfull scarce prosperous desire whereas dare much desire attaine wholie vpon hope alwaies instable mutable must needes befall liue suspen whole life expectation teach inforce themselues dishonest difficult thing whereas labour vaine vexed fruitlesse disgrace neither sorie haue done euill willed vaine repent themselues begun feare beginne againe afterward surprised confusion mind cannot find issue neither commaund obay desirres lead life cannot bee exempt confusion haue mind tyed languishing amidst fruitlesse vowes desire grieuous vnto wh n despight misfortune trauaileth would haue recourse vnto repose secret udies mind canot endure fixed affaire world desirous action nature vnqui hauing little solace himselfe therefore delight drawne occupation mini red vnto b ing busied certainty therein mind endureth neither house solitud walles displeasant thus abandoned himselfe vnwillingly beholdeth himselfe thence proceedeth tediousness contempt himselfe perpetuall agitation mind sad feeble patience repose especially hee ashamed confesse cause shame tormenteth inwardly couetous desire close vp heart none finding issue strangle one anther thence commeth sadnesse consumption thousand flouds assault vncertaine mind held suspence enterprise hath begunne abated remembrance remedilesse estate present affaire th nce groweth thought maketh detest repose enioy complaine themselues haue nothing beare endlesse hatred enuie men prosperitie vnhappy idlenesse nurse enuie desire dead could outstrippe others enuie concieued men fortune disgrace causeth mind fret murmure fortune accuse mallice time retire himselfe corner apart stoope vnder torment fretting consuming himselfe man mind swift ready mooued reioyceth much occasion offered exercise himselfe aboue others pleaseth men malignant whose mind sharpened ordinarily whetted mannaging affaire euen certaine vlcers glad bee rubbed desire bee handled itch content except man scratch spirit seazed desire malignant vlcers take pleasure trauaile affliction certaine infirmity delight body kind paine witnesse turne themselues side refresh themselues changing bed achilles homer sometimes lay vpon belly vpon backe could neuer remaine one state true act sicke man able suffer thing long time thinke health consisteth toss ng turning hence diuers trauels vndert ken shoares sought lenitie alwaies enemie thing present sea land aduentureth daily let v goe campania delicate soyle delighteth v let v visite wood country let v visite forrest calabria let v seeke pleasure amidst desert sort wandring eye may relieued beholding pleasure strange solitude sauage place must go see tarentum hauen much esteemed ayre sweet winter stately house ancient people let v returne rome backe eares haue long time estraged applause theater circensian sport would take pleasure see men bloud spilt behold one voyage begetteth another haue seene one thing long manner man fly himselfe pro iteth flie hee cannot escape hee runneth himselfe hath dangerous company attendeth l v therefore know euill presseth v commeth place selues affliction light soeuer ouerwaighty v neither patient labour pleasure cannot beare owne affaire thing else reason hereof haue procured owne aths b cause oftentimes hauing changed deliberation fell backe againe alwaies mette nothing newe meanes whereof life world beganne commonweale produceth candidate sue office defendeth accused giueth aduise touching affaire peace warre also instruct youth great want good maners informeth men mind vertue layeth hold restraineth addicted auarice dissolution least wise hindereth passing priuate house procureth publique good doth either iudge cittie assistant pronounceth briefe sentence processe straungers citizen haue teacheth iustice sheweth piety wisedome purenesse contempt death excellent goad good conscience thou employest thy time studie thou hast lost honour due execution thy charge concerning publique neither shalt thou exempted neither souldier standeth front battell defendeth right left wing also gardeth gate standeth sentinel place though daungerous yet necessary keepeth watch hath gouernment ammunition house charge though bee bloudy yet haue execute pay well rest thou shalt retire thy selfe thy study thou shalt auoyd care tortureth man life thou shalt troublesome thy selfe vnprofitable others thou shalt get thee many friend better sort men accept thee vertue although shee poore abiect yet shee neuer obscured sheweth beames brightnes farre whosoeuer capable acknowledge follow step renounce conuersation flie humane societie liue onely priuate respect solitude depriued honest occupation find nothing last whereto addict selfe shall beginne build house ouerturne others shall rne sea place shall cause riuers alter course dispence time euilly nature gaue v bestow well sometimes sparing sometimes ouerprodigall v imploy sort yeeld account thereof others haue none left therefore nothing shamefull see old man approue hath liued long time world produce witnes number yeares mine owne part dearest serenus mee thinkes athenodoras submitted himselfe much time fled ouerhastilie confesse well ought somtimes retire selues leasurely secure retreat ensignes displaied without empeachment worldly dignitie valiant assured conquerours make faire honest retreat opinion ought vertue behaue selfe inconstancy worldly affaire disturbe taketh away vertuous man meanes doe good yet ought turne back cast away weapon saue himselfe flight thrust himselfe secret place could bee corner fortune could find ought lesse busie affaire find expedient iudgement make himselfe profitable countrie lawfull beare armes let aspire publique charge must liue priuately let plead put silence let helpe citizen priuate counsell dangerous enter iudgement place let shew himselfe faithfull friend gracious companion temperate guest house theater feast hee haue lost office citizen let vse man therefore great mind haue shut selues within wall one citty haue thrust selues conuersation whole world haue professed world countrey wee might giue vertue spacious field shew herselfe tribunall shut thee art thou admitted plead assist common counsel citty looke backe see great nation people behind thee neuer shall great part bee kept thee greater left thee beware proceed rom thine owne error thou wilt vndertake publique charge except thou consull pritanes embassador supreame dictator thou wilt souldier except thou bee commander tritane although others haue vauntgard fortune hath put thee rereward doe thy deuoire place fight thy voyce thy exhortation thy courage also hath hand cut fight findeth meanes animate companion standeth onely encourageth cry must thou doe fortune hath drawne thee first ranke publique charge yet stand thou helpe thy cry thy mouth bee stopped yet stand helpe thy silence industry good citizen neuer vnprofitable hearing sight contenance becke obstinate silence gate may profit euen certaine holesome drug onely smell without either touch tast doe comfort greatly vertue whether sowed locked selfe whether authority accident whether shee bee constrained scantle sailes idle mute confined straight lodged large spreadeth farre vnperceiued performeth great profitable good briefe serueth whatsoeuer estate countenance shee bee considered thinkest thou example man liueth chap xi maintain th alwayes doctrine stoickes distinguisheth u ous wise raiseth aboue al humane fortune describeth contentment discourse mine appertaineth ignorant person haue little knowledge depraued iudgement vnto wise man hee must walke fearefully slowly great confidence hath selfe hee doubteth en ounter fortune neither euer giue place vnto neither hath cause time feare onely numbreth starres possession dignity owne body likewise eye hand whatsoeuer maketh life deare vnto yea himselfe thing hired liueth though hee lent vnto himselfe ready restore whole willingly redemand neither therefore mispraiseth hee himselfe hee knoweth hee owne diligently circumspectly shall doe thing religious holy man wont doe thing committed trust whensoeuer hee shall bee commanded make restitution hee question fortune say giue thanks haue possessed hath cost mee much entertaine thing thou hast giuen mee thou commandest gratefully willingly restore againe thou wilt haue ought continue hand euen keep thou bee wayes minded restore vnto thee redeliuer thy hand money plate house family whatsoeuer nature summon v first gaue v credit wee answere receiue minde better thou gauest seuenth remedy prise life ee possesse neede dispose selues couragiously vnto death whatsoeuer casually neither delay hide selfe willingly readily deliuer thee thou gauest knew take thee euill returne place whence thou camest shal liue badly knoweth die well wee must therefore aboue thing set light life account soules amongst number thing hate saith cicero skirmisher sort desire beg liues wee auour pretend contemne know like befalleth v oftimes cause dying die fearefully fortune maketh sport selfe whereto saith shee shall reserue thee wretched fearefull creature thou art thou shalt receiue wound skarres thou knowest yeeld thy throat thou shalt liue longer die sooner manfully entertainest thy death plucking backe thy necke opposing thy hand hee shall feare death neuer doe thing worthy liuing man knoweth ordinance life death decreed presently ordered time hee conceiued liue according rule ordinance prefixed likewise lesse constancy mind hee per orme none thing befall may seem sodain foresee come though already past meane repulse assault necessity shake attend constantly know nothing new oppresse men make themselues beleeue misfortune shall euer surprise thinke nothing pleasure content sodainenesse eyther sicknesse captiuity ruine fire know well tumultuous retreat danger nature locked e oftimes haue men cried fire water amongst neighbour oftimes haue torch taper carried dead body man child past dores oft haue heard noice high building sodenly fell downe ground one night hath carried away diuers friend made pallace market place company hath cut hand promised sworne fidelity vnto shall wonder danger haue houered long finally faln vpon part ready set sayle eighth remedy rem mber euils v oth r men cannot happen consequently detaine selues good time thinke vpon storme mine owne part well neuer bee ashamed danger may befall mee publius vehement spirit either tragicke comicke poet often giuen ouer mimicke foperies ordinarily hee vsed delight common people amongst many conceiueth hee could attaine hee pretended light scarsly toucheth heart hee promiseth himselfe thing shall succeed hee desired chap xiiii ought likewise accomodate selues affaire without presuming child slaine whose good taken willingly entertaine death libertie whatsoeuer thought answered worthily man may say caius might haue granted life cannius affraid caius faith well knowne like command
