according custome propose alwaies question followed philosopher traine approched neere place toombe stood whervpo daily sacrifice made diuus caesar cannius quoth thinkest thou whereon fixest thou thy mind resolued said cannius marke swift moment time soule shall feele passing forth promised found thing would returne euery one friend tell estate soules behold tranquillity middest tempest behold mind worthy eternitie summoneth destinie argument truth seeing himselfe readie deliuer last breath questioned departing soule onelie learne vntill death learneth something likewise death selfe man philosophied longer great man shall bee obscured slightly praise shall bee carefully eternized wee commend thee euerlasting memorie worthy cannius greater part caius cruell murthers chap xv bvt profiteth nothing haue cast away cause priuate sadnesse twelft remedy ought despise humane thing beare contentedly imposed v laugh democritus sometimes hatred mankind possesseth thee troope many fearfull sinnes present themselues thou bethinkest thy selfe rare simplicity vnknowne innocency sieldome faith except ministreth profite disaduantages dissolution hatefull aduantages ambition excessiue proud cannot containe selfe within limit boasteth villanies mind blinded obscured vertues ouerturned neither may hope neither profitable v haue darknesse ouercloudeth thing must therfore dispose selues vice common sort displeasing vnto v comparison betwixt democritus heraclitus rather may ridiculous rather let v imitate democritus heraclitus man often went abroad wept laught man thing doe seemed misery man folly thing therefore set light endured patient mind fitting laugh life bewaile adde herevnto also deserueth better mankind laugheth thereat bewaileth leaueth good hope foolishly bewaileth dispaireth recouery therof cannot abstaine laughter beholding world doth greater mind spendeth himselfe teares meaneth lightest passion mind thinketh nothing great nothing seuere thing serious great preparation show men let euerie one present vnto himselfe occasion may either dismay reioyce v shall know bion said true affaire men answerable beginning life neither holie seuere designes conceiued onely soules better peaceably behold men publique manner imperfection torment himselfe thus men affliction inhumane pleasure delighteth men euills euen vnprofitable humanity weepe counterfeit sadnesse man carrieth forth child buried thine misfortune likewise behooueth thee carry thy selfe thou yeeld much vnto thy sorrow requireth custome demandeth many men powre forth teares shew often haue eye dry want witness sorrow iudging absurd thing weepe men discomforted deepe impression hath euil fixed mind depend men opinion sorrow selfe simplest thing conuerted dissimulation thirteenth remedy thinke good men neither miserable li e death cause ought resemble followeth another point accustomed dismay make men pensiue without cause good men die miserably crate compelled dye prison rutillius liue exile pompey cicero yeeld neck strucken whome formerly defended cat liuing image vertues leaning sword loose life country libertie must need torment v see fortune recompence good desert vniustly may man hope himselfe seeth best men suffer worst affliction shall done hereupon consider euery one behaued himselfe constantly valiant desire mind perished ffeminately basely nothing lost either worthy vertue please thee vnworthy man bewaile cowardise hatefull see great men dying valiantly cause men catifes coward let v praise often worthy praised say constant happy art thou thou hast fled humane casualty hatred sicknesse thou hast left thy prison thou wert worthy thy god opinion euil fortune vnworthy fortune might thing would retire themselues instant death looke backe vnto life must haue hand laid neither weepe one laugheth one weepeth one hath himselfe wiped away teares hath teares effected hee vnworthy teares shall weepe hercules hee burned aliue regulus l sh pierced many nailes cato couragiously endured woundes gaue himselfe men light expence time found meanes make themselues eterned dying attained immortality yet another great subiect carefull thought thou disguise counterfeit cunningly foureteenth remedy e hypocrisie neither euer shew thy selfe bee outwardly thou art inwardly re mbling liues many ar fained fashioned ely ostentation death stand thus alwaies guard feare surprised estate wee accustomed wee neuer voide care long opinion gouerneth v men estimate person oftentimes see v many thing fall discouer v spight heart although retired obseruation man selfe succeedeth well yet liue alwaies thus disguised doth afflict affright life would enioy thousand pleasure shee beautified open simple manner action set vaile manner true life hazard contempt thing discouered vnto men disdaine approch somewhat neare vnto obserue better bee contemned reason simplicity bee tormented perpetuall dissimulation teenth keep measure solitude conue detriment eyther honour body good wise man loose nothing hee hath good inclosed himselfe hee wayes putteth confidence fortune hee entirely possesseth rich contenting himselfe vertue hath neede accidentall thing therefore may neither increase decre se hauing attained height place increase fortune taketh away nothing shee hath giuen shee giueth vertue therefore cannot take away vertue free inuiolable immutable assured h rdned casualty shee neyther may bee shaken ouercome shee holdeth eye fixed dreadfull obiects world shee neuer changeth countenance whether present prosperity tempt good men wicked men hurt vertuous men much doe one another man bee harmed except hee bee weake hee harmeth euill men bee weake good good cannot bee offended resemble wise man cannot offended remember man good wiseman saist thou socrates condemned vniustly receiued iniurie place wee ought obserue may fall man may outrage mee yet shall iniured thiefe stolne something grange country locked vp house hath robbed mee haue lost nothing man may bee guilty although hath committed offence liue owne wife imagining hee lay man hee shall bee adulterer although wife shall bee adulteresse one hath giuen poyso hauing intermixed meate lost force giuing hee guilty although euill ensue thereupon ceaseth bee murtherer hath thrust sword although haue put blow benefite cloake wickedness accomplished regard cannot done vniustly followeth therefore man cannot doe iniury wise man neither oughtest thou wonder man doe iniury since man bring profite wise man wanteth nothing receiue way gift euill man bestow hee grieueth assault hee patiently endure iniuries fortune farre easily suffereth hee rich mighty sort instrument fortune chap ix therefore endureth misfortune hee would abide rigor winter iniuries wise man colde heate rain sickenesse raines heates accident neither iudgeth hee man well hee imagineth thing counsell incident wise man rest doe nothing prudence action consist fraudes ambush wrongfully accuse v suborne witnesse v disgrace v presence great men attempt accustomed practises amongst men haue either leasure credite likewise ordinary iniury man take profit man thought make seuenth brideling pa ion iudgeth euill otherwaies passionate men doe conuerteth good hand reward long deserued inheritance recouered much trauell credite house wherein hee done faithfull office wiseman neither liueth hope feare disburtheneth himselfe difficulty furthermore man iniured except moued hee moued troubled soone touched vpright man neuer vexed hee brideleth extrauagant discourse enioyeth deepe peaceable repose although iniury touch moue hinder yet hee attainted choller groweth pretended iniury reason hee displeased hee knoweth man cannot wrong thence proceedeth hee walketh alwayes vpright countenance merry cheare possessed continuall ioy sort strengthneth selfe stead abashed iniuries men may offer disa ters may happen life hee maketh vse difficulty meanes know make proofe vertue let v make profite beseech discourse let v listen attentiuely heart eare wise man behaueth himselfe outraged although wee well aduised cut thing wantonnesse violent couetousnesse pride arrogancy wiseman seeketh liberty without medling vice neither question whether bee lawfull doe iniury wiseman beareth iniury continueth firme patient confident courage sort haue diuers borne away contumely contumelie iniury small man either complaineth reuengeth himselfe therfore neither lawes themselues prefixe penalty thereunto passion mooued certaine basenes hart displeased either dishonorable deed word example lord hath giue audience day yet hath admitted hath carelesly turned head aside spake vnto hath mocked men stead placing vpper end table hath set shall call complaint like vomiting sicke soule whereunto subiect ouer delicate liue much ease haue leisure note particular worse doe follow mind weakned made effeminate much repose become insolent want knowing true iniurie mooued thing part proceede hee either sayth doth vnderstandeth himselfe meanes whereof mooued passionate pretending bee iniured sheweth himselfe man heartlesse witlesse vndoubtedly hee supposeth himselfe bee contemned misprision proceedeth nought else base vilde abiect courage wise man contemned man knoweth owne greatnesse hee resolued man except himselfe attempt thing aduantage disaduantage touching misery rather distraction mind farre hee ouercomming feeleth cross likewise although ouerthrow paine weaknesse body losse friend child ruine country afflicted warre deny wise man hath sence euils wee say hard stupide like flint barre iron vertue hath sence suffereth ninth although feele stroakes hath remedy hand whence followeth cure deserueth name considering hurt rather imagination thing consider pretend doe thee wrong chap xi confesse wiseman receiueth stroks rebateth healeth maketh without effect lesse hee feeleth neither vseth accustomed vertue constancy patience respect either marketh thinketh worthy derision besides wheras greater part contumely offered proud insolent men know carry good fortune wise man hath meanes despise swolne affection constancy greatnes mind greatest vertues passeth swiftly aboue vanity vaine appearance dreame nightly vision haue nothing solide true thinketh likewise men base haue sufficient courage contemne highly raised aboue contumely called contempt outrageth another doth contempt man contemneth better excellent himselfe although hee say doe thing contemners accustomed young child strike parent face infant hath towsed torne mother locke spit vpon discouered thing sight seruants haue hidden hath abstained dishonest disorderly speech yet none doe wee call contumely doe contempt cause wee beare vrbanity slaues ridiculously ensignes markes iustice play like sport good earnest field mar market place senate child sitting riuers side make house sand busied som great mater occupied stone walles building house may make tame know therefore answ red opposed v wise man hee hath neither receiued iniury contumelie punisheth reuengeth himselfe punisheth chap xiii bvt thou thinkest infirmity mind attendeth wiseman place hee answereth questious first wiseman suffereth insolency young old thou mayest obserue others though vpon cause physition angry lunatike person interprete sick man reproches worst vexed feuer forbidden drinke colde water affection hath wiseman towards men physition hath towards sicke patient disdaineth handle priuities haue neede remedy see vrines excrement heare outrage feare maketh vtter wise man knoweth iet gownes ap arrelled purple although well coloured faire sicke diseased sort hee looketh vpon intemperate sicke men therefore hee angry sicknesse haue beene bold speake iniuriously would heale hee setteth light honour tormenteth himselfe little despight insolencies euen taketh little pleasure begger honour hee iudge contumelie basest companion returne like hee hath saluted hee neither waxe prouder many rich men doe honour hee knoweth differ nothing beggers nay wretched one neede little much againe wiseman bee moued saluting king medes attalus asia hee passe without speaking disdainefull countenance hee knoweth well hee hath little cause enuy prince state condition great famine hath charge keepe ouersee sicke mad men shall bee angry one negociate market place neere temple castor make traffique buy slaues haue shoppes filled troupe base slaues saluteth mee name thinke goodnesse vnder none euill men therefore neglect man humanity inhumanity hee doe king thou hast vnder thy gouernements parthian medes bactrians thou containest feare neither darest thou lay thy bowe reason nothing regarde thee thou must handle slaues desire likewise bee rid thee seeke new lord wise man offended man iniurie although one reckoning others yet hee esteemeth alike lesse fooles one hee embase himselfe farre either hee bee moued iniury contumely hee neuer secure security proper good wise man neither hee endure reuenging contumelie offered honour must needes hee whosoeuer displeased iniurie done likewise glad honoured hand chap xiiii men possessed great madnesse seco whence commeth hee confesseth readily fault one thinke woman offer outrage matter rich shee many vassal shee haue carry letter though eares laden pendant chaines large spacious yet alike impudent creature except shee bee endowed much science learning shee bee cruell incontinent desire much vexed haue beene repressed lady groome helpes make ready call contumely porter ou r currish pride clerke checke loftinesse groome chamber much wee laugh toyes great pleasure mind bee filled man beholdeth owne quiet amidst tumult men error therfore shall wise man bold approch gate crabbed froward porter affaire importance shall command shall attempt appease rhe porter whatsoeuer hee bee giuing som present wont giue bread meat dog barketh briefe hee disdaine disburse thing enter remembring himselfe certaine bridge man cannot passe ouer without paying towle therefore hee giueth money towleman porter hee knoweth buy sell contrariwise man hath base mind boasteth hee hath spoken freely groome chamber hee hath broken staffe hee hath gotten accesse master caused varlet bee beaten contendeth maketh himselfe aduerse party vaunting hee hath ouercome maketh himselfe equall shall wise man hee bee buffeted cato time enemy gaue boxe eare entred choller neyther reuenged insolencie true hee pardoned iniury hee denied hee receiued hee shewed himselfe couragious protesting hee moued pardoned strucke wee stay longer point knoweth matter thinges man supposeth either good euill wise man opinion different men hee respecteth repute eyther villanous miserable followeth common tract starres retrograde course carry hee himselfe fashion contrary others chap xv cease therefore demand whether wise man shall bee outraged hee strucken fourth reason wise man patient eye pulled base fellowes exclaime open street prince banquet placed lower end set eate amongst groom hee constrained endure indignity despightes may done man honour insolencies eyther great little shall appeare vnto one nature smaller touch shall greater little moue great deale shall stirre measure great mind according extent owne weakenesse considering onely farre patience doth extend thinke doe much allow wiseman terme limit patience allow owne wisdome hath placed confines world haue nothing common therefore cross incommodities aduersities eye eare abhorre present themselues euery side great number shall dismaied therat aud crosseth euery one shall make head together hee deceiueth himselfe wise man may support one thing another cloase magnanimity certaine bound except manacle tie fortune foot hand shee treade v vnder foote neyther thinke thou onely stoicall austeritie epicure haue made choise patterne idlenesse suppose master delight idlenesse meere pastime saith fortune seldom time visiteth wise man neerly vttered manly speech wilt thou speake brauely wholly driue away fortune consider wisemans house narrow without pompe without noice without decking without porter giue refuse entry goer although gate bee kept man yet fortune setteth foot therein knowing well shee shall entertained shee hath credite epicure himselfe hath giuen body pleasure imagine disgesteth iniuries occasion thinke incredible extraordinary aboue nature stoickes pretend epicure saith wise man ought endure iniuries say wise man cannot iniured chap xvi manifest past hee sheweth ndeth word iniury neither hast thou cause conclude repugneth nature doe deny incommodious thing beaten bee enforced maimed member deny iniurie take sense paine name iniury cannot admitted without empeachment vertues reputation let v consider two opinion admitted concent contempt iniurie askest thou wherein differ two stout sword player whereof one dissembleth wound standeth guard looking backe people cry maketh shewe nothing endure haue parted must therfore thinke difference ouer great point properly concerneth v two example teach v contemne iniuries outrage cal shadow suspitions iniurie contemn ought seeke wise man need wel aduised brother worse affectioned towards thee man cond mn affection wold haue v torm lues desire thy affliction hee withdraw thee thy business thy study caesar farre vnlikely hath loued thee brother honoured inclination might seeme vncertaine put thing doubt say thy brother desireth thou shouldst tortured incessant teares vnworthy affection hee would giue ouer thy vnprofitable griefe neither impious brother bewailed neither would pious lamented whose piety well approued thou art resolue thy selfe nothing bee grieuous vnto death distastfull vnto thee vexe thee wayes troubleth spendeth thine eye vnworthy great misery causlesse shewers complaint nothing shall withdraw thy piety much vnprofitable teares thou thinke thou oughtest bee example thy brother eighth ought bee much aduised confidence patience suruiue whereby may instructed sustaine iniuries fortune constancy art thou doe great captaines doe desperate danger vncertaine purposely faine merry demeasure cloake discontent pleasant countenance feare lest souldiers bee discouraged discouering gouernors discontent shew thou countenance contrary thy thought thou canst purge thy selfe sorrow leastwise hide containe inwardly lest appeare endeauour thy selfe thy brother may imitate thee thinke honest whatsoener see thee doe assume courage according temper thy conntenance thou must solace comfort thou canst notwithstand sorrow thou make wanton thine owne chap xxv thing likewise may restraine thee sorrowing extreamely bee thou informe thy selfe nin h eminent vocation lesse occasion haue make neighbour belieue wee aue lost courage vnworthy act committed charge none thing thou doest remaine hidden common consent men hath made thee great maintaine thou art enuironed troup men come comfort thee carefully consider thy thought diligently obserue whether bee fortified griefe besides onely thou know vse prosperity discreetely thou canst endure aduersity manfully obserue thine eye thing free vnto whose passion may couered touching thy self thou canst hide thy self fortune hath placed thee al men y euery man shall know thou hast carried thy selfe conflict whether vpon first assault thou gauest ouer thy weapon thou hast stood confidently battell heretofore fauour emperour thine owne valour haue made thee rise great estate therefore bare vulgar infirmitie ill befitteth thee nothing vilde base man suffer himselfe bee deuoured sorrow griefe lawfull thee behaue thy selfe thy brother opinion conceiued thy study manner permitteth thee many thing men require many thing thy hand expect much thou wouldest haue thing lawfull thee thou sholdest haue drawn al men eies vpon thee much art thou performe thou hast promised men prayse applaude endeuours thy witte whereas haue need thy fortune yet haue neede thy witte watchman thy mind thou canst therefore doe nothing vnworthy profession perfect learned man diuers men repent themselues haue admired thee thou must weepe immoderately although thou art loose part day sleepe seeking thy repose forsake bulke affaire goe trifle country vndertake sprightly conceit long voyage recreat thy body wearied continuall trauell thy weighty charge loose thy selfe thing vnlawfull thee permissible men base condition liue obscurity great dignity prosperity great seruitude lawfull thee doe thing according thine owne mind thou must giue audience thousand person weepe thou art heare diuers men weepe end teares may profitable vnto danger obtaine mercy milde caesar thine bee dried vp yet behold comfort thee greatly proue singular remedy thee eloquence spent vaine palpable flattery cast thine eye vpon caesar thou wouldest disburthen thy selfe sorrowes consider charge fauour hath imposed vpon thee much industry thou owest shalt thou vnderstand thou art bee dispatch thing owne affaire like sort necessity enioyned thee thou art neither respect thine owne profite affect thy study eleuenth wee must consider well good remaine v lea wise haue least long caesar lord world thou canst addict thy selfe pleasure griefe thing el thou art wholly caesar adde hereunto hauing alwayes made world belieue thou louest caesar better thine owne soule lawfull thee long liueth complaine thy fortune hee safety appertaine vnto thee security thou hast lost nothing thine eye must onely bee dried bee ioyfull thou hast thinges hee thee much tell thee without impeachment thy prudence piety thou hast little respect greatnesse long thy body good health thou giuest way thy sorrow whatsoeuer wil shew thee another remedy strong precedent yet familiar time thou retire thy selfe thy house wilt thou haue cause suspect thy sorrow long thou shalt behold caesar godhead sorrow finde accesse vnto thee caesar possesse whatsoeuer thee thou departest occasion giuen sorrow finde thy solitude creep little little thy soule desireth repose thou art therefore intermit time study twelfth study lenifieth sorrow science good letter thou hast long faithfully loued high worthy thought sure expedient pacifie griefes worke yet vnattempted romane wit hard matter mind vehemently deiected thine quickly vndertake pleasing pleasant study yet shalt thou know thy mind fortified recouer himselfe hee may giue ouer grauer study employ himselfe delightfull free grauer austerity thing hee shall intreat vpon draw although bee sicke debate selfe shal breede delight thy spirit shall take pleasure time shall bee setled quieted selfe thou onghtest therefore exercise thy selfe matter importance temper thy mind pleasing study likewise comfort thee much oftentimes thou hee hee borne voide euill hee neyther feareth desireth suffereth thing madnes neuer giue ouer grieuing shall neuer bee aggrieued dead haue sence soule brother discharged long prison freedome full countenance hee hath thee neither shal receiue doe pleasure thinkest thou miserable hee hath left thinges happy hee desireth belieue mee blessed hath need fortune hee much troubled entertaining vanity rich good delight v reason faire fallacious appearance money estate credite like corrupt couetous ambitious men mind possessed paine beheld enuy oppresse adorned threaten profite slippery vncertaine neuer firmely possessed although man doubt come great fortune great care yet maintenance great prosperity accopanied many care thou wilt giue credit inwardly examine truth life punishment cast deep troubled sea tormented continuall ebbes floates rayseth v vp sodaine encreases straight forsaketh v greater loss continually tossing v wee neuer remaine setled place wee liue suspence incertainety beaten one another sometimes shipwrackt alwayes fearefull sayling stormy sea exposed tempest finde hauen death enuy thy brother therfore rest length hee free length hee secure length hee eternall sixteenth call dead liuing liuing dead hath left emperour race thy selfe brother behinde fortune turned fauourable face hee forsooke euen shee stood vnto heaped fauours vpon plentifull hand hee enioyeth open freer heauen humble low tabernacle hee hath attained conspicuous place whatsoeuer receiued blessed soules deliuered earthly bond blessed bosome freely wandreth beholdeth good nature exceeding pleasure thou art deceiued thy brother hath lost light hath attained securer way must walke complaine desteny hee hath left v gone v chap xxix belieue great happinesse dying happy seuenteenth dieth prosperity hath doubt aduantage nothing assured length one day onely humane affaire obscure confused bee vndertake resolue whether thy brother death wrought enuy eighteenth haue long time enuied death redemandeth hand whether hath procured good besides consideration comfort thee thou oughtest think loosing brother thou hast receiued iniury thou hast beene greatly fauoured long appearance prosperity fifth aduersity onely w e make proo e constancy mind life exhausteth course full fayle peaceable sea fauourable wind approue sufficiency pilot must storme encounter v may approue mind therefore discourage thy selfe contrariwise stand firme thy place endure euery burthen laide vpon thee onely affrighted first assault nothing much confoundeth fortune resolute mind hee shewed sonne safety hee shewed nephewes recompence losse sonne time marcia thy affaire areus sate thee comforted thee vnder another name thinke marcia death hath taken thee euer taken mother flatter thee lessen thy losse teares may conquere destinie let v vni e teares let v spend euery day sorrow let sleeples night consume selfe sadnesse let hand violate torne breastes let nayles imprint sorrow face sixth since sorrow vnprofitable death moued thereby wee ought refrain sorrow let discontent exercise extend selfe sort cruelty dead recalled teares fate immoueable euerlastingly fixed misery changed death possesseth whatsoeuer hee hath taken away let sorrowes cease vnprofi able cause let v gouerne selues neither permit passion transport v beyond measure shame master shippe suffer helme bee beaten hand billow neglect sailes shattered wind leaue shippe mercy tempe hee euen shipwracke bee commended holdeth helme hand though sea swallow sinke chap vii seuenth wee must keepe measure sorrow bvt yet natural inclination v bewaile wee loue denies long moderate necessity presseth v retireth astonisheth constant heart onely time friend die also life diuers occasion separated v opinion addeth nature commandeth consider vnbrideled desire bruit beast nature teacheth yet short cowes day two lowe bull neither doth wanton wandring course mare last long wilde beastes haue sented foote young one haue searched sometimes amidst forrest returne backe againe empty dennes dayes surcease rage birdes great chattering flie empty ne t instant appeased keepe accustomed flight creature long time bewaileth want young one man accompanieth owne griefe onely touched sense thereof also conclusion hee hath taken himselfe torment himselfe thus long time eighth proper w rdes nd generate p n torment themselues confusion thing nothing certaine past could assure thee faire bodie thy sonne marueilous care hee honour maintayned middest many eye cittie founded confounded dissolution excesse could sort warrant themselues palliardise hath made soile faire beginning life plunged drunkennesse gourmandise principall care hath beene know eate drinke adde hereunto burning ruines shipwrackes operation surgeon cut member pull braines th ust hand entrailes heale priuie part without excessiue paine banishment thy sonne honester man rutillius prison sure hath bin wiser man socrates stab poinard voluntarily buried breast sure vertuous cato considering thing thou shalt finde happy nature hath retyred good time place securitie considering end could receiue reward life like nothing deceitfull man life nothing tray rous man would haue accepted life except beene giuen vnawares therfore great happines born another happines death neere shorten life cromutius co dus constancy death yet let men temper iudgement law stoicall must reforme resolution put v estate wherein liued call thy remembrance wretched time wherin ianus made present atrius sec dus clyent confiscation thy father good tooke reason confident speech vttered thy father could holde peace se ing men intended onely make v subiect ianus degree mounted soueraigne authority decreed statue raised pompei theater emperour caused reedified beene burned cardus exclaimed theatre wholly ruinated heart would haue burst seeing ianus sit vpon pompeis cinder wicked souldier enstalled place great captaine notwithstanding sta u reared subscription thee daughter impossible pacifi daughter lesse yet last cordus resolued himselfe deceiue daughter hauing therefore taken bath easily deceiue retired himselfe chamber intended take ection supper hauing day infirmitie body discouered meant embracing thee therefore said deerest daughter haue concealed nothing thee whole life entred way death haue almost attained halfe thou neyther shouldest canst recall back againe spoken commanded light carried away retired himselfe obscure place act discouered euery one glad prey taken throat greedie wolues accuser ianus incitation presented themselues siege tutor alwayes vnder mother custodie hee house owne yet would leaue thine yong man stature beautie strength bodie borne souldier refused warfare hee would leaue thee desolate consider marcia many com ort mother oftentimes haue contained selfe many consideration moued thereunto first supposed despoile thee sorrow vnable yet suppresse thy teares meane space wipe away secondly assured selfe haue authoritie excite thee first conformed confirmed selfe furthermore afraid mastered fortune would haue troden vnder foote loued therefore endeuour howsoeuer laying hand mine owne wound creepe forward pernicious vntimely remedy expected therefore whilest thy sorrow weakened disheartned selfe end mitigated confirmed delay sustaine remedy might suffer selfe comforted cured moreouer turned ouer thing whereby prouoked cut vp thing alreadie cured man say kinde consolation reuiue long buried euils discouer vnto vnderstanding aduersities scarcely endure presence one onely let man thinke affliction crosse pernicious surmount remedy oftentimes cured contrary therefore present sorrow owne attendant make palliatiue cure eare scarrifie shall get thy inuincible spirit hath ouermastered many misery may ashamed shrink one wound body hath oftentimes bin cicatrized let therefore weepe mourne longer whose delicate mind haue beene weakened long felicitie quickly iected vpon motion slightest misery let haue spent whole yeares calamitie indure grieuous assault confident vnmoueable constancy one good hath continuall infelicitie finally hardneth tormenteth ordinarily fortune hath giuen thee intermission hath exercised thee grieuous sorrowes nay hath spared thee day thy birth thou diddest loose thy mother soone thou wert borne nay euen thy entrance world soone thou wert abandoned life thou wert brought vp vnder thy stepdame thou obsequiousnesse pietie much could expected naturall daughter compelledst thy mother yet none hath paide dearely finde good stepdame thou expectedst arriuall thine vncle mother side man vertuous valiant thou diddest loose lest fortune make thy misfortune slight delay moneth thou buriedst thy deerest spouse thou haddest three sonnes height thy sorrow mournefull tidings brought thee euen thy child absent thy misery beene reserued till time end thy sorrow might haue meanes reliefe refuge passe ouer many danger many affright incessantly assaulted thee thou hast endured lap wherein time thou hast dandled thy three little nephewes thou hast afterward entertained dead bone twenty dayes thou haddest solemnized obsequies sonne died enfolded thine armes attended thy louing kiss thou heardest newes banished thou wert yet vnexercised bewaile liuing chap iii confesse later wound one grieuous thou hast euer felt although accident grieuous yet heluias constancie much approued may resist hath scratcht skin hath pierced depth thy breast entrailes euen yong souldiers bemoane themselues ouermuch slight wound fearefull phisitians hand surgeon razor contrariwise old souldiers although thrust thorow doe patiently without groning suffer armes leg cut body owne must thou present thy selfe great courage entertayne thy cure remoue thy selfe lamentation shrill shreeks immoderate howling disconsolate woman vaine hast thou suffered many misery tho hast yet learned miserable thinkest thou deale fearfully thee haue taken none thine euills thee haue heaped vp laid thee haue done resolutely resolued ouercome thy griefe circumscribe chap iiii shall first get vpper hand thinkesenecaes et treatise e distinguisheth two mine grieuous first vndertake thy piet e content giue care haue euill cannot approue vnto thee make manifest thing wherewith thou thinkest oppressed intolerable may belieued yet please selfe shall happie amongst thing wont make others miserable thou art credit others concerneth mee selfe tell thee end thou maiest deluded ill grounded report miserable nay say secure thee cannot miserable chap v first borne vnder good condition entereth consideratio former point concerneth himselfe sheweth miserable first nature hath taught v bee contented little except wee forsake nature hath disposed thing depresse hee hath alwaies endeuoured greatest good consist himselfe complement content bee resident heart say wise man could freely speake would denie miserable contrariwise would maintaine boldly fortunate men would repute selfe nearely lodged god present sufficient mitigate miseri haue wholly dedicated selfe wisemen scarce able enough assure counsaile selfe haue retired selfe another man marcellus thou knowest euery place wisemans country shall wee say hath banished thee hath hee beene country space ten whole yeeres vndoubtedly end encrease romane empire yet absent long behold africa draweth vnto replenished alarum threatning war spaine recalleth repaireth broken dispersed troupe pompey perfidious aegypt calles forth conclusion whole world intent vpon occasion shaken empire wh ther shall march first party shall hee first oppose himselfe victory shall driue thorow country world let nation reuerence serue thy selfe finish thy dayes content tho art much esteemed brutus constantly therefore marcellus endure exile neither change place way change mind although pressed pouerty wherein euill man knoweth well auarice dissolution ouerturne thing haue yet ouerturned vnderstanding little necessary man entertainement hath vertuous man need mine owne part finde dispossessed many incumbrance good desire thing whereof body standeth need short hee demandeth couering defence colde mea e drinke extinguish hunger thirst man desireth besides serueth entertaine excesse hath true vse necessary ound depthes murther many beastes fill belly goe fish oyster forraine vnknown sea god goddess may destroy men whose dissolution hath exceeded bound romane empire much enuied haue fowle ambitious kitchen taken brought beyond loud phasis part asia ashamed send dainty parthian whome yet wee haue demanded recompence wrong haue done v bring place know proper enkindle glutton appetite decayed stomackes hardly disgest bei g glutted many dainty brought farthest ocean vomit end may eate eate end may vomit take time disgest dainty morsel search whole world man dispise delicacy wrong doth hee pouerty man desire pouerty likewise profiteth healed wils poore man depriued dainty ceaseth wish yet vndoubtedly hee cannot hee like catus caesar nature thinke brought world shew great vice might doe great worldly prosp ritie spent one supper summe two hundreth fiftie thousand crownes herein assisted wit best bellygods yet scarcely found might consume one repast reuenue three prouinces miserable men whose pallats pleased precious dainty made precious reason excellent sauour sweetnesse yeeld taste reason raritie cunning dressing otherwise would awaken themselues neuer little neede many art entertaine belly neede traffiques desolation wood fishing sea riuers nature hath furnished place sufficient meat body country place like blinde men passe ouer trauell nation saile sea may satisfie hunger little prouoke much chap x pleaseth aske rig lanch ship arme hand wilde beast men ontinuation inuectiue intemperance runne hither thither tumultuously heape rich vpon rich thinke litle body desperate furie extreme folly thou canst hold little desire much although therefore increase rent enlarge bound land yet shall neuer make bodi greater traffique hath beene prosperous warfare hath brought home rich spoiles dainty haue sought place gathered together bestow prouision heape vp many thing frugalitie prosperitie ancient roman vndoubtedly ancestor whose vertues time sustayne vice vnhappie prepared meat owne hand whose bed earth whose house yet shined gold whose temple yet shined precious stone day sware religiously god made earth sworne image returned enemie resolution die end would violate plighted faith accompt lesse blessedly liued dictator gaue audience embassadours samnite time dressed homely victual fire owne hand yea hand alreadie oftentimes defeated enemie put c owne laurell lap piter capitoline better apicius liued memorie citie sometimes philosopher commanded depart corrupters youth made profession science gourmandise infected whole age discipline whose death shall amisse consider know gathered together kitchin summe two million halfe gold hee particular banquet consumed present giuen prince great reuenue capitoll finding himselfe much debt beganne time consider estate affaire stood finding remained yet summe two hundreth fiftie thousand crownes supposing litle danger die hunger killed himselfe poison great dissolution thought himselfe poore hauing two hundreth fiftie thousand crownes goe thinke measure monie minde pertinent matter chap xi apicivs made small reckoning two hundreth fiftie thousand crownes hauing sufficiently detested intemperance proueth againe euery countrie hath enough selfe nourish inhabiteth desire worldly good insatiable men desire wish droue away poison man depraued minde last potion holsommest eate hee drunke poison delighted immeasurable banquet gloried therein bragged vice drawne whole citie admiration riot hee incited youth themselues apt enough follow euill example follow imitate end men keepe measure vse worldly good notwithstanding haue bound abuse follow euill customes hath limit rule vnbridled wil couetousnesse thinketh thing enough nature sufficed little pouertie incommoditie banished none exile miserable fertile enough nourish one man banished man couet gowne lodging hee desireth vse hee shall neither want house cloathing body couered little nourished nature hath made euery thing easie shee knew necessarie man wish furre gowne purple embroidered gold composed diuers colour rich fashion hee poore owne default rigour aduersitie restore vnto man hee hath lost yet shalt thou doe nothing hee shall want desireth thee banisht man wanteth hath coueteth cubberd garnished vessell gold siluer cup great price long agoe laboured cunning workman hand medal made precious men madnesse troupe seruants great house otherwaies spacious vnable containe goodly stable furnished many fat gallant horse marbels stone price brought corner world let man gather vp together many thing yet neuer satisfie vnsatiable minde water world sufficient quench thirst desireth drinke satisfie necessitie extinguish heat proceeding inflammation entrailes thirst sicknesse neither hapneth monie meate also nature euery desire proceedeth errour want whatsoeuer thou shalt heape vp serue inflame satisfie containeth himselfe within naturall measure haue sence pouertie mediocritie contrarie side alwaies euery content exceedeth mediocritie midst greatest rich shall alwayes finde pouertie attendeth solitarie barren place suffice content themselues necessarie thing desire superfluity haue neuer enough although whole kingdomes minde maketh men rich accompanieth exile desart finding sufficient maintaine bodie hath good aboundance enioyeth contentedly mony appertaineth nothing mind thing vntrained mind much addicted body much affect vertuous men cannot loue good world concerne immortall god precious stone gold siluer great table well garnished earthly burthen sincere minde forgetfull nature cannot loue alwayes light mount high heauen soone findeth gate open meane much bond body masse flesh inuironeth permit vpon wing suddain swift thoght visiteth raiseth celestiall thing therefore freeman allied god great world time neuer banished thought circleth heauens neuer part thou hast alwayes restrained liberalitie thou hast power thine owne thou daughter family hast forborne bestow thy fauours plentifully vpon thy child rich thou hast administred good father left v beene thine hast beene sparing thou haddest restore stranger thou hast spared credite thou haddest employ one wayes allied vnto thee estate honour charge pleasure thee thou neuer diddest respect v enrich thy selfe thou canst therefore want thy sonne taken thee safetie neuer thoughtest appertained vnto thee chap xv consolation must aimed withstand remedie mother sorrow better specifieth party appliet diuers remedy whence true force thy motherly sorrow doth arise want embrace deare child cannot see cannot deuise whose sight redeemed sorrow communicated al discontent thee drinke eate thee place likewise whereas met last time cannot haue great efficacie afflict minde likewise fortune cruelly complot thee thou wert secure fearedst matter dared assault thee three dayes strucken time beene fitly separated distance place absence yeares disposed thee affliction thou camest backe againe vnto enioy pleasure contentment thy sonne end thou mightest lose good conuerse communicate haddest thou beene separated long time assault much vexed thee distance time might haue asswaged thy sorrowes thou haddest beene seuered thou haddest endured thy losse contentedly thou haddest enioied last fruit yet two day thy son companie cruel destinie hath carried matter sort thou foundest rome time banished arriuedst ontinently afterwards receiue griefe vpon departure furious affliction first thou hast lost thy precedent wound yet vnhealed haue beene renewed againe chap xvi thou oughtest alleage thine excuse confirmeth consideration wom n infirmity thou art woman almost permitted weepe fill yet ought measure therefore ancestor allowed ten moneths space bewaile husband limiting sort publike ordinance obstinate sadne woman pretended hinder teares bring end foolish extinguish reason thou shouldest build vpon certaine woman hauing begunne entertaine sorrow neuer giue ouer till death hath made end thou hast knowne diuers hauing lost sonnes haue neuer afterwards one greatest euils raigne time hath entangled thee amongst diuers others pearles precious stone haue tempted thee rich esteemed greatest good world haue bewitched thine eye dangerous example wherewith neuer hast thou according custome diuers woman desire nothing reputed bewtifull hidden thy grossenesse beene vnfitting burthen neither hast thou made away fruit thy wombe thou thoughtest thou haddest sometimes setled gilippus trauelled towards syracu hee saw star setled selfe vpon lance roman campe men iudgment appeared certain dart set fire reason fire aire fell oftentimes maner lightning wont follow westward westerly argument part heauens crownes made ordinarily windes engendred higher region aire hath none circle windes lodged vnder argument adde likewise crowne neuer gathered aire setled still otherwise neuer seene aire setled may pushed extended moulded forme agitated cannot receiue impression light formed neither isteth euery first part portion thereof scattered hath stay therefore neuer shall see planet whatsoeuer crowned except aire thick calme meanes whereof capable conserue line appearance begirteth round brightnesse without cause call againe thy remembrance example proposed thee little stone cast fishpoole lake setled water maketh innumerable circle doth riuer water fli th thus quickly giueth leisure meanes stone forme figure therefore falleth aire setled may receiue impression fleeteth runneth away swiftly incapable forme disperseth euery gure would approch staied circle scattered litle litle confounded themselues expresse stilnesse repose tranquilitie aire scatter one side winde commeth thence opened diuers place storme follow commeth passe may vnderstood thinges haue declared alreadie whole face circle vanish appeareth aire moderate consequently still peaceable cut one side see aire shaken side opened winde blow dispersed euery part signe assailed diuers way aire stirreth selfe one side meanes whereof appeareth storme hand combate windes reason inconstancie aire whirleth turneth selfe thus part crownes part appeare moone night time noted star seldome day grecian haue denied whereas history reproue confute caus raritie light sunne strong aire selfe agitated hot lesse thick power moone feeble therefore easily sustained aire inuironeth cel stiall fire feeble cannot beames breake scatter aire thence commeth impression made time without let pierce plant themselues easily solid matter scattereth doth day aire likewise ought bee thick exclude driue away brightnesse lent neither thin attenuate giueth meanes beames beat vpon stay temperature diuided celestiall acriall earthly thing first part examineth nature star greatnes forme fire wherein world included whether heauen solid firme concreate matter compact subtill thin substance whether dr ueth driuen whether star vnder fixed contexture thereof sunne obserueth annuall change whether obserueth oblique course like question second part intreateth impression ayre conuerse betwixt heauen end destiny ordaineth thus shall bee made destinated one shall bee eloquent man vnder condition destinated hee bee instructed good letter destiny therefore addicteth study cause hee shall become wise man shall bee rich traffique vpon sea order fate promiseth great patrimony destiny likewise inclosed hee shall set sayle wind reason thereof without feare exception shall embarque sayle say expiation hee shall escape danger hee hath appeased forethreatned wrath god sacrifice likewise destiny must expiate therefore shall doe thing haue beene oftentimes opposed v approue nothing hath left power hath beene committed destiny matter shall bee handled tell remaineth somewhat man although destiny continueth haue explicated question order fate certaine expiation remedy prodigy preuent danger remedy impugne destiny comprehended law saiest thou doth southsayer profite mee although hee co nsell nothing yet must necessarily make expiation sufficeth minister destiny health seemeth proceed fate yet ought wee thanke physitian benefite fate came vnto v hand chap xxxix caecinna saith diuers sort lightning regard signification according tuscan stoiques three sort lightning one counsell authority third estate first precedeth act commeth thought flash lightning counselleth discouereth thought deuiseth second lightning commeth thing executed signifie eyther good euill fortune shall succeed third lightning happeneth men rest without thinking thing sort lightning menasseth promiseth admonisheth reason whereof caecinna nameth momentary know counsell hee admonisheth giueth counsell yet hath distinction therefore separated counsell first perswadeth disswadeth third containeth simple aduice flie imminent perill wee feare neighbour decei e v set fire house slaues conspire v besides see distinction first concerneth thinketh thinketh nothing euery thing hath property wee counsell deliberate wee admonish bethinke themselues chap xl first three sort concerne lightning diuers name lightning according diuers effect signification thereof sort lightning one pierceth scattereth burneth lightning pierceth subtle flaming taking flight thorow narrow passage reason flame subtle thinne nothing dissipateth gathered together ball hauing intermixed selfe force coacted stormy winde meanes whereof lightning entreth issueth ordinarily one habite force spred large pierceth breaketh toucheth burneth hath much terrestriall vapour fiery flaming meanes whereof hee leaueth great k fire behinde remaine thing hath strucken lightning falleth without fire wee properly call firie lightning leaueth manifest markes fire behinde lightning burneth blacketh burneth three sort either attainteth blasteth sleightly burneth causeth thing struken fall fire fire difference sort meanes burned bla ed scorched likewise blasted scorched alwayes burned may bee fire hath giuen light attaint wee know many thing consumed fire without making flame nothing burne except burned adde word one thing may bee burned yet kindled something kindled burned chap xli effect lightning blacke thing touch tuscan opinion touching falling lightning passe ouer kinde lightning blacketh thinges beateth vpon eyther discoloureth coloureth discouer difference discoloured whose colour vitiated changed thing coloured whose appearance otherwise first blew blacke pale tuscians stoikes accord herein differ tuscan say iupiter darteth lightning giue three different handful cast first say admonisheth peaceable darted good iupiter himselfe second likewise darted hand aduice counsell whereunto hee calleth twelue god kind lightning sometimes doth seem good without harming vpon sent third also darted iupiter hee hath consulted god call superiours infolded spoyleth includeth ouerturneth meeteth withall publike particular fire consumeth whatsoeuer meeteth chap xlii obserue well shall perceiue first sight antiquity erreth herein explication tuscan opinion according senacaes mind folly belieue iupiter darteth lightning cloudes sometimes catch hold statue pillar tree blasting sheepe innocent beast burning vp altar yet sparing sacrilegious person hee sufficient counsell himselfe hee must call god assist likewise lightning hee himselfe darteth presage ioy peace lightninges darted plurality voyces many god dangerous aske mee opinion thinke tuscan besotted belieue iupiter hath beene suspence ill addressed execute pray hee hath darted fire fall innocent beast leaue wicked vnpunished shall wee say hee would vse greatest iustice hath succeeded according minde intention saide wisemen pretending clammie limie pitchie substance others cause water bred according ordinance nature body oftentimes earth humour corrupted either stroake shaking age place cold heate offence nature sulphurous earth draw certaine humour sometimes continue long diuers humidity earth body sometimes little euen therefore body vaine opened bloud floweth long vntill vntill orifice pricke shut hath cicatrise sort bloud stopped sort earth vaines open brook riuers spread themselues considered great orifice water consumed sometimes dried vp impediment sometimes vniteth selfe cicatris followeth way hath made sometimes masse earth wee said immutable ceaseth conuert humiditie nutriment sometimes conduit dried filled againe either assembling owne force gathering others ofttimes thing void set neere vnto thing full draw humor passeth easily another thing oftentimes earth drieth selfe afterwards becommeth moist falleth vnder earth happeneth cloud earth thickeneth selfe engendereth humidity waightie longer containe oftentimes gathereth thin dispersed liquor like vnto dew gathered diuers place one master make fountaines call sweat earth certaine droppes expressed thorow straitnesse place drawne cunning thing shee hath resolued doe beginning whereunto commeth sodainely determinately first day world informed vnity shee came take habitude wee see shee hath shee prefixed day wherein earth bee drowned end might bee enterprise difficult execution new worke sea long since haue exercised fashioned themselues thereunto seest thou floudes ocean runne towardes bankes sought liberty hast thou obserued floud hath aduanced selfe put sea possession earth doest thou perceiue sea doth nothing ome tempest bound restraine danger part thou hearest tumult whence issue many riuers great noyse nature hath lodged much water assaile v euery side shee thinketh fitte true digging earth wee finde water eyther vndermined auarice pushed forward cause wee haue digged searched little deeper sometimes bloudy death ensueth furthermore certaine lake vnder earth maruailous great much hidden sea besides great number riuers streames thorow certaine passage vnder earth shall bee therefore euerie side certaine course deluge part water floating thorow earth others long time brideled restrained shall finally gette vpper hand shall ioyne floudes riuers pooles marishes sea shall fill brim mouthes fountaines shall enlarge euen belly emptying selfe wasteth body force dissipated swet like sort earth shall melt selfe cause ceasing shall finde meanes plunge drown selfe selfe thinke many great thing shall confound themselues together neyther shall bee long delay ruine world shall remitte thing course diligence accord betwixt partes thereof shall bee shaken incontinently cloudes shall breake forth water beneath shall ue bottomlesse caues couer earth nothing violent hard bee stayed rebellious pernicious would restraine violent water shee shall vse liberty granted commandement nature shee shall fill shee rrauerseth enuironeth euen fire issuing diuers place sodainely setteth fire vnderstanding time c mee able noah shall bee flame conspiring assembling together make one body moment sea vented powred forth shall come ioyne one waues shall rage alwayes thus mankind shall bee ruined beast likewise brought confusion whose nature men taken vpon earth shall sucke vp water constraine sea returne within bound tempest channell ocean driuen farre limit shall chased caues ancient order shall bee reestablished euery liuing creature shall bee engendred anew earth shall bee inhabited innocent men borne better hap mankind shall perseuer long integrity shall onely bee long time men shall bee new wickednesse shall incontinently flie middest vertue hard bee found shee requireth guide gouernour touching vice men learne without master end third booke naturall question natvrall qvestions written lvcivs annaevs seneca dedicated lvcillivs fourth booke preface contentment vertuous man receiueth himselfe thou art much delighted lucillius best sicily gouernment thou writest vnto full repose without trouble please thee farre thou wilt containe thy selfe within thy limit makest empire procuration ouernment doubt thou wilt carrie thy selfe thi sort know farre thou art estranged ambition familiarly thou art addicted delighted honest retirement studie good letter cannot support containe themselues haue need conuersation men multiplicitie affaire thou accordest well thy selfe neither wonder men partaker great good wee v imperious troublesome selues sometimes cherish selues much otherwhiles little day heart puffed vp pride morrow couetousnesse tormenteth v prostituted vaine pleasure anone burned care trauaile worst neuer alone retired selues ust eeds therefore continuall debate accompanied many enormous vice doe therefore lucillius thou wert accustomed doe seperate thy selfe much thou canst communitie neither permit thy selfe accosted flatterer craft master bewitching greater richer sort poyson lattery taste great men thou shalt hardly esca e although thou take heed beleeue entrap e thou betray thy selfe treason flattery haue naturally force pleasing although reiected oftentimes ex luded last entertained repulse maketh encrease neither disgrace outrage tame shall speake incredible yet true man hit place open happily therefore lieth open dispose thy selfe therefore sort thou mayest assured thou canst touched thou mayest impenitrable thou hast caried chariest eye strike thee thorow armes thou reputest assured one vse flatterie secretly sparingly another openly counterfeising foole men sight simplicitie cunning plancus one cunningest sicophant vellius time said ought flatter cretly dissimulation vaine saith flattery obscured flatterer getteth much discouered likewise blush hath beene taunted thinke thou shalt mee e great number plancus sufficient remedie flatterie refuse praised crispus passienus whose equall n uer know subtill discouerie thing especially distinguishing uring vice oftentimes said wee onely put dore flatte y shut sort wont put friend thrust backe contenteth v gratefull breake open remember haue heard great philosopher demetrius say certaine slaue enfranchised goodly touch fool sh rub man comedie auarice become rich shortest way heape vp great wealth day wherein repented himselfe good conscience neuer saith enuie practises teach haue need meanes escape shipwrack flie contention happen betweene buyer seller trust incertaintie countrie life retire themselues exercise lesse certaine pleading lesse manner likewise may easily ioyfully enrich themselues impouerish ease quiet sweare saith thou art higher fidus annaeus apollonius picta although thou hast meane crooked statute fracas say thou art liberall man wherof debate shall excepted carrieth himselfe hee saith winde fluent aire one part winde fluent aire violence force aire fleeteth one part course aire litle vehement ordinarie know may bee answered part breuiti b sufficient defend v r proo e let v vse man circumspect let spare word whose adiection hee may exclude cauill let v come matter selfe haue sufficiently disputed forme chap ii democritvs saith many small body whereof winde composed calleth atomi voide streight followeth winde contrariwise estate aire calme peaceable much voide atomes euen market place street long little companie man may walke without tumult companie meeteth straight groweth quarrell throng iustle one another space wherein inuironed many body haue filled small place must needes bee incountring one another one pushed push back againe confused together compresse one another thence commeth winde two body debate fallen downe haue long time floted remayned suspence incline themselues body great exstent neither iustle one another impelled one chap iii refutation democritus argument former chapter false opinion thou maist gather hereby skie cloudie aire thick winde stirring time diuers body assembled together whence proceedeth also thicknesse cloud adde herevnto riuers lake fog fall oftentimes body pressed conioyned together yet winde sometimes great mist spred abroad scarce one man see another though stand neare together come passe except many body enclosed themselues little space time wanteth winde foggie adde hereunto falleth contrarie side rising sunne ordinarily attenuateth thick moist aire vpon rise doth winde rise body set libertie presse multitude resolued chap iiii therefore saye thou winde made diuers sort windes made since thou c nfessest made ter one manner sometimes earth pusheth caues great abundance ayre oftimes great continuall xhalation driueth vp high shee depr s change intermixed ayre turned wind neither b pe waded belieue conceale men doe hold meane meate wind caused body cannot burst th except viole like wise sometimes scharg belly noice making n escape heard spaciou na ure maintaineth thing changing nature produceth windes good v shee disgesteth alwayes otherwise wee might feare stinke vncle nnesse therefore mo e app ance ay part earth necessarily arriue g numbe atomes heaped together afterwards attennated hapneth winde made enlargeth selfe narrow place requireth greater space chap v thinkest thou uaporations water earth onely cause wind ayre hath selfe naturall faculty motion grauity aire caused afterwards resolued violence thing stood thicke needefull extenuated striue get greater space mine owne part iudge truer firmer cause ayre hath naturall force mouing selfe shee hath selfe thinges haue without hauing need conceiuing thinkest thou force motion hath beene giuen v ay ha h beene condemned remaine idle without agitation considering tha water ceaseth haue motion although windes bee calme otherwise shee could breed fish wee see likewise mosse herb grow water float aboue chap vi somewhat therefore vitall water speake onely water hath somthing vitall selfe fire consumeth thing createth likewise somethings cannot seem b e true difference betwixt ayre wind betwixt lake riuer sometimes sunne selfe cause winde sometimes melting colde ayre finding thicke closed selfe purifieth dilateth chap vii whense wind proceed haue spoken diuers current maruailous swiftnesse spend themselues bottomlesse pit others gentill spred abroade spacious channells flow peaceably without noise denie contayned n vast receptacle diuers place remayne repose without stirring neede long time insist vpon proofe many water earth would suffice produce many flouds shee aboundance store thus must needes b e sometimes riuer swelleth inwardly carryeth masse earth beginning dissolued rest aboue shaken followeth man ouertr steth eye cannot extend minde f rther ye hi body beleeueth cauities earth gulfes spacious sea see thing may hinder shore composed thing daily meete withall passe although worthy admiration contrariwise take singular pleasure beholde smallest trifle haue noueltie assembly therefore starres whereby beauty immeasurable chap xxxii wonderest thou wisedome hath yet attained perfection iniquitie yet wholly discouered shee new borne bestow labour vpon eies hand seruice se keth wisedome iudgeth worthy superficiall knowledge respecteth philosophie liberall studie thereof play pastime put downe rayneth man knoweth loose time therefore many schooles philosopher emptie old new academique haue reader left teach
